Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406 Record retention -- Commission estimates tax if person fails to file a return.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(1): (1)(a); 59-1-1408 A person subject to a tax, fee, or charge shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(1)(a): keep in a form prescribed by the commission books and records that are necessary to determine the amount of a tax, fee, or charge the person owes;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(1)(b): (1)(a); 59-1-1408 keep books and records described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(1)(c): open the person's books and records for examination at any time by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(1)(c)(i): the commission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(1)(c)(ii): an agent or representative the commission designates.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(2)(a): If a person required to file a return with the commission fails to file the return with the commission, the commission may estimate the tax, fee, or charge due from the best information or knowledge the commission can obtain.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(2)(b): (2)(a) An estimate the commission makes under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(3): (2)(a) For the purpose of ascertaining the correctness of a return or for estimating a tax, fee, or charge due in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(3)(a): examine the books and records bearing upon the matter required to be included in a return;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(3)(b): authorize an agent or representative designated by the commission to examine the books and records bearing upon the matter required to be included in a return;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(3)(c): require the attendance of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(3)(c)(i): an officer or employee of a person required to make a return; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(3)(c)(ii): a person having knowledge of a pertinent fact;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(3)(d): take testimony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1406(3)(e): require any other necessary information.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407 Mathematical errors.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(1): The commission shall correct a mathematical error.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(2): The commission shall provide notice to a person if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(2)(a): because of a mathematical error appearing on a return, an amount of tax, fee, or charge in excess of that shown upon the return is due; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(2)(b): an assessment of the amount of tax, fee, or charge is or will be made on the basis of what would have been the correct amount of tax, fee, or charge but for the mathematical error.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(3): (2) The notice required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(3)(a): shall describe the mathematical error; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(3)(b): is not considered to be a notice of deficiency.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(4): (2); (2); (2); (2) For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(4)(a): (2) there is no restriction upon the assessment and collection of an amount of tax, fee, or charge described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(4)(b): (2); (2) the person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(4)(b)(i): (2) file a petition to the commission on the basis of a notice provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1407(4)(b)(ii): apply for review by a district court or the Utah Supreme Court of the determination of a mathematical error by the commission.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409 Definition -- Recomputation of amounts due -- Refunds allowed.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(1): As used in this section, "overpayment" means the amount by which a tax, fee, or charge a person pays exceeds the amount of tax, fee, or charge the person owes.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(2): 59-1-1404 If the commission determines that the correct amount of a tax, fee, or charge a person is required to remit is greater or less than the amount shown to be due on a return, the commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(2)(a): recompute the tax, fee, or charge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(2)(b): 59-1-1404 mail notice to the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(2)(b)(i): that the commission recomputed the tax, fee, or charge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(2)(b)(ii): 59-1-1404 in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(3): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (C); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act If the amount of a tax, fee, or charge a person pays exceeds the amount of tax, fee, or charge the person owes, the commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(3)(a): credit the overpayment against any liability the person owes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(3)(b): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (C); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act refund any balance to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(3)(b)(i): the person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(3)(b)(ii): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (C); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(3)(b)(ii)(A): the person's assignee;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(3)(b)(ii)(B): the person's personal representative;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(3)(b)(ii)(C): the person's successor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(3)(b)(ii)(D): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (C); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act a person similar to Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(4): The commission may not credit or refund interest on an overpayment to a person if the commission determines that the overpayment was made for the purpose of investment.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(5): 59-1-1404 If the commission erroneously determines an amount of tax, fee, or charge to be due from a person, the commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(5)(a): authorize the amount to be cancelled upon the commission's records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(5)(b): 59-1-1404 mail notice to the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(5)(b)(i): that the commission cancelled the amount upon the commission's records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1409(5)(b)(ii): 59-1-1404 in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410 Action for collection of tax, fee, or charge -- Action for refund or credit of liability -- Denial of refund claim under appeal -- Appeal of denied refund claim.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(1): 59-5-114; 59-7-519; 59-10-536; 59-11-113
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(1)(a): 59-5-114; 59-7-519; 59-10-536; 59-11-113 Except as provided in Subsections (3) through (7) and Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(1)(b): Except as provided in Subsections (3) through (7), if the commission does not assess a tax, fee, or charge within the three-year period provided in Subsection (1)(a), the commission may not commence a proceeding to collect the tax, fee, or charge.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), for purposes of this part, a return filed before the last day prescribed by statute or rule for filing the return is considered to be filed on the last day for filing the return.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(2)(b): A return of withholding tax under Chapter 10, Part 4, Withholding of Tax, is considered to be filed on April 15 of the succeeding calendar year if the return:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(2)(b)(i): is for a period ending with or within a calendar year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(2)(b)(ii): is filed before April 15 of the succeeding calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(3): 59-1-1406 The commission may assess a tax, fee, or charge or commence a proceeding for the collection of a tax, fee, or charge at any time if:

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(5)(c): the three-year period under Subsection (1) expires before the commission completes the audit.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(6): An assessment under Subsection (5) shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(6)(a): for the time period for which the commission could not make the assessment because of the expiration of the three-year period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(6)(b): in an amount equal to the difference between:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(6)(b)(i): the commission's estimate of the amount of tax, fee, or charge the person would have been assessed for the time period described in Subsection (6)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(6)(b)(ii): the amount of tax, fee, or charge the person actually paid for the time period described in Subsection (6)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(7): If a person erroneously pays a liability, overpays a liability, pays a liability more than once, or the commission erroneously receives, collects, or computes a liability, the commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(7)(a): credit the liability against any amount of liability the person owes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(7)(b): refund any balance to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(7)(b)(i): the person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(7)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(7)(b)(ii)(A): the person's assign;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(7)(b)(ii)(B): the person's personal representative;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(7)(b)(ii)(C): the person's successor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(7)(b)(ii)(D): a person similar to Subsections (7)(b)(ii)(A) through (C) as determined by the commission by rule made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1410(8)(a)(ii): two years from the date the tax was paid.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1411 Notice and demand.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1411(1): The commission shall as soon as practicable mail notice and demand to a person who owes a liability that has been assessed but remains unpaid.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1411(4): Upon issuance of the notice and demand described in this section, a person that owes a liability shall pay the liability at the place and time stated in the notice and demand.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1415 Release of lien.
------------------------------------------------
The commission may release property from a lien placed under this part:Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1415(1): if the commission determines that the interests of the state will not be jeopardized by the release; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1415(2): under conditions the commission may require.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1416 Transferees.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1416(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1416(1)(a): If a transferee is obligated at law or equity for an amount of a liability of a person that originally owes a liability, the transferee is subject to this part for the assessment, payment, and collection of the amount of the liability for which the transferee has an obligation.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1416(1)(b): The period of limitations for an assessment against a transferee is extended:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1416(1)(b)(i): subject to the other provisions of this section, by one year for each successive transfer:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1416(1)(b)(i)(A): in the order of transfer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1416(1)(b)(i)(B): beginning from the person that originally owes the liability to the transferee involved; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1416(1)(b)(ii): by not more than three years in the aggregate.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1417 Burden of proof -- Statutory construction.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1417(1): 59-1-1405; Part 5, Petitions for Redetermination of Deficiencies In a proceeding before the commission, the burden of proof is on the petitioner except for determining the following, in which the burden of proof is on the commission:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1417(1)(a): whether the petitioner committed fraud with intent to evade a tax, fee, or charge;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1417(1)(b): whether the petitioner is obligated as the transferee of property of the person that originally owes a liability or a preceding transferee, but not to show that the person that originally owes a liability is obligated for the liability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1417(1)(c): 59-1-1405; Part 5, Petitions for Redetermination of Deficiencies whether the petitioner is liable for an increase in a deficiency if the increase is asserted initially after a notice of deficiency is mailed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1417(1)(c)(i): required to be reported; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1417(1)(c)(ii): of which the commission has no notice at the time the commission mails the notice of deficiency.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1417(2): Regardless of whether a taxpayer has paid or remitted a tax, fee, or charge, the commission or a court considering a case involving the tax, fee, or charge shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1417(2)(a): construe a statute imposing the tax, fee, or charge strictly in favor of the taxpayer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1417(2)(b): construe a statute providing an exemption from or credit against the tax, fee, or charge strictly against the taxpayer.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1419 Venue -- Section does not affect right to seek judicial review.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1419(1): If the commission commences a proceeding relating to the following, the venue is the Third District Court in Salt Lake City:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1419(1)(a): failure to pay a liability;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1419(1)(b): failure to file a return; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1419(1)(c): failure to supply information.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1419(2): Part 6, Judicial Review Nothing in this section affects a right to seek judicial review in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420 Administrative garnishment order for liability.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(1): 70C-7-103; Title 78B, Chapter 5, Part 5, Utah Exemptions Act As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(1)(a): "Administrative garnishment order" includes a continuing administrative garnishment order issued under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(1)(b): 70C-7-103 "Disposable earnings" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(1)(c): "Garnishee" means a person to whom the commission issues an administrative garnishment order under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(1)(d): Title 78B, Chapter 5, Part 5, Utah Exemptions Act "Nonexempt periodic payment" means any recurring payment that, under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(2): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(2)(a): (3) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(2)(b): In addition to the underlying liability, the commission may satisfy through an administrative garnishment any costs or fees incurred by the commission as a result of issuing the administrative garnishment order.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(3): (2); 59-1-1414 The commission may issue an administrative garnishment order to a person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(3)(a): 59-1-1414 the commission has filed a warrant against the taxpayer for the underlying liability in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(3)(b): the commission's executive director or the executive director's designee signs the administrative garnishment order.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(4): An administrative garnishment order issued in accordance with this section is subject to the procedures and due process protections provided by Rule 64D, Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(5): The maximum portion of a taxpayer's disposable earnings subject to garnishment under this section is the lesser of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(5)(a): 25% of the taxpayer's disposable earnings; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(5)(b): the amount by which the taxpayer's disposable earnings for a pay period exceeds the number of weeks in that pay period multiplied by 30 times the federal minimum wage as provided in 29 U.S.C. Sec. 201 et seq., Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(6): Upon agreement by the garnishee, the parties to an administrative garnishment order may accept and transmit documents relating to the administrative garnishment order by electronic means, including service of process, proof of service, interrogatories, answers, and any other information shared between the garnishee and the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7): (7)(b)(i); (ii); (3)(a); 78A-2-216 In an administrative garnishment order issued under this section, the commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(a): identify the taxpayer, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(a)(i): the taxpayer's name and address; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(a)(ii): if known:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(a)(ii)(A): the last four digits of the taxpayer's social security number, or the taxpayer's full social security number, if the taxpayer's full social security number is required by federal law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(a)(ii)(B): the taxpayer's date of birth;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(b): (7)(b)(i); (ii) contain a statement that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(b)(i): if known, the nature, location, account number, and estimated value of the property subject to administrative garnishment;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(b)(ii): if known, the name, address, and phone number of the person holding the property subject to administrative garnishment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(b)(iii): (7)(b)(i); (ii) the name, address, and phone number of any person claiming an interest in the property described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(c): state whether any of the property subject to administrative garnishment consists of earnings;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(d): (3)(a) state the outstanding amount owed under the warrant described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(e): state the amount of any applicable costs or fees included in the administrative garnishment;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(f): state the manner in which the garnishee shall deliver the property to the commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(7)(g): 78A-2-216 state that the commission shall pay the garnishee the fee described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8): (8)(d)(i); (9)(c) As part of the administrative garnishment order, the commission shall serve on the garnishee the following interrogatories:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(a): whether the garnishee is indebted to the taxpayer and, if so, the nature of the indebtedness;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(b): whether the garnishee possesses or controls any property of the taxpayer, and, if so, the nature, location, and estimated value of the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(c): whether the garnishee knows of any property of the taxpayer in the possession or control of another person, and if so, the following information about the property:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(c)(i): the nature;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(c)(ii): the location; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(c)(iii): the estimated value;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(d): (8)(d)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(d)(i): whether the garnishee intends to deduct from the property a liquidated claim against the taxpayer;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(d)(ii): (8)(d)(i) a description of any claim described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(d)(iii): the amount deducted, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(e): (9)(c) the date and manner of the garnishee's service of the documents described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(f): the date on which the taxpayer was previously served with any continuing administrative garnishment order;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(g): any other relevant information the commission requests, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(g)(i): the taxpayer's position;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(g)(ii): the taxpayer's rate of pay;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(g)(iii): the taxpayer's compensation method;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(g)(iv): the taxpayer's pay period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(8)(g)(v): a computation of the taxpayer's disposable earnings.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(9): (8); (9)(b); (9)(b) Within seven days after the day on which an administrative garnishment order is served, the garnishee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(9)(a): (8) answer each interrogatory described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(9)(b): serve the answers to the interrogatories on the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(9)(c): (9)(b) serve the taxpayer and any other person known to the garnishee to have an interest in the property a copy of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(9)(c)(i): the administrative garnishment order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(9)(c)(ii): (9)(b) the answers to the interrogatories described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(9)(d): (9)(b) inform the taxpayer of the taxpayer's right to reply to the answers described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(10): (10)(c); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(10)(a): A garnishee who acts in accordance with this section and the administrative garnishment order is released from liability unless an answer to an interrogatory is successfully controverted.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(10)(b): (10)(c); (3)(a) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(10)(b)(i): (3)(a) the lesser of the value of the property or the balance owed under the warrant described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(10)(b)(ii): reasonable costs and fees; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(10)(b)(iii): attorney fees incurred by the parties as a result of the garnishee's failure.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(10)(c): If a garnishee demonstrates that the garnishee took reasonable steps to secure the property, the commission may excuse the garnishee of liability in whole or in part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(11): If the commission files a motion to enforce an administrative garnishment order under this section, the commission shall file the motion in district court and attach to the motion a statement that the commission has in good faith conferred or attempted to confer with the garnishee in an effort to settle the issue without court action.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(12): A garnishee is not liable for drawing, accepting, making, or endorsing a negotiable instrument that is not in the possession or control of the garnishee at the time the administrative garnishment order is served.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(13): A garnishee may deduct from the property any liquidated claim against the taxpayer.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(14): (14)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(14)(a): If a debt owed by the taxpayer to the garnishee is secured by the property subject to the administrative garnishment order, the commission may apply the property to the debt.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(14)(b): (14)(a) An administrative garnishment order described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15): (15)(c); (3)(a); (15)(b)(i); (5); (8)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(a): The commission may issue a continuing administrative garnishment order against any nonexempt periodic payment.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(b): (15)(c); (3)(a) A continuing administrative garnishment order applies to payments to the taxpayer:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(b)(i): beginning on the day on which the continuing administrative garnishment order is served; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(b)(ii): (15)(c); (3)(a) ending on the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(b)(ii)(A): (15)(c) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(b)(ii)(B): 120 days after the day on which a second or subsequent continuing administrative garnishment against the taxpayer is served;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(b)(ii)(C): the day on which the last nonexempt periodic payment subject to the continuing administrative garnishment order occurs;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(b)(ii)(D): (3)(a) the day on which the warrant described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(b)(ii)(E): the day on which the commission releases the continuing administrative garnishment order.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(c): (15)(b)(i); (5) If the commission issues a continuing administrative garnishment order during the term of another continuing administrative garnishment order against the same taxpayer, the period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(c)(i): is in effect at the time the commission serves the subsequent continuing administrative garnishment order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(c)(ii): (5) requires payments greater than or equal to the maximum portion of disposable earnings described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(d): (8) For each periodic payment period, no later than seven days after the day on which the periodic payment period ends, the garnishee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(d)(i): (8) answer each interrogatory described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(d)(ii): serve the answers to the interrogatories on the commission, the taxpayer, and any other person known to the garnishee to have an interest in the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(15)(d)(iii): deliver the property to the commission in the manner specified in the continuing administrative garnishment order.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(16): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(16)(a): The commission may not name more than one garnishee in an administrative garnishment order.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(16)(b): Priority among garnishments is according to the order of service on the garnishee.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1420(16)(c): An administrative garnishment order applies to earnings accruing during the pay period in which the order is effective.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1501 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Specie Legal Tender Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1501.1 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
Subject to Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1502 Specie legal tender is legal tender in the state -- Person may not compel another person to tender or accept specie legal tender -- Court or congressional action to authorize gold or silver coin or bullion as legal tender.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1502(1): Specie legal tender is legal tender in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1502(2): Except as expressly provided by contract, a person may not compel any other person to tender or accept specie legal tender.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1502(3): Gold or silver coin or bullion, other than gold or silver coin that is issued by the United States, is considered to be specie legal tender and is legal tender in the state if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1502(3)(a): a court of competent jurisdiction issues a final, unappealable judgment or order determining that the state may recognize the gold or silver coin or bullion, other than gold or silver coin that is issued by the United States, as legal tender in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1502(3)(b): Congress enacts legislation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1502(3)(b)(i): expressly provides that the gold or silver coin or bullion, other than gold or silver coin that is issued by the United States, is legal tender in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1502(3)(b)(ii): expressly allows the state to recognize the gold or silver coin or bullion, other than gold or silver coin that is issued by the United States, as legal tender in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1502(4): 70A-1a-201 A central bank digital currency, as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1503 Nonrefundable credit -- Sales and use tax exemption -- Sales and use tax remittance.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1503(1): 59-10-1028 A nonrefundable individual income tax credit is allowed as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1503(2): 59-12-104(50) Sales of currency or coin are exempt from sales and use taxes as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1503(3): 59-12-107 The remittance of a sales and use tax on a transaction involving specie legal tender is as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1505 Attorney general to enforce part.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
The attorney general shall enforce this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1506 Severability clause.
----------------------------------------------------
If any provision of this part or the application of any provision to any person or circumstance is held invalid by a final decision of a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this part shall be given effect without the invalid provision or application.  The provisions of this part are severable.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1601 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Transparency of Ballot Propositions Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(1): 11-14-103; Title 20A, Chapter 7, Issues Submitted to the Voters
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(1)(a): 11-14-103 "Ballot proposition" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(1)(a)(i): an opinion question or other question concerning a tax increase submitted to voters for their approval or rejection; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(1)(a)(ii): 11-14-103 a question submitted to voters concerning the issuance of bonds under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(1)(b): Title 20A, Chapter 7, Issues Submitted to the Voters "Ballot proposition" does not include an initiative or referendum authorized under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(2): "Determination date" means the date of an election at which a ballot proposition is considered by voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(3): 20A-1-102 "Election officer" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(4): Title 20A, Chapter 2, Voter Registration "Eligible voter" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(4)(a): Title 20A, Chapter 2, Voter Registration has registered to vote in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(4)(b): is a resident of a voting district or precinct within the taxing entity that is holding an election to consider a ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(5): 59-2-102 "Governing body" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(6): Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act "Tax increase" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(6)(a): for a property tax, the imposition of a property tax rate or increase in a property tax rate if the imposition or increase is required to be submitted to voters for their approval or rejection; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(6)(b): Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act for a sales and use tax imposed under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(6)(b)(i): is not currently imposed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(6)(b)(ii): exceeds the sales and use tax rate that is currently imposed.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(7): 59-2-102; Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act "Taxing entity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(7)(a): 59-2-102 a taxing entity as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1602(7)(b): Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act a county, city, or town authorized to impose a sales and use tax under


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1603 Applicability of part.
------------------------------------------------------
A taxing entity may not submit a ballot proposition unless the taxing entity complies with this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604 Arguments for and against a ballot proposition -- Rebuttal arguments -- Posting arguments.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(1): The arguments for or against a ballot proposition shall conform to the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(2): (2)(c)(i)(B)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(2)(a)(i): The governing body of a taxing entity shall submit to the election officer an argument in favor of a ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(2)(a)(ii): To prepare an argument for or against a ballot proposition, an eligible voter shall file a request with the election officer at least 65 days before the election at which the ballot proposition is to be voted on.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(2)(b): If two or more eligible voters wish to submit an argument for, or an argument against, a ballot proposition, the election officer shall designate one of the eligible voters to submit the argument.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(2)(c): (2)(c)(i)(B)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(2)(c)(i): An eligible voter who submits an argument under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(2)(c)(i)(A): ensure that the argument does not exceed 500 words in length;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(2)(c)(i)(B): submit the argument to the election officer no less than 60 days before the determination date; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(2)(c)(i)(C): include with the argument the eligible voter's name, residential address, postal address, email address if available, and phone number.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(2)(c)(ii): (2)(c)(i)(B) An election officer shall refuse to accept and publish an argument that is submitted after the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3): (3)(b)(iii); (3)(c)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(a): An election officer who timely receives the arguments in favor of and against a ballot proposition shall, within one business day after the day on which the election officer receives both arguments, send, via email or mail:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(a)(i): a copy of the argument in favor of the ballot proposition to the eligible voter who submitted the argument against the ballot proposition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(a)(ii): a copy of the argument against the ballot proposition to the eligible voter who submitted the argument in favor of the ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(b): The eligible voter who submitted a timely argument in favor of the ballot proposition:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(b)(i): may submit to the election officer a rebuttal argument of the argument against the ballot proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(b)(ii): shall ensure that the rebuttal argument does not exceed 250 words in length; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(b)(iii): shall submit the rebuttal argument no later than 45 days before the election day on which the ballot proposition will be submitted to the voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(c): The eligible voter who submitted a timely argument against the ballot proposition:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(c)(i): may submit to the election officer a rebuttal argument of the argument in favor of the ballot proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(c)(ii): shall ensure that the rebuttal argument does not exceed 250 words in length; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(c)(iii): shall submit the rebuttal argument no later than 45 days before the election day on which the ballot proposition will be submitted to the voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(3)(d): (3)(b)(iii); (3)(c)(iii) An election officer shall refuse to accept and publish a rebuttal argument that is submitted after the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(4): (4)(b); (4)(a)(i); (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(4)(a): (4)(b); (4)(a)(i) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(4)(a)(i): an eligible voter may not modify an argument or rebuttal argument after the eligible voter submits the argument or rebuttal argument to the election officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(4)(a)(ii): (4)(a)(i) a person other than the eligible voter described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(4)(b): The election officer, and the eligible voter who submits an argument or rebuttal argument, may jointly agree to modify an argument or a rebuttal argument in order to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(4)(b)(i): correct factual, grammatical, and spelling errors; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(4)(b)(ii): reduce the number of words to come into compliance with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(4)(c): (4)(b) An election officer shall refuse to accept and publish an argument or rebuttal argument if the eligible voter who submits the argument or rebuttal argument fails to negotiate, in good faith, to modify the argument or rebuttal argument in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(5): An election officer may designate another eligible voter to take the place of an eligible voter described in this section if the original eligible voter is, due to injury, illness, death, or another circumstance, unable to continue to fulfill the duties of an eligible voter described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(6): 20A-7-801 The election officer of a taxing entity shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(6)(a): 20A-7-801 post the arguments and rebuttal arguments on the Statewide Electronic Voter Information Website as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(6)(b): if a taxing entity has a public website, post all arguments and rebuttal arguments in a prominent place on the taxing entity's public website for 30 consecutive days before the determination date; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(6)(c): if the taxing entity publishes a newsletter or other periodical, post all arguments and rebuttal arguments in the next scheduled newsletter or other periodical published before the determination date.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(7): (6); 59-1-1605 When posting an argument and rebuttal argument under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(7)(a): a rebuttal argument is posted in the same manner as a direct argument;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(7)(b): each rebuttal argument follows immediately after the direct argument that it seeks to rebut; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1604(7)(c): 59-1-1605 information regarding the public meeting required by Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605 Public meeting requirements.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(1): The governing body of a taxing entity shall conduct a public meeting in accordance with this section no more than 45, but at least four, days before the determination date.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(2): The governing body of the taxing entity shall allow equal time, within a reasonable limit, for a presentation of the arguments:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(2)(a): in favor of the ballot proposition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(2)(b): against the ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(3): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(3)(a): (1) A governing body of a taxing entity conducting a public meeting described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(3)(b): A taxing entity shall hold a public meeting described in this section beginning at or after 6 p.m.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(4): (1); (4)(a); (4)(a); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(4)(a): (1) A taxing entity shall provide a digital audio recording of a public meeting described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(4)(b): (4)(a); (4)(a); (4)(a) For purposes of providing the digital audio recording described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(4)(b)(i): (4)(a) if a taxing entity has a public website, provide access to the digital audio recording described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1605(4)(b)(ii): (4)(a) provide a digital copy of the recording described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1701 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Depository Institution Data Match System and Levy Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1702 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1702(1): 59-1-1704 "Agreement" means an agreement described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1702(2): 59-1-1414 "Delinquent taxpayer" means a person against whom the commission is considered to have obtained a judgment for a liability under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1702(3): 7-1-103 "Depository institution" is a depository institution described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1702(4): 59-1-1703 "Depository institution data match system" means the database that the commission develops, maintains, and operates in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1702(5): "Identifying information" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1702(5)(a): the name of the account holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1702(5)(b): the social security number of the account holder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1702(5)(c): other identifying information.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1702(6): 59-1-1402 "Liability" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1702(7): "Satisfy a liability" means to pay in full a liability that is the subject of a levy under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1703 Depository institution data match system.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1703(1): The commission shall develop, maintain, and operate a database as provided in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1703(2): (1) The database described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1703(2)(a): shall use automated data exchanges;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1703(2)(b): shall identify a delinquent taxpayer by identifying information;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1703(2)(c): may be accessed only by the commission or a depository institution;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1703(2)(d): shall be used to determine whether a delinquent taxpayer identified in the database has the same identifying information as that of an account holder at a depository institution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1703(2)(e): shall be updated by the commission on at least a quarterly basis.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704 Election to enter into an agreement.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704(1): A depository institution that does business in this state may elect to use the depository institution data match system to respond to judicial process against a delinquent taxpayer.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704(2): (1) A depository institution may not make an election under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704(3): A depository institution that elects to use the depository institution data match system shall enter into an agreement with the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704(4): An agreement under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704(4)(a): address the operation of the depository institution data match system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704(4)(b): require the depository institution to comply with this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704(4)(c): address reimbursement to the depository institution for complying with this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704(4)(d): provide for the security and confidentiality of data contained in the depository institution data match system.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704(5): An election under this section does not preclude the commission from requiring a depository institution to respond to judicial process against a delinquent taxpayer:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704(5)(a): by means other than the depository institution data match system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1704(5)(b): as provided by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1705 Requirement to access depository institution data match system.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1705(1): 59-1-1704 A depository institution that enters into an agreement with the commission in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1705(2): A depository institution that accesses the depository institution data match system shall determine whether a delinquent taxpayer identified in the depository institution data match system has the same identifying information as that of an account holder at the depository institution.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1706 Requirement for a depository institution to provide information to the commission.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A depository institution that determines under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 59-1-1706(1): the name of the account holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1706(2): the address of the account holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1706(3): the account number of the account holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1706(4): the account balance of the account holder on the day that the depository institution provides the commission the information required by this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1706(5): the type of account of the account holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1706(6): the social security number of the account holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1706(7): other information that identifies the account holder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1706(8): the name of, and contact information for, other account holders that have access to the account.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1707 Commission requirement to provide notice of levy to depository institution -- Duration of levy.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1707(1): 59-1-1706 The commission shall provide, within three business days after a depository institution provides the commission information described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1707(1)(a): stating that the commission levies an amount equal to the liability of a delinquent taxpayer that is an account holder at the depository institution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1707(1)(b): identifying the account subject to levy.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1707(2): (1); 59-1-1711 A levy described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1707(2)(a): the day on which the commission releases the levy;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1707(2)(b): the day on which the delinquent taxpayer satisfies the liability; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1707(2)(c): 59-1-1711 the day on which the depository institution releases, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1707(3): The commission shall provide notice to a depository institution by electronic means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1707(3)(a): if the commission releases a levy, no later than one business day after the day on which the commission releases the levy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1707(3)(b): if a delinquent taxpayer satisfies the liability, no later than one business day after the day on which the delinquent taxpayer satisfies the liability.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1711 Depository institution to release portion of amount subject to levy.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1711(1): 59-1-1710 Subject to the other provisions of this section, a depository institution shall release the portion of the amount subject to a levy under this part that the commission may receive in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1711(2): 59-1-1710(3); 59-1-1710; 59-1-1710(3); 59-1-1713 On the first business day after the day on which the commission provides the notice described in Subsection
