Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1711(2)(b)(ii): the fees that an account holder agreed to pay the depository institution to process a writ of garnishment in a deposit agreement.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1712 Limitations on commission authority to levy.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1712(1): During the time period that a levy the commission imposes on the account of a delinquent taxpayer is valid, the commission may not impose another levy on that account.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1712(2): The commission may impose a levy in accordance with the procedures and requirements of this part on an account subject to a previous levy under this part if that previous levy is no longer valid.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1713 Commission payment to depository institution to secure amount subject to levy.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In addition to any compensation that the commission pays to the depository institution in accordance with an agreement, the commission shall pay the depository institution $10 if the depository institution secures an amount subject to levy under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1714 Amount levied or released in error -- Rulemaking authority.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1714(1): If the commission levies an amount in error, the commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1714(1)(a): pay the cost of a depository institution charge incurred as a result of the levy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1714(1)(b): if a person other than the commission pays the depository institution charge, reimburse the person for the depository institution charge incurred as a result of the levy.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1714(2): If a depository institution releases an amount in an account holder's account to the commission in error, the commission shall return the amount to the depository institution by electronic means for deposit into the account holder's account.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1714(3): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1714(3)(a): what constitutes levying or releasing an amount in error; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1714(3)(b): the depository institution charges the commission shall pay.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1715 Limits on a depository institution's authority to disclose or provide notice -- Depository institution authority to provide information.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1715(1): 59-1-1708; (2) Before a depository institution secures an amount subject to levy in a delinquent taxpayer's account in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1715(1)(a): provided information to the commission or the commission provided information to the depository institution in relation to the account holder or the account holder's account in accordance with this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1715(1)(b): took an action in relation to the account holder or the account holder's account in accordance with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1715(2): A depository institution may provide information to an account holder describing the depository institution's duties under this part if the information the depository institution provides does not identify that the depository institution:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1715(2)(a): provides or has provided information to the commission in relation to a particular account holder or account holder's account in accordance with this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1715(2)(b): takes or has taken an action in relation to a particular account holder or account holder's account in accordance with this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1716 Limits on depository institution liability.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
A depository institution is not liable to a person for the following if the depository institution acts in good faith:Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1716(1): providing or failing to provide information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1716(2): taking or failing to take an action.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-1-1717 Confidentiality of information.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Except for the exchange of information between the commission and a depository institution that is necessary to meet the requirements of this part, information the commission obtains from a depository institution is subject to Section

Utah Code Annotated - Title 59 - Chapter 2 - Property Tax Act
*************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-101 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Property Tax Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(1)(a): "Acquisition cost" means any cost required to put an item of tangible personal property into service.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(1)(b): "Acquisition cost" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(1)(b)(i): the purchase price of a new or used item;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(1)(b)(ii): the cost of freight, shipping, loading at origin, unloading at destination, crating, skidding, or any other applicable cost of shipping;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(1)(b)(iii): the cost of installation, engineering, rigging, erection, or assembly, including foundations, pilings, utility connections, or similar costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(1)(b)(iv): sales and use taxes.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(2): "Aerial applicator" means aircraft or rotorcraft used exclusively for the purpose of engaging in dispensing activities directly affecting agriculture or horticulture with an airworthiness certificate from the Federal Aviation Administration certifying the aircraft or rotorcraft's use for agricultural and pest control purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(3): "Air charter service" means an air carrier operation that requires the customer to hire an entire aircraft rather than book passage in whatever capacity is available on a scheduled trip.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(4): "Air contract service" means an air carrier operation available only to customers that engage the services of the carrier through a contractual agreement and excess capacity on any trip and is not available to the public at large.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(5): 72-10-102 "Aircraft" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(6)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (6)(b), "airline" means an air carrier that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(6)(a)(i): operates:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(6)(a)(i)(A): on an interstate route; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(6)(a)(i)(B): on a scheduled basis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(6)(a)(ii): offers to fly one or more passengers or cargo on the basis of available capacity on a regularly scheduled route.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(6)(b): "Airline" does not include an:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(6)(b)(i): air charter service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(6)(b)(ii): air contract service.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(7): "Assessment roll" or "assessment book" means a permanent record of the assessment of property as assessed by the county assessor and the commission and may be maintained manually or as a computerized file as a consolidated record or as multiple records by type, classification, or categories.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(8): "Base parcel" means a parcel of property that was legally:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(8)(a): subdivided into two or more lots, parcels, or other divisions of land; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(8)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(8)(b)(i): combined with one or more other parcels of property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(8)(b)(ii): subdivided into two or more lots, parcels, or other divisions of land.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9): 59-2-1602; 59-2-924
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(a): 59-2-1602; 59-2-924 "Certified revenue levy" means a property tax levy that provides an amount of ad valorem property tax revenue equal to the sum of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(a)(i): 59-2-1602 the amount of ad valorem property tax revenue to be generated statewide in the previous year from imposing a multicounty assessing and collecting levy, as specified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(a)(ii): 59-2-924 the product of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(a)(ii)(A): 59-2-924 eligible new growth, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(a)(ii)(B): the multicounty assessing and collecting levy certified by the commission for the previous year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(b): For purposes of this Subsection (9), "ad valorem property tax revenue" does not include property tax revenue received by a taxing entity from personal property that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(b)(i): assessed by a county assessor in accordance with Part 3, County Assessment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(b)(ii): semiconductor manufacturing equipment.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(c): For purposes of calculating the certified revenue levy described in this Subsection (9), the commission shall use:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(c)(i): the taxable value of real property assessed by a county assessor contained on the assessment roll;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(c)(ii): the taxable value of real and personal property assessed by the commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(9)(c)(iii): the taxable year end value of personal property assessed by a county assessor contained on the prior year's assessment roll.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(10): 41-1a-301 "County-assessed commercial vehicle" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(10)(a): 41-1a-301 any commercial vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer that is not apportioned under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(10)(b): any passenger vehicle owned by a business and used by its employees for transportation as a company car or vanpool vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(10)(c): vehicles that are:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(10)(c)(i): especially constructed for towing or wrecking, and that are not otherwise used to transport goods, merchandise, or people for compensation;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(10)(c)(ii): used or licensed as taxicabs or limousines;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(10)(c)(iii): used as rental passenger cars, travel trailers, or motor homes;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(10)(c)(iv): used or licensed in this state for use as ambulances or hearses;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(10)(c)(v): especially designed and used for garbage and rubbish collection; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(10)(c)(vi): used exclusively to transport students or their instructors to or from any private, public, or religious school or school activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(11): 59-2-1330; 59-2-919.1 "Eligible judgment" means a final and unappealable judgment or order under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(11)(a): 59-2-919.1 that became a final and unappealable judgment or order no more than 14 months before the day on which the notice described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(11)(b): for which a taxing entity's share of the final and unappealable judgment or order is greater than or equal to the lesser of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(11)(b)(i): $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(11)(b)(ii): 2.5% of the total ad valorem property taxes collected by the taxing entity in the previous fiscal year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(12)(a): "Escaped property" means any property, whether personal, land, or any improvements to the property, that is subject to taxation and is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(12)(a)(i): inadvertently omitted from the tax rolls, assigned to the incorrect parcel, or assessed to the wrong taxpayer by the assessing authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(12)(a)(ii): undervalued or omitted from the tax rolls because of the failure of the taxpayer to comply with the reporting requirements of this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(12)(a)(iii): undervalued because of errors made by the assessing authority based upon incomplete or erroneous information furnished by the taxpayer.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(12)(b): "Escaped property" does not include property that is undervalued because of the use of a different valuation methodology or because of a different application of the same valuation methodology.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(13): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(13)(a): "Fair market value" means the amount at which property would change hands between a willing buyer and a willing seller, neither being under any compulsion to buy or sell and both having reasonable knowledge of the relevant facts.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(13)(b): For purposes of taxation, "fair market value" shall be determined using the current zoning laws applicable to the property in question, except in cases where there is a reasonable probability of a change in the zoning laws affecting that property in the tax year in question and the change would have an appreciable influence upon the value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(14): "Geothermal fluid" means water in any form at temperatures greater than 120 degrees centigrade naturally present in a geothermal system.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(15): "Geothermal resource" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(15)(a): the natural heat of the earth at temperatures greater than 120 degrees centigrade; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(15)(b): the energy, in whatever form, including pressure, present in, resulting from, created by, or which may be extracted from that natural heat, directly or through a material medium.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(a): "Goodwill" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(a)(i): acquired goodwill that is reported as goodwill on the books and records that a taxpayer maintains for financial reporting purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(a)(ii): the ability of a business to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(a)(ii)(A): generate income that exceeds a normal rate of return on assets and that results from a factor described in Subsection (16)(b); or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(a)(ii)(B): obtain an economic or competitive advantage resulting from a factor described in Subsection (16)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(b): The following factors apply to Subsection (16)(a)(ii):
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(b)(i): superior management skills;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(b)(ii): reputation;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(b)(iii): customer relationships;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(b)(iv): patronage; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(b)(v): a factor similar to Subsections (16)(b)(i) through (iv).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c): "Goodwill" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(i): the intangible property described in Subsection (19)(a) or (b);
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(ii): locational attributes of real property, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(ii)(A): zoning;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(ii)(B): location;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(ii)(C): view;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(ii)(D): a geographic feature;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(ii)(E): an easement;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(ii)(F): a covenant;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(ii)(G): proximity to raw materials;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(ii)(H): the condition of surrounding property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(ii)(I): proximity to markets;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(iii): value attributable to the identification of an improvement to real property, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(iii)(A): reputation of the designer, builder, or architect of the improvement;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(iii)(B): a name given to, or associated with, the improvement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(iii)(C): the historic significance of an improvement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(16)(c)(iv): the enhancement or assemblage value specifically attributable to the interrelation of the existing tangible property in place working together as a unit.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(17): 17D-1-301; 17D-1-301 "Governing body" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(17)(a): for a county, city, or town, the legislative body of the county, city, or town;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(17)(b): for a special district under Title 17B, Limited Purpose Local Government Entities - Special Districts, the  special district's board of trustees;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(17)(c): for a school district, the local board of education;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(17)(d): 17D-1-301; 17D-1-301 for a special service district under Title 17D, Chapter 1, Special Service District Act:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(17)(d)(i): 17D-1-301 the legislative body of the county or municipality that created the special service district, to the extent that the county or municipal legislative body has not delegated authority to an administrative control board established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(17)(d)(ii): 17D-1-301 the administrative control board, to the extent that the county or municipal legislative body has delegated authority to an administrative control board established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(17)(e): for a public infrastructure district under Title 17D, Chapter 4, Public Infrastructure District Act, the public infrastructure district's board of trustees.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18): 59-2-107; 59-2-1502; 59-2-1503
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (18)(c), "improvement" means a building, structure, fixture, fence, or other item that is permanently attached to land, regardless of whether the title has been acquired to the land, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(a)(i)(A): attachment to land is essential to the operation or use of the item; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(a)(i)(B): the manner of attachment to land suggests that the item will remain attached to the land in the same place over the useful life of the item; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(a)(ii): removal of the item would:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(a)(ii)(A): cause substantial damage to the item; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(a)(ii)(B): require substantial alteration or repair of a structure to which the item is attached.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(b): "Improvement" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(b)(i): an accessory to an item described in Subsection (18)(a) if the accessory is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(b)(i)(A): essential to the operation of the item described in Subsection (18)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(b)(i)(B): installed solely to serve the operation of the item described in Subsection (18)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(b)(ii): an item described in Subsection (18)(a) that is temporarily detached from the land for repairs and remains located on the land.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(c): 59-2-107; 59-2-1502; 59-2-1503 "Improvement" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(c)(i): 59-2-107 an item considered to be personal property pursuant to rules made in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(c)(ii): a moveable item that is attached to land for stability only or for an obvious temporary purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(c)(iii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(c)(iii)(A): manufacturing equipment and machinery; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(c)(iii)(B): essential accessories to manufacturing equipment and machinery;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(c)(iv): an item attached to the land in a manner that facilitates removal without substantial damage to the land or the item; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(18)(c)(v): 59-2-1502; 59-2-1503 a transportable factory-built housing unit as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19): 59-7-614 "Intangible property" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(a): property that is capable of private ownership separate from tangible property, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(a)(i): money;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(a)(ii): credits;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(a)(iii): bonds;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(a)(iv): stocks;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(a)(v): representative property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(a)(vi): franchises;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(a)(vii): licenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(a)(viii): trade names;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(a)(ix): copyrights; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(a)(x): patents;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(b): a low-income housing tax credit;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(c): goodwill; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(d): 59-7-614 a clean or renewable energy tax credit or incentive, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(d)(i): a federal renewable energy production tax credit under Section 45, Internal Revenue Code;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(d)(ii): a federal energy credit for qualified renewable electricity production facilities under Section 48, Internal Revenue Code;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(d)(iii): a federal grant for a renewable energy property under American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, Pub. L. No. 111-5, Section 1603; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(19)(d)(iv): 59-7-614 a tax credit under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(20): "Livestock" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(20)(a): a domestic animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(20)(b): a fish;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(20)(c): a fur-bearing animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(20)(d): a honeybee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(20)(e): poultry.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(21): 59-7-607; 59-10-1010 "Low-income housing tax credit" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(21)(a): a federal low-income housing tax credit under Section 42, Internal Revenue Code; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(21)(b): 59-7-607; 59-10-1010 a low-income housing tax credit under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(22): "Metalliferous minerals" includes gold, silver, copper, lead, zinc, and uranium.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(23): "Mine" means a natural deposit of either metalliferous or nonmetalliferous valuable mineral.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(24): "Mining" means the process of producing, extracting, leaching, evaporating, or otherwise removing a mineral from a mine.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(25): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(25)(a): "Mobile flight equipment" means tangible personal property that is owned or operated by an air charter service, air contract service, or airline and:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(25)(a)(i): is capable of flight or is attached to an aircraft that is capable of flight; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(25)(a)(ii): is contained in an aircraft that is capable of flight if the tangible personal property is intended to be used:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(25)(a)(ii)(A): during multiple flights;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(25)(a)(ii)(B): during a takeoff, flight, or landing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(25)(a)(ii)(C): as a service provided by an air charter service, air contract service, or airline.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(25)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(25)(b)(i): "Mobile flight equipment" does not include a spare part other than a spare engine that is rotated at regular intervals with an engine that is attached to the aircraft.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(25)(b)(ii): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the commission may make rules defining the term "regular intervals."
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(26): "Nonmetalliferous minerals" includes, but is not limited to, oil, gas, coal, salts, sand, rock, gravel, and all carboniferous materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(27): "Part-year residential property" means property that is not residential property on January 1 of a calendar year but becomes residential property after January 1 of the calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(28): 72-7-502 "Personal property" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(28)(a): every class of property as defined in Subsection (29) that is the subject of ownership and is not real estate or an improvement;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(28)(b): any pipe laid in or affixed to land whether or not the ownership of the pipe is separate from the ownership of the underlying land, even if the pipe meets the definition of an improvement;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(28)(c): bridges and ferries;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(28)(d): livestock; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(28)(e): 72-7-502 outdoor advertising structures as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(29): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(29)(a): "Property" means property that is subject to assessment and taxation according to its value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(29)(b): "Property" does not include intangible property as defined in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(30): 54-2-1
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(30)(a): 54-2-1 "Public utility" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(30)(a)(i): the operating property of a railroad, gas corporation, oil or gas transportation or pipeline company, coal slurry pipeline company, electrical corporation, sewerage corporation, or heat corporation where the company performs the service for, or delivers the commodity to, the public generally or companies serving the public generally, or in the case of a gas corporation or an electrical corporation, where the gas or electricity is sold or furnished to any member or consumers within the state for domestic, commercial, or industrial use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(30)(a)(ii): 54-2-1 the operating property of any entity or person defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(30)(b): "Public utility" does not include the operating property of a telecommunications service provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(31): 59-2-103; 59-2-1115
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(31)(a): 59-2-103; 59-2-1115 Subject to Subsection (31)(b), "qualifying exempt primary residential rental personal property" means household furnishings, furniture, and equipment that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(31)(a)(i): are used exclusively within a dwelling unit that is the primary residence of a tenant;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(31)(a)(ii): are owned by the owner of the dwelling unit that is the primary residence of a tenant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(31)(a)(iii): 59-2-103; 59-2-1115 after applying the residential exemption described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(31)(b): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the commission may by rule define the term "dwelling unit" for purposes of this Subsection (31) and Subsection (34).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(32): "Real estate" or "real property" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(32)(a): the possession of, claim to, ownership of, or right to the possession of land;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(32)(b): all mines, minerals, and quarries in and under the land, all timber belonging to individuals or corporations growing or being on the lands of this state or the United States, and all rights and privileges appertaining to these; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(32)(c): improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(33): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(33)(a): "Relationship with an owner of the property's land surface rights" means a relationship described in Subsection 267(b), Internal Revenue Code, except that the term 25% shall be substituted for the term 50% in Subsection 267(b), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(33)(b): For purposes of determining if a relationship described in Subsection 267(b), Internal Revenue Code, exists, the ownership of stock shall be determined using the ownership rules in Subsection 267(c), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(34): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(34)(a): "Residential property," for purposes of the reductions and adjustments under this chapter, means any property used for residential purposes as a primary residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(34)(b): "Residential property" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(34)(b)(i): except as provided in Subsection (34)(b)(ii), includes household furnishings, furniture, and equipment if the household furnishings, furniture, and equipment are:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(34)(b)(i)(A): used exclusively within a dwelling unit that is the primary residence of a tenant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(34)(b)(i)(B): owned by the owner of the dwelling unit that is the primary residence of a tenant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(34)(b)(ii): if the county assessor determines that the property will be used for residential purposes as a primary residence:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(34)(b)(ii)(A): property under construction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(34)(b)(ii)(B): unoccupied property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(34)(c): "Residential property" does not include property used for transient residential use.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(34)(d): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the commission may by rule define the term "dwelling unit" for purposes of Subsection (31) and this Subsection (34).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(35): "Split estate mineral rights owner" means a person that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(35)(a): has a legal right to extract a mineral from property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(35)(b): does not hold more than a 25% interest in:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(35)(b)(i): the land surface rights of the property where the wellhead is located; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(35)(b)(ii): an entity with an ownership interest in the land surface rights of the property where the wellhead is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(35)(c): is not an entity in which the owner of the land surface rights of the property where the wellhead is located holds more than a 25% interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(35)(d): does not have a relationship with an owner of the land surface rights of the property where the wellhead is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(36): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(36)(a): "State-assessed commercial vehicle" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(36)(a)(i): any commercial vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer that operates interstate or intrastate to transport passengers, freight, merchandise, or other property for hire; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(36)(a)(ii): any commercial vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer that operates interstate and transports the vehicle owner's goods or property in furtherance of the owner's commercial enterprise.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(36)(b): "State-assessed commercial vehicle" does not include vehicles used for hire that are specified in Subsection (10)(c) as county-assessed commercial vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(37): "Subdivided lot" means a lot, parcel, or other division of land, that is a division of a base parcel.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(38): "Tax area" means a geographic area created by the overlapping boundaries of one or more taxing entities.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(39): 59-2-103 "Taxable value" means fair market value less any applicable reduction allowed for residential property under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(40): "Taxing entity" means any county, city, town, school district, special taxing district, special district under Title 17B, Limited Purpose Local Government Entities - Special Districts, or other political subdivision of the state with the authority to levy a tax on property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(41): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(41)(a): "Tax roll" means a permanent record of the taxes charged on property, as extended on the assessment roll, and may be maintained on the same record or records as the assessment roll or may be maintained on a separate record properly indexed to the assessment roll.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(41)(b): "Tax roll" includes tax books, tax lists, and other similar materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-102(42): 59-12-102 "Telecommunications service provider" means the same as that term is defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103 Rate of assessment of property -- Residential property.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(1)(a)(i): "Household" means the association of individuals who live in the same dwelling, sharing the dwelling's furnishings, facilities, accommodations, and expenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(1)(a)(ii): "Household" includes married individuals, who are not legally separated, who have established domiciles at separate locations within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(1)(b): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the commission may make rules defining the term "domicile."
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(2): All tangible taxable property located within the state shall be assessed and taxed at a uniform and equal rate on the basis of its fair market value, as valued on January 1, unless otherwise provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(3): 59-2-103.5 Subject to Subsections (4) through (6) and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(4): Part-year residential property located within the state is allowed the residential exemption described in Subsection (3) if the part-year residential property is used as residential property for 183 or more consecutive calendar days during the calendar year for which the owner seeks to obtain the residential exemption.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(5): No more than one acre of land per residential unit may qualify for the residential exemption described in Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(6): 59-2-103.5; 59-2-102
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(6)(a): Except as provided in Subsections (6)(b)(ii) and (iii), a residential exemption described in Subsection (3) is limited to one primary residence per household.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(6)(b): 59-2-103.5; 59-2-102 An owner of multiple primary residences located within the state is allowed a residential exemption under Subsection (3) for:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(6)(b)(i): subject to Subsection (6)(a), the primary residence of the owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(6)(b)(ii): each residential property that is the primary residence of a tenant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103(6)(b)(iii): 59-2-103.5; 59-2-102 subject to Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5 Procedures to obtain an exemption for residential property -- Procedure if property owner or property no longer qualifies to receive a residential exemption.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(1): 59-2-103 Subject to Subsections (4), (5), and (10), for residential property other than part-year residential property, a county legislative body may adopt an ordinance that requires an owner to file an application with the county board of equalization before the county applies a residential exemption authorized under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(1)(a): the residential property was ineligible for the residential exemption during the calendar year immediately preceding the calendar year for which the owner is seeking to have the residential exemption applied to the value of the residential property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(1)(b): an ownership interest in the residential property changes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(1)(c): the county board of equalization determines that there is reason to believe that the residential property no longer qualifies for the residential exemption.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(2)(a): The application described in Subsection (1):
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(2)(a)(i): shall be on a form the commission provides by rule and makes available to the counties;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(2)(a)(ii): shall be signed by the owner of the residential property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(2)(a)(iii): may not request the sales price of the residential property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(2)(b): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the commission may make rules providing the contents of the form described in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(2)(c): For purposes of the application described in Subsection (1), a county may not request information from an owner of a residential property beyond the information in the form provided by the commission under this Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(3): 59-2-103
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(3)(a): 59-2-103 Regardless of whether a county legislative body adopts an ordinance described in Subsection (1), before a county may apply a residential exemption to the value of part-year residential property, an owner of the property shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(3)(a)(i): file the application described in Subsection (2)(a) with the county board of equalization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(3)(a)(ii): 59-2-103 include as part of the application described in Subsection (2)(a) a statement that certifies:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(3)(a)(ii)(A): the date the part-year residential property became residential property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(3)(a)(ii)(B): that the part-year residential property will be used as residential property for 183 or more consecutive calendar days during the calendar year for which the owner seeks to obtain the residential exemption; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(3)(a)(ii)(C): 59-2-103 that the owner, or a member of the owner's household, may not claim a residential exemption for any property for the calendar year for which the owner seeks to obtain the residential exemption, other than the part-year residential property, or as allowed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(3)(b): If an owner files an application under this Subsection (3) on or after May 1 of the calendar year for which the owner seeks to obtain the residential exemption, the county board of equalization may require the owner to pay an application fee not to exceed $50.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(4): 59-2-102; 59-2-103 Before a county allows residential property described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(4)(a): states under penalty of perjury that, to the best of each owner's knowledge, upon completion of construction or occupancy of the residential property, the residential property will be used for residential purposes as a primary residence;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(4)(b): is signed by each owner of the residential property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(4)(c): is on a form approved by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(5): 59-2-103; 59-2-103
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(5)(a): 59-2-103; 59-2-103 Before a county allows residential property described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(5)(a)(i): states under penalty of perjury that, to the best of each owner's knowledge, the residential property will be used for residential purposes as a primary residence of a tenant;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(5)(a)(ii): is signed by each owner of the residential property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(5)(a)(iii): is on a form approved by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(5)(b)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(5)(b)(i)(A): In addition to the declaration, a county assessor may request from an owner a current lease agreement signed by the tenant.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(5)(b)(i)(B): If the lease agreement is insufficient for a county assessor to make a determination about eligibility for a residential exemption, a county assessor may request a copy of the real estate insurance policy for the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(5)(b)(i)(C): If the real estate insurance policy is insufficient for a county assessor to make a determination about eligibility for a residential exemption, a county assessor may request a copy of a filing from the most recent federal tax return showing that the owner had profit or loss from the residential property as a rental.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(5)(b)(ii): A county assessor may not request information from an owner's tenant.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(6): 59-2-103; 59-2-103; 59-2-103; 59-2-103 Except as provided in Subsection (7), if a property owner no longer qualifies to receive a residential exemption authorized under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(6)(a): 59-2-103 file a written statement with the county board of equalization of the county in which the property is located:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(6)(a)(i): on a form provided by the county board of equalization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(6)(a)(ii): 59-2-103 notifying the county board of equalization that the property owner no longer qualifies to receive a residential exemption authorized under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(6)(b): 59-2-103; 59-2-103 declare on the property owner's individual income tax return under Chapter 10, Individual Income Tax Act, for the taxable year for which the property owner no longer qualifies to receive a residential exemption authorized under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(7): 59-2-103; 59-2-103 A property owner is not required to file a written statement or make the declaration described in Subsection (6) if the property owner:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(7)(a): changes primary residences;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(7)(b): 59-2-103 qualified to receive a residential exemption authorized under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(7)(c): 59-2-103 qualifies to receive a residential exemption authorized under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(8): Subsections (2) through (7) do not apply to qualifying exempt primary residential rental personal property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(9): 59-2-103; 59-2-306; 59-2-306; 59-2-1115; 59-2-306; 59-2-1115
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(9)(a): 59-2-103; 59-2-306 Subject to Subsection (10), for the first calendar year in which a property owner qualifies to receive a residential exemption under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(9)(b): 59-2-306; 59-2-1115; 59-2-306; 59-2-1115 Subject to Subsection (10) and notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10): 59-2-103; 59-2-1004; 59-2-919.1; 59-2-103; 59-2-103; 59-2-1004; 59-2-919.1
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(a): After an ownership interest in residential property changes, the county assessor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(a)(i): notify the owner of the residential property that the owner is required to submit a written declaration described in Subsection (10)(d) within 90 days after the day on which the county assessor mails the notice under this Subsection (10)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(a)(ii): provide the owner of the residential property with the form described in Subsection (10)(e) to make the written declaration described in Subsection (10)(d).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(b): A county assessor is not required to provide a notice to an owner of residential property under Subsection (10)(a) if the situs address of the residential property is the same as any one of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(b)(i): the mailing address of the residential property owner or the tenant of the residential property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(b)(ii): the address listed on the:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(b)(ii)(A): residential property owner's driver license; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(b)(ii)(B): tenant of the residential property's driver license; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(b)(iii): the address listed on the:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(b)(iii)(A): residential property owner's voter registration; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(b)(iii)(B): tenant of the residential property's voter registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(c): A county assessor is not required to provide a notice to an owner of residential property under Subsection (10)(a) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(c)(i): the owner is using a post office box or rural route box located in the county where the residential property is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(c)(ii): the residential property is located in a county of the fourth, fifth, or sixth class.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(d): An owner of residential property that receives a notice described in Subsection (10)(a) shall submit a written declaration to the county assessor under penalty of perjury certifying the information contained in the form described in Subsection (10)(e).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(e): 59-2-103; 59-2-1004; 59-2-919.1; 59-2-103; 59-2-103; 59-2-1004; 59-2-919.1 The written declaration required by Subsection (10)(d) shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(e)(i): signed by the owner of the residential property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-103.5(10)(e)(ii): 59-2-103; 59-2-1004; 59-2-919.1; 59-2-103; 59-2-103; 59-2-1004; 59-2-919.1 in substantially the following form:


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-104 Situs of property for tax purposes.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-104(1): The situs of all taxable property is the tax area where it is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-104(2): Personal property, unless assessed by the commission, shall be assessed in the tax area where the owner is domiciled in this state on January 1, unless the owner demonstrates to the satisfaction of the county assessor that the personal property is usually kept in a tax area other than that of the domicile of the owner, in which case that property shall be assessed in the other tax area.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-104(3): Land shall be assessed in parcels or subdivisions not exceeding 640 acres each, and tracts of land containing more than 640 acres, which have been sectioned by the United States government, shall be assessed by sections or fractions of sections.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-104(4): The following property shall be listed and assessed in the county where the property is located:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-104(4)(a): public utilities, when operated wholly in one county;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-104(4)(b): bridges and ferries which are not public utilities, when operated wholly in one county;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-104(4)(c): electric light lines and similar improvements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-104(4)(d): canals, ditches, and flumes when separately taxable.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-105 Situs of public utilities, bridges, ferries, and canals.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Public utilities, and bridges and ferries not public utilities, when operated wholly in one county, and electric light lines and similar improvements, canals, ditches, and flumes when separately taxable, shall be listed and assessed in the county in which the property is located.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-107 Classes of personal property -- Rulemaking authority.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The commission shall make rules:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-107(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-107(2): defining classes of items considered to be personal property for purposes of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-107(3): (2) defining items that fall into the classes established under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-107(4): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act defining any class or item as personal property if the commission defined that class or item as personal property prior to January 1, 2004, by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-107(4)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act a rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-107(4)(b): a published decision of the commission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-107(4)(c): an official schedule published by the commission.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109 Burden of proof.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(1): For an appeal to the commission involving the valuation or equalization of real property assessed under Part 2, Assessment of Property, the party carrying the burden of proof shall demonstrate:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(1)(a): substantial error in the original assessed value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(1)(b): a sound evidentiary basis to support the value the party requests.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(2)(a): For an appeal to the county board of equalization or the commission involving the valuation or equalization of real property assessed under Part 3, County Assessment, the party carrying the burden of proof shall demonstrate:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(2)(a)(i): except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), substantial error in:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(2)(a)(i)(A): the original assessed value in an appeal to the county board of equalization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(2)(a)(i)(B): the value set by the county board of equalization in an appeal to the commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(2)(a)(ii): a sound evidentiary basis to support the value the party requests.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(2)(b): The party carrying the burden of proof does not have to show substantial error as required by Subsection (2)(a)(i) if the party is requesting:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(2)(b)(i): the original assessed value in an appeal to the county board of equalization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(2)(b)(ii): the value set by the county board of equalization in an appeal to the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(3): For property assessed under Part 2, Assessment of Property, the commission has the burden of proof, if the commission is a party to the appeal that asserts that the fair market value of the assessed property is greater than the original assessed value for that calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(4): For property assessed under Part 3, County Assessment, the following shall carry the burden of proof before a county board of equalization or the commission:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(4)(a): the county assessor or the county board of equalization that is a party to the appeal has the burden of proof to support the value the county assessor or the county board of equalization requests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(4)(b): the taxpayer that is a party to the appeal has the burden of proof to support the value the taxpayer requests.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109(5): A preponderance of the evidence suffices to sustain the burden for all parties.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1 Burden of proof for an appeal involving property eligible for deferral for 2023.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(1): 59-2-1802.1 This section applies to an appeal to the county board of equalization or the commission involving the valuation or equalization of real property that is eligible for a deferral under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(2): 59-2-303.3
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(2)(a): 59-2-303.3 The party carrying the burden of proof shall demonstrate:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(2)(a)(i): 59-2-303.3 except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), substantial error in:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(2)(a)(i)(A): 59-2-303.3 the adjusted value set by the county assessor in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(2)(a)(i)(B): the value set by the county board of equalization in an appeal to the commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(2)(a)(ii): a sound evidentiary basis to support the value the party requests.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(2)(b): The party carrying the burden of proof does not have to show substantial error as required by Subsection (2)(a)(i) if the party is requesting:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(2)(b)(i): the adjusted value in an appeal to the board of equalization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(2)(b)(ii): the value set by the county board of equalization in an appeal to the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(3): The following shall carry the burden of proof:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(3)(a): the county assessor or the county board of equalization that is a party to the appeal has the burden of proof to support the value the county assessor or the county board of equalization requests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-109.1(3)(b): the taxpayer that is a party to the appeal has the burden of proof to support the value the taxpayer requests.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-110(1): (1)(b); (2); (1)(a)(i); 59-2-919; 59-2-919.1; 59-2-1317; (2); (1)(b)(i)

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-110(1)(a)(i): the person required under the applicable provision of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-110(1)(a)(ii): (2); (1)(a)(i) each person designated in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-110(1)(b): 59-2-919; 59-2-919.1; 59-2-1317; (2); (1)(b)(i) If a governmental entity is required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-110(1)(b)(i): the person required under the applicable section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-110(1)(b)(ii): (2); (1)(b)(i) one person designated in accordance with Subsection
