Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9 Assessment of pollution control equipment.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(1): Part 3, County Assessment As used in this section, "pollution control equipment" means property that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(1)(a): Part 3, County Assessment is assessed under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(1)(b): is used:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(1)(b)(i): to prevent, control, or reduce air or water pollution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(1)(b)(ii): in connection with an establishment described in NAICS subsector 324110 of the 2022 North American Industry Classification System of the federal Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(1)(c): is purchased to satisfy a requirement of the federal or state government; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(1)(d): does not significantly:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(1)(d)(i): increase the facility's output or capacity;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(1)(d)(ii): reduce the facility's total operating costs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(1)(d)(iii): extend the useful life of any other property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(2): The taxable value of pollution control equipment is calculated by applying the percent good factor against the acquisition cost of the pollution control equipment as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(3): 59-2-1005
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(3)(a): 59-2-1005 A taxpayer owning property assessed under this section may make an appeal relating to the value of the property in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(3)(b): As part of an appeal described in this subsection, a taxpayer may request a deviation from the schedule provided in this section for a specific item of property if use of the schedule does not result in the fair market value of the property, including any relevant installation or assemblage value, at the retail level of trade and on the lien date.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(4): (4)(a); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(4)(a): A county assessor may deviate from the schedule provided in this section when necessary to reach fair market value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(4)(b): (4)(a) When a deviation described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(4)(c): A county assessor may not use a schedule other than the schedule provided in this section without prior written consent of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-301.9(4)(d): (3) If a county assessor deviates from the schedule provided in this section and the taxpayer makes an appeal in accordance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-302 Basis of property taxation for political subdivision.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The assessments made by:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-302(1): the county assessor, as equalized by the county board of equalization and the commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-302(2): the commission, as apportioned to each county, city, town, school, road, or other district in their respective counties, are the only basis of property taxation for political subdivisions of the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303 General duties of county assessor.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303(1): 59-2-303.2
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303(1)(a): 59-2-303.2 Before May 22 each year, the county assessor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303(1)(a)(i): ascertain the names of the owners of all property that is subject to taxation by the county;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303(1)(a)(ii): except as provided in Subsection (2), assess the property to the owner, claimant of record, or occupant in possession or control at midnight on January 1 of the taxable year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303(1)(a)(iii): 59-2-303.2 conduct the review process described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303(1)(b): No mistake in the name or address of the owner or supposed owner of property renders the assessment invalid.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303(2): If a conveyance of ownership of the real property was recorded in the office of a county recorder after January 1 but more than 14 calendar days before the day on which the county treasurer mails the tax notice, the county assessor shall assess the property to the new owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303(3): 59-2-301 A county assessor shall become fully acquainted with all property in the county assessor's county, as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303(4): 59-2-703; 59-2-303.1 A county assessor in a county of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class shall seek assistance from other county assessors or an appraiser contracted in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1 Mandatory cyclical appraisals.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1): 59-2-704 For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(a): 59-2-704 "Corrective action" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(a)(i): 59-2-704 factoring pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(a)(ii): notifying the state auditor that the county failed to comply with the requirements of this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(a)(iii): filing a petition for a court order requiring a county to take action.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(b): "Mass appraisal system" means a computer assisted mass appraisal system that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(b)(i): a county assessor uses to value real property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(b)(ii): includes at least the following system features:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(b)(ii)(A): has the ability to update all parcels of real property located within the county each year;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(b)(ii)(B): can be programmed with specialized criteria;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(b)(ii)(C): provides uniform and equal treatment of parcels within the same class of real property throughout the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(b)(ii)(D): annually updates all parcels of residential real property within the county using accepted valuation methodologies as determined by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(1)(c): "Property review date" means the date a county assessor completes a detailed review of the property characteristics of a parcel of real property in accordance with Subsection (3)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(2): 59-2-301
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(2)(a): 59-2-301 The county assessor shall annually update property values of property as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(2)(b): The county assessor shall conduct the annual update described in Subsection (2)(a) by using a mass appraisal system.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(2)(c): The county assessor and the commission shall jointly certify that the county's mass appraisal system meets the requirements:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(2)(c)(i): described in Subsection (1)(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(2)(c)(ii): of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3)(a): In addition to the requirements in Subsection (2), the county assessor shall complete a detailed review of property characteristics for each property at least once every five years.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3)(b): The county assessor shall maintain on the county's mass appraisal system, a record of the last property review date for each parcel of real property located within the county assessor's county.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3)(c)(i): The county assessor shall maintain on the county's mass appraisal system a parcel's property tax class or category that is used for the purpose of property tax assessment on the annual assessment date.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3)(c)(ii): The classifications or categories of real property under Subsection (3)(c)(i) shall include, at minimum:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3)(c)(ii)(A): primary residential;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3)(c)(ii)(B): commercial;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3)(c)(ii)(C): vacant land;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3)(c)(ii)(D): secondary residential; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3)(c)(ii)(E): non-taxable.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(3)(c)(iii): The classifications or categories of real property used by the county assessor, and the classification or category applied to a specific parcel, is public information.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(4): 59-2-704; 59-2-1602; 59-2-1603
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(4)(a): 59-2-704 The commission shall take corrective action if the commission determines that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(4)(a)(i): a county assessor has not satisfactorily followed the current mass appraisal standards, as provided by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(4)(a)(ii): 59-2-704 the sales-assessment ratio, coefficients of dispersion, or other statistical measures of appraisal performance related to the studies required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(4)(a)(iii): the county assessor has failed to comply with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(4)(b): If a county assessor fails to comply with the requirements of this section for one year, the commission shall assist the county assessor in fulfilling the requirements of Subsections (2) and (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(4)(c): 59-2-1602; 59-2-1603 If a county assessor fails to comply with the requirements of this section for two consecutive years, the county will lose the county's allocation of the revenue generated statewide from the imposition of the multicounty assessing and collecting levy authorized in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(4)(d): If a county loses its allocation of the revenue generated statewide from the imposition of the multicounty assessing and collecting levy described in Subsection (4)(c), the revenue the county would have received shall be distributed to the Multicounty Appraisal Trust created by interlocal agreement by all counties in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(5)(a): On or before July 1, 2008, the county assessor shall prepare a five-year plan to comply with the requirements of Subsections (2) and (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(5)(b): The plan shall be available in the county assessor's office for review by the public upon request.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(5)(c): The plan shall be annually reviewed and revised as necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(6): 59-2-303
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(6)(a): A county assessor shall create, maintain, and regularly update a database containing the following information that the county assessor may use to enhance the county's ability to accurately appraise and assess property on an annual basis:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(6)(a)(i): fee and other appraisals;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(6)(a)(ii): property characteristics and features;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(6)(a)(iii): property surveys;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(6)(a)(iv): sales data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(6)(a)(v): any other data or information on sales, studies, transfers, changes to property, or property characteristics.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.1(6)(b): 59-2-303 A county assessor may provide access to the information in the database to another county assessor that requests assistance in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2 Automatic review of assessed value of review property.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1): 59-2-1004; 59-2-919.1; 59-2-1004; 59-2-1006; 59-1-602; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Part 4, Judicial Review As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(a): 59-2-1004; 59-2-919.1; 59-2-1004; 59-2-1006; 59-1-602; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Part 4, Judicial Review "Final assessed value" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(a)(i): 59-2-1004; 59-2-919.1 for a review property for which the taxpayer did not appeal the valuation or equalization in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(a)(ii): 59-2-1004 for a review property for which the taxpayer appealed the valuation or equalization in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(a)(iii): 59-2-1006 for real property for which the taxpayer or a county assessor appealed the valuation or equalization to the commission in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(a)(iii)(A): the commission, if the commission has issued a decision in the appeal or the parties have entered a stipulation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(a)(iii)(B): a county board of equalization, if the commission has not yet issued a decision in the appeal and the parties have not entered a stipulation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(a)(iv): 59-1-602; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Part 4, Judicial Review for real property for which the taxpayer or a county assessor sought judicial review of the valuation or equalization in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(b): "Median property value change" means the midpoint of the property value changes for all real property that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(b)(i): of the same class of real property as the review property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(b)(ii): located within the same county and within the same market area as the review property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(c): "Property value change" means the percentage change in the fair market value of real property on or after January 1 of the previous year and before January 1 of the current year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(d): "Qualifying change" means one of the following changes to real property that occurs on or after January 1 of the previous taxable year and before January 1 of the current taxable year:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(d)(i): a physical improvement if, solely as a result of the physical improvement, the fair market value of the physical improvement equals or exceeds the greater of 10% of fair market value of the real property or $20,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(d)(ii): a zoning change, if the fair market value of the real property increases solely as a result of the zoning change; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(d)(iii): a change in the legal description of the real property, if the fair market value of the real property increases solely as a result of the change in the legal description of the real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(e): "Review property" means real property located in the county:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(e)(i): that on or after January 1 of the previous year and before January 1 of the current year has not had a qualifying change; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(e)(ii): for which the county assessor did not conduct a detailed review of property characteristics during the current taxable year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(f): "Threshold increase" means an increase in a review property's assessed value for the current taxable year compared to the final assessed value of the review property for the previous taxable year that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(f)(i): the median property value change plus 15%; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(1)(f)(ii): at least $10,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(2): 59-2-311
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(2)(a): 59-2-311 Before completing and delivering the assessment book to the county auditor in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(2)(b): The county assessor shall retain a record of the properties for which the county assessor conducts a review in accordance with this section and the results of that review.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(3)(a): If the county assessor determines that the assessed value of the review property reflects the review property's fair market value, the county assessor may not adjust the review property's assessed value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(3)(b): If the county assessor determines that the assessed value of the review property does not reflect the review property's fair market value, the county assessor shall adjust the assessed value of the review property to reflect the fair market value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(4): Title 59, Chapter 1, Part 6, Judicial Review; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Part 4, Judicial Review The review process described in this section does not supersede or otherwise affect a taxpayer's right to appeal or to seek judicial review of the valuation or equalization of a review property in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(4)(a): this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(4)(b): Title 59, Chapter 1, Part 6, Judicial Review
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.2(4)(c): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Part 4, Judicial Review


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3 Automatic review for property with 150% or more valuation increase.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(1): As used in this section, "qualifying increase" means a valuation increase that is equal to or more than 150% higher than the previous year's valuation for property that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(1)(a): is county assessed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(1)(b): on or after January 1 of the previous year and before January 1 of the current year, has not had:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(1)(b)(i): a physical improvement if the fair market value of the physical improvement increases enough to result in the valuation increase solely as a result of the physical improvement;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(1)(b)(ii): a zoning change if the fair market value of the real property increases enough to result in the valuation increase solely as a result of the zoning change; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(1)(b)(iii): a change in the legal description of the real property, if the fair market value of the real property increases enough to result in the valuation increase solely as a result of the change in the legal description of the real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(2): 59-2-311
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(2)(a): For the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2023, the county assessor shall review the assessment of the property with a qualifying increase on or before May 31, 2024.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(2)(b): 59-2-311 For a calendar year beginning on or after January 1, 2024, the county assessor shall review the assessment of a property with a qualifying increase before delivery of the assessment book to the county auditor in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(2)(c): The county assessor shall retain a record of the properties for which the county assessor conducts a review in accordance with this Subsection (2) and the results of that review.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(3): 59-2-919.1
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(3)(a): When the county assessor conducts the review described in Subsection (2):
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(3)(a)(i): if the county assessor determines that the assessed value of the property reflects the property's fair market value, the county assessor may not adjust the property's assessed value; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(3)(a)(ii): if the county assessor determines that the assessed value of the property does not reflect the review property's fair market value, the county assessor shall adjust the assessed value of the review property to reflect the fair market value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(3)(b): If a county assessor makes an adjustment under Subsection (3)(a) for the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2023, the county legislative body shall authorize a refund of the property tax that is overpaid as a result of the adjustment.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(3)(c): 59-2-919.1 If a county assessor makes an adjustment under Subsection (3)(a) for the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2024, the county assessor shall list the adjusted value set in accordance with this section as the original assessed value on the valuation notice sent in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4): 59-2-1008
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(a): Upon completing the review described in Subsection (2), the county assessor shall report to the commission:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(a)(i): the number of properties that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(a)(i)(A): required a review in accordance with Subsection (2); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(a)(i)(B): the county reduced the value as a result of the review; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(a)(ii): the parcel number of any property:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(a)(ii)(A): that required a review in accordance with Subsection (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(a)(ii)(B): that has an increase in value of $50,000 or more; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(a)(ii)(C): for which the county assessor did not reduce the value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(b): 59-2-1008
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(b)(i): 59-2-1008 A county that has any property subject to a review in accordance with this section for two consecutive years shall report to the Revenue and Taxation Interim Committee:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(b)(i)(A): 59-2-1008 at the same meeting or a meeting after the meeting during which the commission makes the report described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(b)(i)(B): in the same year as the commission report; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(b)(i)(C): on the number of properties with a qualifying increase and the reasons for the qualifying increases.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(b)(ii): The requirement to report applies if the county has a property that is subject to review under this section in each of two consecutive years regardless of whether the property that is subject to review is the same property for each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(4)(b)(iii): The requirement to report does not apply if the qualifying increase is less than $50,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(5): The review process described in this section does not supersede or otherwise affect a taxpayer's right to appeal or to seek judicial review of the valuation or equalization of a review property in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(5)(a): Part 10, Equalization;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(5)(b): Chapter 1, Part 6, Judicial Review; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-303.3(5)(c): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Part 4, Judicial Review.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305 Listing property in taxing entities.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The county assessor shall list all property in each taxing entity in the county by identifier and fair market value.  The commission may prescribe procedures and formats, after consultation with affected state agencies and county assessors, which will provide reasonable uniformity and reduced costs in listing property.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5 Boundary actions not effective for purposes of assessment until required documents are recorded.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1): 67-1a-6.5; 17-23-20; 67-1a-6.5 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(a): "Affected area" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(a)(i): in the case of the creation or incorporation of a local entity, the area within the newly created local entity's boundary;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(a)(ii): in the case of an annexation of an area into an existing local entity, the annexed area;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(a)(iii): in the case of an adjustment of a boundary between local entities, the area that before the boundary adjustment was in the boundary of one local entity but becomes, because of the boundary adjustment, included within the boundary of another local entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(a)(iv): in the case of the withdrawal or disconnection of an area from a local entity, the area that is withdrawn or disconnected;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(a)(v): in the case of the consolidation of multiple local entities, the area within the boundary of the consolidated local entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(a)(vi): in the case of the division of a local entity into multiple local entities, the area within the boundary of each new local entity created by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(a)(vii): in the case of the dissolution of a local entity, the area that used to be within the former boundary of the dissolved local entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(b): 67-1a-6.5 "Applicable certificate" has the same meaning as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(c): 17-23-20 "Boundary action" has the same meaning as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(d): "Effective date" means the effective date, under applicable statute, of the boundary action that is the subject of an applicable certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(e): 67-1a-6.5 "Local entity" has the same meaning as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(1)(f): "Required documents" means the documents relating to a boundary action that are required under applicable statute to be submitted to the county recorder for recording following the lieutenant governor's issuance of an applicable certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-305.5(2): Notwithstanding the effective date, a boundary action is not effective for purposes of assessing under this part the property located within the affected area until the required documents are recorded in the office of the recorder of each county in which the affected area is located.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(1)(b): 59-2-1005 A request under Subsection (1)(a) shall include a notice of the procedure under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(1)(c): 59-2-306.5 A telecommunications service provider shall file a signed statement setting forth the telecommunications service provider'spersonal property in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b) or (c), a person shall file a signed statement described in Subsection (1) on or before May 15 of the year the county assessor requests the statement described in Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(2)(b): For a county of the first class, a person shall file the signed statement described in Subsection (1) on or before the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(2)(b)(i): 60 days after the day on which the county assessor requests the statement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(2)(b)(ii): May 15 of the year the county assessor requests the statement described in Subsection (1) if, by resolution, the county legislative body of that county adopts the deadline described in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(2)(c): If a county assessor requests a signed statement described in Subsection (1) on or after March 16, the person shall file the signed statement within 60 days after the day on which the county assessor requests the signed statement.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(3): 59-2-1115 The signed statement shall include the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(3)(a): all property belonging to, claimed by, or in the possession, control, or management of the person, any firm of which the person is a member, or any corporation of which the person is president, secretary, cashier, or managing agent;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(3)(b): the county in which the property is located or in which the property is taxable; and, if taxable in the county in which the signed statement was made, also the city, town, school district, road district, or other taxing district in which the property is located or taxable;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(3)(c): all lands in parcels or subdivisions not exceeding 640 acres each, the sections and fractional sections of all tracts of land containing more than 640 acres that have been sectionized by the United States government, and the improvements on those lands; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(3)(d): 59-2-1115 for a person who owns taxable tangible personal property as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(4): Every county assessor may subpoena and examine any person in any county in relation to any signed statement but may not require that person to appear in any county other than the county in which the subpoena is served.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(5): 59-2-306.5

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306(5)(b): 59-2-306.5 If the signed statement discloses personal property of a telecommunications service provider, the county assessor shall notify the telecommunications service provider of the requirement to file a signed statement in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5 Valuation of personal property of telecommunications service provider -- Reporting information to counties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(1): 59-2-1601 As used in this section, "Multicounty Appraisal Trust" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(2): A telecommunications service provider shall provide to the Multicounty Appraisal Trust a signed statement setting forth all of the personal property that the telecommunications service provider owns, possesses, manages, or has under the telecommunications service provider's control in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(3): The signed statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(3)(a): may be requested by the Multicounty Appraisal Trust:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(3)(a)(i): each year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(3)(a)(ii): if requested, on or before January 31;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(3)(b): shall itemize each item of personal property that the telecommunications service provider owns, possesses, manages, or has under the telecommunications service provider's control:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(3)(b)(i): by county and by tax area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(3)(b)(ii): for the tax year that began on January 1; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(3)(c): shall be submitted:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(3)(c)(i): annually on or before March 31; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(3)(c)(ii): electronically in a form approved by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4): 59-2-307
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(a): 59-2-307 Except where an estimate is made in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(b)(i): Between March 31 and May 31 of each year:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(b)(i)(A): the Multicounty Appraisal Trust may communicate with a telecommunications service provider to address any inconsistency or error in the filed signed statement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(b)(i)(B): the telecommunications service provider may file an amended signed statement with the Multicounty Appraisal Trust regarding the items agreed to by the Multicounty Appraisal Trust and the telecommunications service provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(b)(ii): The communication described in this Subsection (4)(b) is in addition to the audit authority provided by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(c): On or before May 31 of each year, the Multicounty Appraisal Trust shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(c)(i): forward to each county information about the total value of personal property of each telecommunications service provider within the county, by tax area, including a listing of personal property that is exempt; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(c)(ii): issue a tax notice to each telecommunications service provider listing the tax due to each county, by tax area.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(d): On or before June 30 of each year, a telecommunications service provider shall pay to the county the tax due on the tax notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(e): A telecommunications service provider may appeal the valuation of personal property to the county on or before the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(e)(i): July 30 of the year the Multicounty Appraisal Trust requests a statement described in Subsection (3)(a); or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(4)(e)(ii): 60 days after mailing of a tax notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(5): The Multicounty Appraisal Trust shall forward to each county information about the total value of personal property of each telecommunications service provider within the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-306.5(6): If a signed statement filed in accordance with this section discloses real property, the Multicounty Appraisal Trust shall send a copy of the signed statement to the county in which the property is located.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307 Refusal by taxpayer to file signed statement -- Estimation of value -- Penalty.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(1)(d): The assessor shall pay all money recovered under this section into the county treasury.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(2)(b)(ii)(A): on or after March 16; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(2)(b)(ii)(B): by a county assessor of a county of the first class.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(3): 59-2-306; (3)(a)(ii)(A); 59-2-306.5; (3)(b)(i)(B); (3)(a)(i); (3)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(3)(a): 59-2-306; (3)(a)(ii)(A) If an owner neglects or refuses to file a signed statement requested by an assessor as required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(3)(a)(i): the assessor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(3)(a)(i)(A): make a record of the failure to file; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(3)(a)(i)(B): make an estimate of the value of the property of the owner based on known facts and circumstances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(3)(a)(ii): (3)(a)(ii)(A) the assessor of a county of the first class:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(3)(a)(ii)(A): shall make a subsequent request by mail for the signed statement, informing the owner of the consequences of not filing a signed statement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(3)(a)(ii)(B): (3)(a)(ii)(A) may impose a fee for the actual and necessary expenses of the mailing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-307(3)(b): 59-2-306.5; (3)(b)(i)(B)

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-308 Assessment in name of representative -- Assessment of property of decedents -- Assessment of property in litigation -- Assessment of personal property valued by Multicounty Appraisal Trust.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-308(1): If a person is assessed as agent, trustee, bailee, guardian, executor, or administrator, a county shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-308(1)(a): add the representative designation to the name; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-308(1)(b): enter the assessment separately from the individual assessment.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-308(2): A county may assess the undistributed or unpartitioned property of a deceased individual to an heir, guardian, executor, or administrator, and the payment of taxes binds all the parties in interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-308(3): Property in litigation, which is in the possession of a court or receiver, shall be assessed to the court clerk or receiver, and the taxes shall be paid under the direction of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-308(4): A county shall add the valuation the Multicounty Appraisal Trust gives to personal property of a telecommunications service provider to the valuation of any real property of the telecommunications service provider within the county before making an assessment in accordance with this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-309 Property escaping assessment -- Duties of assessing authority -- Property willfully concealed -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-309(1): Part 13, Collection of Taxes Any escaped property  may be assessed by the original assessing authority at any time as far back as five years prior to the time of discovery, in which case the assessor shall enter the assessments on the tax rolls and follow the procedures established under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-309(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act Any property found to be willfully concealed, removed, transferred, or misrepresented by its owner or agent in order to evade taxation is subject to a penalty equal to the tax on its value, and neither the penalty nor assessment may be reduced or waived by the assessor, county, county Board of Equalization, or the commission, except pursuant to a procedure for the review and approval of waivers adopted by county ordinance, or by administrative rule adopted in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-310 Assessment in name of claimant as well as owner.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Real property described on the assessment book need not be described a second time, but any person claiming the real property and a desire to be assessed for the land may have the person's name inserted with that of the person to whom the real property is assessed.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-311 Completion and delivery of assessment book -- Signed statement required -- Contents of signed statement -- Adjustment of assessment in assessment book.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I, ____, the assessor of ____ County, do swear that before May 22, _______(year), I made diligent inquiry and examination, and either personally or by deputy, established the value of all of the property within the county subject to assessment by me; that the property has been assessed on the assessment book equally and uniformly according to the best of my judgment, information, and belief at its fair market value; that I have faithfully complied with all the duties imposed on the assessor under the revenue laws including the requirements of SectionUtah Code Annotated § 59-2-311(1): Before May 22 each year, the county assessor shall complete and deliver the assessment book to the county auditor.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-311(2): 59-2-303.1 The county assessor shall subscribe and sign a statement in the assessment book substantially as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-311(3): (1); 59-2-1004.5; 59-2-303.2 Before completing and delivering the assessment book under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-311(3)(a): 59-2-1004.5 by the county board of equalization in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-311(3)(b): 59-2-303.2 by the county assessor in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-313 Assessor to furnish information to commission.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The county assessor shall furnish to the commission, promptly upon demand, any information it may require as to the several kinds of personal and real property, and the taxable value of those properties, which are located in the county.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-313.1 County assessor duties to provide assessment data -- Commission review -- Subscription to market data service.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-314 Penalty for failure to complete assessment book.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any assessor who fails to complete and deliver the assessment book to the county auditor within the time prescribed by law, or who fails to transmit the information required under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-315 Liability for willful failure or neglect of duty -- Action on official bond -- Judgment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-315(1): The assessor and sureties are liable on the official bond for all taxes on property within the county which, through willful failure or neglect, is not assessed or which has been willfully assessed at less than its fair market value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-315(2): The county attorney shall, upon showing of proper evidence and upon written demand by the commission or the county  legislative body, commence and prosecute to judgment an action upon the assessor's bond for all taxes lost from willful failure or neglect in assessing property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-315(3): If, during the trial of the action against the assessor, the value of the unassessed or underassessed property is determined, the assessor is liable for the difference between the amount of taxes collected and the amount of taxes which should have been collected pursuant to law.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-320 Total property valuation.
--------------------------------------------------------
The county auditor shall add the valuations, and enter the total valuation of each kind of property, and the total valuation of all property, on the assessment book.  In the appropriate column the total acreage of the county shall be shown.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-321 Extension of taxes on assessment book.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-321(1): The property taxes of each city, town, school, and special taxing district shall be extended on the assessment book by the county auditor at the rate certified by the governing body of the city, town, school, and special taxing district at the time the state and county taxes are extended.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-321(2): The whole tax shall be carried into a column of aggregates, and shall be collected by the county treasurer at the time and in the manner provided by law for collecting state and county taxes.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-322 Transmittal of statement to commission.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-322(1): The county auditor shall, before June 8 of each year, prepare from the assessment book of that year a statement showing in separate columns:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-322(1)(a): the total value of all property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-322(1)(b): the value of real estate, including patented mining claims, stated separately;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-322(1)(c): the value of the improvements;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-322(1)(d): the value of personal property exclusive of money; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-322(1)(e): the number of acres of land and the number of patented mining claims, stated separately.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-322(2): As soon as the statement is prepared the county auditor shall transmit the statement to the commission.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-323 Changes ordered by commission.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-323(1): 59-2-322; 59-1-210 The commission shall, before June 17 or within 10 days after the county auditors of the state have filed their report with the commission as provided for under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-323(2): As soon as the county auditor receives from the commission a statement of the changes made by it in the assessment book of the county, or of any assessment contained therein, the auditor shall make the corresponding changes in the assessment book, by entering the same in a column provided with the proper heading in the assessment book, counting any fractional sum when more than 50 cents as one dollar and omitting it when less than 50 cents, so that the value of any separate assessment shall contain no fractions of a dollar; but shall in all cases disregard any action of the county board of equalization or commission which is prohibited by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-324 Entering corrected sum of taxes in assessment book.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The county auditor shall then compute, and enter in a separate money column in the assessment book, the aggregate sum in dollars and cents to be paid as taxes on the property enumerated in the book.  Taxes levied only on a certain kind or class of property for a special purpose, other than for state, county, city, town, and school purposes, etc., shall be separately set out, and shall foot up the column showing the total amount of the taxes, and the column of total value of property in the county, as corrected by the commission.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-325 Statement transmitted to commission.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-325(1): The county auditor shall, before November 1 of each year:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-325(1)(a): prepare from the assessment rolls of that year a statement showing:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-325(1)(a)(i): the amount and value of all property in the county, as classified by the county assessment rolls, and the value of each class;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-325(1)(a)(ii): the total amount of taxes remitted by the county board of equalization;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-325(1)(a)(iii): the state's share of the taxes remitted;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-325(1)(a)(iv): the county's share of the taxes remitted;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-325(1)(a)(v): the rate of county taxes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-325(1)(a)(vi): any other information requested by the commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-325(1)(b): provide a copy of the statement to the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-325(2): The county auditor shall prepare the statement in the manner prescribed by the commission.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-326 Assessment roll delivered to county treasurer.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Before November 1, the county auditor must deliver the corrected assessment roll to the county treasurer, together with a signed statement subscribed by him in a form substantially as follows:

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-327 Assessment roll -- Taxes charged to county treasurer.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-327(1): 59-2-1317 The county auditor shall deliver the assessment roll, with the taxes extended, all orders of the county board of equalization and commission posted, and all relief granted, prior to the time prescribed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-327(2): 59-2-326 After delivering the corrected assessment roll to the county treasurer, under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-327(3): 59-2-1365 The county auditor shall either report the final taxes charged or report the adjustments in taxable value and tax amounts from the preliminary taxes charged amount to the county treasurer for use in settling with all taxing entities under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-328 Duty of auditor upon termination of treasurer's term of office.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the assessment book or the delinquent tax list is transferred from one treasurer to another, the county auditor shall credit the one and charge the other with the amount of taxes then outstanding.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-329 Verification of auditor's statements.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The county auditor shall verify all statements made by the auditor under the provisions of this title and attach a signed statement of verification.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-401 Assessment of transitory personal property.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
If any taxable personal property is brought into a county from another county of this state at any time after January 1, and the property has not been assessed for that year, it shall be listed and assessed the same as if it had been in the county at the time of the regular assessment.  The county assessor shall enter the assessment on the tax rolls in the hands of the county treasurer or elsewhere, and if made after the assessment book has been delivered to the county treasurer, the assessment shall be reported by the assessor to the county auditor, and the auditor shall charge the assessor with the taxes on the property.  The assessor shall notify the person assessed and immediately proceed to secure or collect the taxes as provided under

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402 Proportional assessment of transitory personal property brought from outside state -- Exemptions -- Reporting requirements -- Penalty for failure to file report -- Claims for rebates and adjustments.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(1): (2) If any taxable transitory personal property, other than property exempted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(2): (1); 59-2-405(4); 41-3-201 The following property is exempt from proportional assessment under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(2)(a): property acquired during the calendar year;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(2)(b): registered motor vehicles with a gross laden weight of 27,000 pounds or less;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(2)(c): vehicles that are registered and licensed in another state;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(2)(d): 59-2-405(4) property subject to the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(2)(e): state-assessed commercial vehicles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(2)(f): 41-3-201 a motor home that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(2)(f)(i): brought into the state for the sole purpose of selling the motor home to a licensed dealer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(2)(f)(ii): 41-3-201 purchased for resale by a person licensed as a dealer under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(3): If any taxable transitory personal property is brought into the state at any time during the year, the owner of the property, or the owner's agent, shall immediately secure a personal property report form from the assessor, complete it in all pertinent respects, sign it, and file it with the assessor of the county in which the property is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(4): 59-2-307 If the owner of the taxable transitory personal property, or the owner's agent, fails to secure, complete, and file a personal property report form with the county assessor, the assessor shall estimate the value of the property in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-402(5): An owner of taxable transitory personal property, except motor vehicles with a gross laden weight of 27,000 pounds or less, who has paid taxes on the personal property and who removes the property from the state prior to December, is entitled to a rebate of a proportionate share of the taxes paid as determined by the commission.  If a claim for rebate or adjustments is filed with the county auditor by December 10, the auditor shall immediately submit the claim with a recommendation to the county executive for its approval or denial.  If the claim is not approved prior to the end of the calendar year, or within 30 days after its submission, or if the claim is submitted after December 10, it shall be considered denied, and the owners of the property may file an action in the district court for a refund or an adjustment.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-403 Assessment of interstate state-assessed commercial vehicles -- Apportionment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When assessing state-assessed commercial vehicles covering interstate routes, the commission shall apportion the assessment for the rolling stock used in interstate commerce at the same percentage ratio that has been filed with the Motor Vehicle Division of the commission for determining the proration of registration fees.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-501 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Farmland Assessment Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(1): 59-2-503 "Actively devoted to agricultural use" means that the land in agricultural use produces in excess of 50% of the average agricultural production per acre:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(1)(a): 59-2-503 as determined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(1)(b): for:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(1)(b)(i): the given type of land; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(1)(b)(ii): the given county or area.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(2): 59-2-506.5 "Conservation easement rollback tax" means the tax imposed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(3): "Identical legal ownership" means legal ownership held by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(3)(a): identical legal parties; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(3)(b): identical legal entities.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(4): 59-2-102 "Land in agricultural use" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(4)(a): 59-2-102 land devoted to the raising of useful plants and animals with a reasonable expectation of profit, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(4)(a)(i): forages and sod crops;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(4)(a)(ii): grains and feed crops;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(4)(a)(iii): 59-2-102 livestock as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(4)(a)(iv): trees and fruits; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(4)(a)(v): vegetables, nursery, floral, and ornamental stock; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(4)(b): land devoted to and meeting the requirements and qualifications for payments or other compensation under a crop-land retirement program with an agency of the state or federal government.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(5): 59-2-503(1)(a); 59-2-503(1)(a); 59-2-512 "Other eligible acreage" means land that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(5)(a): five or more contiguous acres;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(5)(b): eligible for assessment under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(5)(c): 59-2-503(1)(a); 59-2-503(1)(a); 59-2-512
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(5)(c)(i): 59-2-503(1)(a) located in the same county as land described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(5)(c)(ii): 59-2-503(1)(a); 59-2-512 contiguous across county lines with land described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(6): 10-9a-604; 17-27a-604 "Platted" means land in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(6)(a): parcels of ground are laid out and mapped by their boundaries, course, and extent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(6)(b): 10-9a-604; 17-27a-604 the plat has been approved as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(7): 59-2-506 "Rollback tax" means the tax imposed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8): 59-2-509; 59-2-509; 59-2-509; 59-2-509; 59-2-508(5); 59-2-508(5); 59-2-503; 59-2-503 "Withdrawn from this part" means that land that has been assessed under this part is no longer assessed under this part or eligible for assessment under this part for any reason including that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(a): an owner voluntarily requests that the land be withdrawn from this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(b): the land is no longer actively devoted to agricultural use;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(c): 59-2-509; 59-2-509
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(c)(i): the land has a change in ownership; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(c)(ii): 59-2-509; 59-2-509
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(c)(ii)(A): 59-2-509 the new owner fails to apply for assessment under this part as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(c)(ii)(B): 59-2-509
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(c)(ii)(B)(I): 59-2-509 an owner applies for assessment under this part as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(c)(ii)(B)(II): the land does not meet the requirements of this part to be assessed under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(d): 59-2-509; 59-2-509
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(d)(i): the legal description of the land changes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-502(8)(d)(ii): 59-2-509; 59-2-509

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503 Qualifications for agricultural use assessment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(1): For general property tax purposes, land may be assessed on the basis of the value that the land has for agricultural use if the land:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(1)(a): is not less than five contiguous acres in area, except that land may be assessed on the basis of the value that the land has for agricultural use:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(1)(a)(i): if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(1)(a)(i)(A): the land is devoted to agricultural use in conjunction with other eligible acreage; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(1)(a)(i)(B): the land and the other eligible acreage described in Subsection (1)(a)(i)(A) have identical legal ownership; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(1)(a)(ii): as provided under Subsections (4) and (5); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(1)(b): except as provided in Subsection (6) or (7):
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(1)(b)(i): is actively devoted to agricultural use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(1)(b)(ii): has been actively devoted to agricultural use for at least two successive years immediately preceding the tax year for which the land is being assessed under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(2): In determining whether land is actively devoted to agricultural use, production per acre for a given county or area and a given type of land shall be determined by using the first applicable of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(2)(a): production levels reported in the current publication of the Utah Agricultural Statistics;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(2)(b): current crop budgets developed and published by Utah State University; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(2)(c): other acceptable standards of agricultural production designated by the commission by rule adopted in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(3): 59-4-101 Land may be assessed on the basis of the land's agricultural value if the land:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(3)(a): 59-4-101 is subject to the privilege tax imposed by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(3)(b): is owned by the state or any of the state's political subdivisions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(3)(c): meets the requirements of Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(4): Notwithstanding Subsection (1)(a), the commission or a county board of equalization may grant a waiver of the acreage limitation for land upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(4)(a): appeal by the owner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(4)(b): submission of proof that 80% or more of the owner's, purchaser's, or lessee's income is derived from agricultural products produced on the property in question.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(5): Notwithstanding Subsection (1)(a), the commission or a county board of equalization shall grant a waiver of the acreage limitation for land upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(5)(a): appeal by the owner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(5)(b): submission of proof that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(5)(b)(i): the failure to meet the acreage requirement arose solely as a result of an acquisition by a public utility or a governmental entity by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(5)(b)(i)(A): eminent domain; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(5)(b)(i)(B): the threat or imminence of an eminent domain proceeding; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(5)(b)(ii): the land is actively devoted to agricultural use.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(6)(a): The commission or a county board of equalization may grant a waiver of the requirement that the land is actively devoted to agricultural use for the tax year for which the land is being assessed under this part upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(6)(a)(i): appeal by the owner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(6)(a)(ii): submission of proof that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(6)(a)(ii)(A): the land was assessed on the basis of agricultural use for at least two years immediately preceding that tax year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(6)(a)(ii)(B): the failure to meet the agricultural production requirements for that tax year was due to no fault or act of the owner, purchaser, or lessee.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(6)(b): As used in Subsection (6)(a), "fault" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(6)(b)(i): intentional planting of crops or trees which, because of the maturation period, do not give the owner, purchaser, or lessee a reasonable opportunity to satisfy the production levels required for land actively devoted to agricultural use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(6)(b)(ii): implementation of a bona fide range improvement program, crop rotation program, or other similar accepted cultural practices which do not give the owner, purchaser, or lessee a reasonable opportunity to satisfy the production levels required for land actively devoted to agricultural use.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(7): Land that otherwise qualifies for assessment under this part qualifies for assessment under this part in the first year the land resumes being actively devoted to agricultural use if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(7)(a): the land becomes ineligible for assessment under this part only as a result of a split estate mineral rights owner exercising the right to extract a mineral; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(7)(b): the land qualified for assessment under this part in the year immediately preceding the year the land became ineligible for assessment under this part only as a result of a split estate mineral rights owner exercising the right to extract a mineral.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(8): 65A-8a-106 Land that otherwise qualifies under Subsection (1) to be assessed on the basis of the value that the land has for agricultural use does not lose that qualification by becoming subject to a forest stewardship plan developed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(a): Notwithstanding Subsection (1) and except as provided in Subsection (9)(d), land in agricultural use that is intentionally allowed to lay fallow for one or more growing seasons qualifies for assessment under this part if the fallowing is conducted:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(a)(i): during periods of limited water supply;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(a)(ii): as part of a prudent farm management practice, including crop rotation, rotational grazing, or soil water management; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(a)(iii): to facilitate voluntary participation in a water management or agricultural water optimization program.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(b): If the owner of land assessed under this part fallows the land during any period in a calendar year, the owner may, on or before December 31 of the year in which the land is fallowed, provide to the county assessor written notice that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(b)(i): identifies the land that was fallowed during any period of the year in which the notice is provided, including the acreage of the fallowed land;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(b)(ii): demonstrates how the land qualifies under Subsection (9)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(b)(iii): specifies whether the owner intends to fallow the land during any period in the following calendar year, and, if so, the intended duration of the fallowing period.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(c)(i): If the written notice under Subsection (9)(b) indicates that the owner intends to fallow the land during any period in the following calendar year, the county assessor may, within 45 days of receiving the written notice, require the owner to submit to the county assessor a land management plan in a form prescribed by the county assessor that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(c)(i)(A): identifies the owner's objectives in fallowing the land for the intended duration of the fallowing period;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(c)(i)(B): provides adequate assurances to the county assessor that the fallowed land will become actively devoted to agricultural use upon the expiration of the intended fallowing period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(c)(i)(C): includes any other information required by the county assessor.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(c)(ii): If the owner submits to the county assessor a land management plan for fallowed land that meets the requirements of Subsection (9)(c)(i), the county assessor may not require the owner to submit a new or additional land management plan for the same land within three years from the day on which the owner submitted the plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(d): Fallowed land is withdrawn from this part if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(d)(i): the county assessor determines that the land does not qualify under Subsection (9)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(d)(ii): the owner fails to return the fallowed land to active agricultural use upon the expiration of the intended fallowing period as specified in the written notice; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-503(9)(d)(iii): the owner fails to comply with the requirements of Subsection (9)(c), if a land management plan is required.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504 Exclusions from designation as agricultural use -- Exception.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(1)(a): part of a platted subdivision or planned unit development, with restrictions prohibiting its use for agricultural purposes with surface improvements in place, whether within or without a city; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(1)(b): platted with surface improvements in place that are not an integral part of agricultural use.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(2)(a): If land has been platted with surface improvements in place, the land has been withdrawn from this part, and the owner is not able to transfer title to the platted property, or continue development of the platted property due to economic circumstances, or some other reasonable cause, the owner may petition the county assessor for reinstatement under this part for assessment purposes as land in agricultural use without vacating the subdivision plat.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(2)(b): (2)(a) The county assessor may grant the petition for reinstatement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3): For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(a): "platted with surface improvements in place" means that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(a)(i): land is platted; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(a)(ii): all surface improvements necessary for the land to be sold as a lot or a unit are in place:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(a)(ii)(A): regardless of whether or not it is the owner of the land who puts the surface improvements in place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(a)(ii)(B): as determined by the:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(a)(ii)(B)(I): county legislative body if the land is located in an unincorporated area of the county;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(a)(ii)(B)(II): city legislative body if the land is located in a city; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(a)(ii)(B)(III): town legislative body if the land is located in a town; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(b): "surface improvement" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(b)(i): a curb;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(b)(ii): a gutter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-504(3)(b)(iii): pavement.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506 Rollback tax -- Penalty -- Computation of tax -- Procedure -- Lien -- Interest -- Notice -- Collection -- Distribution.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(1): 59-2-506.5; 59-2-511 Except as provided in this section, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(2)(a): An owner shall notify the county assessor that land is withdrawn from this part within 120 days after the day on which the land is withdrawn from this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(2)(b): An owner that fails to notify the county assessor under Subsection (2)(a) that land is withdrawn from this part is subject to a penalty equal to the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(2)(b)(i): $10; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(2)(b)(ii): 2% of the rollback tax due for the last year of the rollback period.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(3)(a): The county assessor shall determine the amount of the rollback tax by computing the difference for the rollback period described in Subsection (3)(b) between:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(3)(a)(i): the tax paid while the land was assessed under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(3)(a)(ii): the tax that would have been paid had the property not been assessed under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(3)(b): For purposes of this section, the rollback period is a time period that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(3)(b)(i): begins on the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(3)(b)(i)(A): the date the land is first assessed under this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(3)(b)(i)(B): five years preceding the day on which the county assessor mails the notice required by Subsection (5); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(3)(b)(ii): ends the day on which the county assessor mails the notice required by Subsection (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(4): 4-46-102
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(4)(a): The county treasurer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(4)(a)(i): collect the rollback tax; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(4)(a)(ii): after the rollback tax is paid, certify to the county recorder that the rollback tax lien on the property has been satisfied by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(4)(a)(ii)(A): preparing a document that certifies that the rollback tax lien on the property has been satisfied; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(4)(a)(ii)(B): providing the document described in Subsection (4)(a)(ii)(A) to the county recorder for recordation.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(4)(b): 4-46-102 The county treasurer shall pay the rollback tax collected under this section as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(4)(b)(i): 4-46-102 20% to the county for use for open land and working agricultural land as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(4)(b)(ii): 80% to the various taxing entities pro rata in accordance with the property tax levies for the current year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(5)(a): The county assessor shall mail to an owner of the land that is subject to a rollback tax a notice that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(5)(a)(i): the land is withdrawn from this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(5)(a)(ii): the land is subject to a rollback tax under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(5)(a)(iii): the rollback tax is delinquent if the owner of the land does not pay the tax on or before the due date listed on the notice described in this Subsection (5)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(5)(b)(i): The rollback tax is due and payable within 60 days after the day on which the county assessor mails the notice required by Subsection (5)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(5)(b)(ii): Subject to Subsection (7), the rollback tax is delinquent if an owner of the land that is withdrawn from this part does not pay the rollback tax on or before the due date listed on the notice described in Subsection (5)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(6)(a): Subject to Subsection (6)(b), the following are a lien on the land assessed under this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(6)(a)(i): the rollback tax; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(6)(a)(ii): interest imposed in accordance with Subsection (7).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(6)(b): The lien described in Subsection (6)(a) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(6)(b)(i): arise upon the imposition of the rollback tax under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(6)(b)(ii): end on the day on which the rollback tax and interest imposed in accordance with Subsection (7) are paid in full; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(6)(b)(iii): relate back to the first day of the rollback period described in Subsection (3)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(7): 59-2-1331; 59-2-1317; 59-2-1317
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(7)(a): 59-2-1331 A delinquent rollback tax under this section shall accrue interest:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(7)(a)(i): from the date of delinquency until paid; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(7)(a)(ii): 59-2-1331 at the interest rate established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(7)(b): 59-2-1317; 59-2-1317 The county treasurer shall include in the notice required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(8)(a): Land that becomes ineligible for assessment under this part only as a result of an amendment to this part is not subject to the rollback tax if the owner of the land notifies the county assessor, in accordance with Subsection (2), that the land is withdrawn from this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(8)(b): Land described in Subsection (8)(a) that is withdrawn from this part as a result of an event other than an amendment to this part, whether voluntary or involuntary, is subject to the rollback tax.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(9): 59-2-511; 59-2-503 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(10): 59-2-503; 59-2-503 Land that becomes ineligible for assessment under this part only as a result of a split estate mineral rights owner exercising the right to extract a mineral is not subject to the rollback tax:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(10)(a): 59-2-503; 59-2-503
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(10)(a)(i): 59-2-503 for the portion of the land required by a split estate mineral rights owner to extract a mineral if, after the split estate mineral rights owner exercises the right to extract a mineral, the portion of the property that remains in agricultural production still meets the acreage requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(10)(a)(ii): 59-2-503 for the entire acreage that would otherwise qualify for assessment under this part if, after the split estate mineral rights owner exercises the right to extract a mineral, the entire acreage that would otherwise qualify for assessment under this part no longer meets the acreage requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(10)(b): for the period of time that the property described in Subsection (10)(a) is ineligible for assessment under this part due to the extraction of a mineral by the split estate mineral rights owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(11): 59-2-1707
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(11)(a): 59-2-1707 A portion of land withdrawn from this part is not subject to the rollback tax if the portion of land:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(11)(a)(i): qualifies for assessment under Part 17, Urban Farming Assessment Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(11)(a)(ii): 59-2-1707 for the tax year immediately following withdrawal, the owner of the portion of land applies in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506(11)(b): Any remaining portion of the withdrawn land that does not satisfy the requirements of Subsection (11)(a) is subject to the rollback tax.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-506.5 Conservation easement rollback tax -- One-time in lieu fee payment -- Computation -- Lien -- Interest -- Notice -- Procedure -- Collection -- Distribution.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
