Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004 Appeal to county board of equalization -- Real property -- Time period for appeal -- Public hearing requirements -- Decision of board -- Extensions approved by commission -- Appeal to commission.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1): 59-2-1006; 59-1-602; 59-2-1006 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(a): "Applicable lien date" means January 1 of the year in which the valuation or equalization of real property is appealed to the county board of equalization.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(b): 59-2-1006; 59-1-602 "Final assessed value" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(b)(i): for real property for which the taxpayer appealed the valuation or equalization to the county board of equalization in accordance with this section, the value given to the real property by the county board of equalization, including a value based on a stipulation of the parties;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(b)(ii): 59-2-1006 for real property for which the taxpayer or a county assessor appealed the valuation or equalization to the commission in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(b)(ii)(A): the commission, if the commission has issued a decision in the appeal or the parties have entered a stipulation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(b)(ii)(B): a county board of equalization, if the commission has not yet issued a decision in the appeal and the parties have not entered a stipulation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(b)(iii): 59-1-602 for real property for which the taxpayer or a county assessor sought judicial review of the valuation or equalization in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(c): "Inflation adjusted value" means the value of the real property that is the subject of the appeal as calculated by changing the final assessed value for the previous taxable year for the real property by the median property value change.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(d): "Median property value change" means the midpoint of the property value changes for all real property that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(d)(i): of the same class of real property as the qualified real property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(d)(ii): located within the same county and within the same market area as the qualified real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(e): "Property value change" means the percentage change in the fair market value of real property on or after January 1 of the previous year and before January 1 of the current year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(f): 59-2-1006 "Qualified real property" means real property:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(f)(i): 59-2-1006 for which:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(f)(i)(A): 59-2-1006 the taxpayer or a county assessor appealed the valuation or equalization for the previous taxable year to the county board of equalization in accordance with this section or the commission in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(f)(i)(B): the appeal described in Subsection (1)(f)(i)(A), resulted in a final assessed value that was lower than the assessed value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(f)(i)(C): the assessed value for the current taxable year is higher than the inflation adjusted value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(f)(ii): that, on or after January 1 of the previous taxable year and before January 1 of the current taxable year, has not had a qualifying change.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(g): "Qualifying change" means one of the following changes to real property that occurs on or after January 1 of the previous taxable year and before January 1 of the current taxable year:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(g)(i): a physical improvement if, solely as a result of the physical improvement, the fair market value of the physical improvement equals or exceeds the greater of 10% of fair market value of the real property or $20,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(g)(ii): a zoning change, if the fair market value of the real property increases solely as a result of the zoning change; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(g)(iii): a change in the legal description of the real property, if the fair market value of the real property increases solely as a result of the change in the legal description of the real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(h): "Qualifying contract" means a contract for the completed sale of residential property that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(h)(i): involves residential property for which a taxpayer appealed the valuation or equalization to the county board of equalization;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(h)(ii): identifies the final sales price for the residential property described in Subsection (1)(h)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(1)(h)(iii): is executed within six months before or after the applicable lien date.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(a): A taxpayer dissatisfied with the valuation or the equalization of the taxpayer's real property may make an application to appeal by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(a)(i): filing the application with the county board of equalization within the time period described in Subsection (3); or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(a)(ii): making an application by telephone or other electronic means within the time period described in Subsection (3) if the county legislative body passes a resolution under Subsection (11) authorizing a taxpayer to make an application by telephone or other electronic means.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(b)(i): The county board of equalization shall make a rule describing the contents of the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(b)(ii): In addition to any information the county board of equalization requires, the application shall include information about:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(b)(ii)(A): the burden of proof in an appeal involving qualified real property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(b)(ii)(B): the process for the taxpayer to learn the inflation adjusted value of the qualified real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(c)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(c)(i)(A): The county assessor shall notify the county board of equalization of a qualified real property's inflation adjusted value within 15 business days after the date on which the county assessor receives notice that a taxpayer filed an appeal with the county board of equalization.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(c)(i)(B): The county assessor shall notify the commission of a qualified real property's inflation adjusted value within 15 business days after the date on which the county assessor receives notice that a person dissatisfied with the decision of a county board of equalization files an appeal with the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(c)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(c)(ii)(A): A person may not appeal a county assessor's calculation of inflation adjusted value but may appeal the fair market value of a qualified real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(2)(c)(ii)(B): A person may appeal a determination of whether, on or after January 1 of the previous taxable year and before January 1 of the current taxable year, real property had a qualifying change.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(3): 59-2-919.1
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(3)(a): 59-2-919.1 Except as provided in Subsection (3)(b) and for purposes of Subsection (2), a taxpayer shall make an application to appeal the valuation or the equalization of the taxpayer's real property on or before the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(3)(a)(i): September 15 of the current calendar year; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(3)(a)(ii): 59-2-919.1 the last day of a 45-day period beginning on the day on which the county auditor provides the notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(3)(b): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the commission shall make rules providing for circumstances under which the county board of equalization is required to accept an application to appeal that is filed after the time period prescribed in Subsection (3)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(4): 59-2-301.8; 59-2-301.8
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(4)(a): 59-2-301.8; 59-2-301.8 The taxpayer shall include in the application under Subsection (2)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(4)(a)(i): the taxpayer's estimate of the fair market value of the property and any evidence that may indicate that the assessed valuation of the taxpayer's property is improperly equalized with the assessed valuation of comparable properties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(4)(a)(ii): 59-2-301.8; 59-2-301.8 a signed statement of the personal property located in a multi-tenant residential property, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(4)(a)(ii)(A): 59-2-301.8 appeals the value of multi-tenant residential property assessed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(4)(a)(ii)(B): intends to contest the value of the personal property located within the multi-tenant residential property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(4)(b): For an appeal involving qualified real propertythe county board of equalization shall presume that the fair market value of the qualified real property is equal to the inflation adjusted value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(5): Subject to Subsection (6), in reviewing evidence submitted to a county board of equalization by or on behalf of an owner or a county assessor, the county board of equalization shall consider and weigh:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(5)(a): the accuracy, reliability, and comparability of the evidence presented by the owner or the county assessor;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(5)(b): if submitted, the sales price of relevant property that was under contract for sale as of the lien date but sold after the lien date;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(5)(c): if submitted, the sales offering price of property that was offered for sale as of the lien date but did not sell, including considering and weighing the amount of time for which, and manner in which, the property was offered for sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(5)(d): if submitted, other evidence that is relevant to determining the fair market value of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(6)(a): This Subsection (6) applies only to an appeal to a county board of equalization involving the valuation or equalization of residential property that is not qualified real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(6)(b): If a qualifying contract is submitted as evidence in an appeal described in Subsection (6)(a), the only evidence that the county board of equalization or hearing officer may consider to determine that the final sales price identified in the qualifying contract does not provide an accurate or reliable indication of the fair market value of the residential property is evidence of the following, if submitted:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(6)(b)(i): evidence disputing the nature of the qualifying contract as an arms-length transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(6)(b)(ii): evidence demonstrating that changes in market conditions have occurred in the time period between the day on which the qualifying contract was executed and the applicable lien date; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(6)(b)(iii): evidence demonstrating that a qualifying change to the residential property has occurred in the time period between the day on which the qualifying contract was executed and the applicable lien date.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(6)(c): In determining the fair market value of residential property in an appeal described in Subsection (6)(a), the county board of equalization may not consider any evidence or information other than the evidence submitted to the county board of equalization by the parties in the appeal.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7): 59-1-404; 59-1-404
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (7)(b), at least five days before the day on which the county board of equalization holds a public hearing on an appeal:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(a)(i): the county assessor shall provide the taxpayer any evidence the county assessor relies upon in support of the county assessor's valuation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(a)(ii): the taxpayer shall provide the county assessor any evidence not previously provided to the county assessor that the taxpayer relies upon in support of the taxpayer's appeal.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(b): 59-1-404; 59-1-404
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(b)(i): 59-1-404; 59-1-404 The deadline described in Subsection (7)(a) does not apply to evidence that is commercial information as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(b)(i)(A): 59-1-404 for the purpose of complying with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(b)(i)(B): the taxpayer fails to execute the nondisclosure agreement before the deadline described in Subsection (7)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(b)(ii): The county assessor shall disclose evidence described in Subsection (7)(b)(i) as soon as practicable after the county assessor receives the executed nondisclosure agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(b)(iii): The county assessor shall provide the taxpayer a copy of the nondisclosure agreement with reasonable time for the taxpayer to review and execute the agreement before the deadline described in Subsection (7)(a) expires.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(c): If at the public hearing, a party presents evidence not previously provided to the other party, the county board of equalization shall allow the other party to respond to the evidence in writing within 10 days after the day on which the public hearing occurs.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(d)(i): A county board of equalization may adopt rules governing the deadlines described in this Subsection (7), if the rules are no less stringent than the provisions of this Subsection (7).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(7)(d)(ii): A county board of equalization's rule that complies with Subsection (7)(d)(i) controls over the provisions of this subsection.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8): 59-2-1001; 59-2-301.1; 59-2-301.2; 59-2-301.3; 59-2-301.4
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(a): 59-2-1001 The county board of equalization shall meet and hold public hearings as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(b)(i): For purposes of this Subsection (8)(b), "significant adjustment" means a proposed adjustment to the valuation of real property that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(b)(i)(A): is to be made by a county board of equalization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(b)(i)(B): would result in a valuation that differs from the original assessed value by at least 20% and $1,000,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(b)(ii): When a county board of equalization is going to consider a significant adjustment, the county board of equalization shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(b)(ii)(A): list the significant adjustment as a separate item on the agenda of the public hearing at which the county board of equalization is going to consider the significant adjustment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(b)(ii)(B): for purposes of the agenda described in Subsection (8)(b)(ii)(A), provide a description of the property for which the county board of equalization is considering a significant adjustment.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(c): The county board of equalization shall make a decision on each appeal filed in accordance with this section within 60 days after the day on which the taxpayer makes an application.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(d): The commission may approve the extension of a time period provided for in Subsection (8)(c) for a county board of equalization to make a decision on an appeal.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(e): Unless the commission approves the extension of a time period under Subsection (8)(d), if a county board of equalization fails to make a decision on an appeal within the time period described in Subsection (8)(c), the county legislative body shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(e)(i): list the appeal, by property owner and parcel number, on the agenda for the next meeting the county legislative body holds after the expiration of the time period described in Subsection (8)(c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(e)(ii): hear the appeal at the meeting described in Subsection (8)(e)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(f): The decision of the county board of equalization shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(f)(i): a determination of the valuation of the property based on fair market value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(f)(ii): a conclusion that the fair market value is properly equalized with the assessed value of comparable properties.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(g): If no evidence is presented before the county board of equalization, the county board of equalization shall presume that the equalization issue has been met.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(h): 59-2-301.1; 59-2-301.2; 59-2-301.3; 59-2-301.4
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(h)(i): If the fair market value of the property that is the subject of the appeal deviates plus or minus 5% from the assessed value of comparable properties, the county board of equalization shall adjust the valuation of the appealed property to reflect a value equalized with the assessed value of comparable properties.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(8)(h)(ii): 59-2-301.1; 59-2-301.2; 59-2-301.3; 59-2-301.4 Subject to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(9)(a): If the decision of the county board of equalization warrants a refund of any amount of property taxes paid for the tax year for the real property that is the subject of the appeal, the county shall issue the refund directly to the taxpayer that paid the property taxes, or an officer or agent of that taxpayer as identified in the information provided under Subsection (9)(b), regardless of whether the taxpayer is the owner of record of the real property at the time the decision is rendered.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(9)(b): A taxpayer entitled to a refund under this section that is not the owner of record of the real property subject to the appeal shall, within 10 calendar days after the day on which the decision of the county board of equalization is rendered, provide the following information to the county board of equalization:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(9)(b)(i): a statement that the taxpayer is entitled to receive the refund under Subsection (9)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(9)(b)(ii): the name of the taxpayer, or an officer or agent of that taxpayer, entitled to receive the refund;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(9)(b)(iii): the mailing address of the taxpayer, or an officer or agent of that taxpayer, to which the taxpayer requests the refund to be sent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(9)(b)(iv): any other information requested by the county board of equalization.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(10): 59-2-1006 If any taxpayer is dissatisfied with the decision of the county board of equalization, the taxpayer may file an appeal with the commission as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004(11): A county legislative body may pass a resolution authorizing taxpayers owing taxes on property assessed by that county to file property tax appeals applications under this section by telephone or other electronic means.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.1(1)(a)(i): the taxpayer filed an appeal of the valuation or equalization of the property with the county board of equalization for the calendar year that begins on January 1, 2023;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.1(1)(a)(ii): 59-2-1004 the county board of equalization has issued a decision in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5 Valuation adjustment for decrease in taxable value caused by a natural disaster.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1): (1); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(a): (1); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act "Natural disaster" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(a)(i): an explosion;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(a)(ii): fire;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(a)(iii): a flood;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(a)(iv): a storm;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(a)(v): a tornado;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(a)(vi): winds;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(a)(vii): an earthquake;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(a)(viii): lightning;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(a)(ix): any adverse weather event; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(a)(x): (1); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act any event similar to an event described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(1)(b): "Natural disaster damage" means any physical harm to property caused by a natural disaster.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(2): (3); (4) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(3): (2); (2); (2) An owner may not receive the valuation adjustment described in this section if the decrease in taxable value described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(3)(a): due to the intentional action or inaction of the owner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(3)(b): (2); (2) less than 30% of the taxable value of the property described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(4): (2); 59-2-1004(3); (2); (4)(a); 59-2-1001; (4)(b); (4)(c)(i); (4)(c)(i); (4)(c)(i); (4)(c)(i); (4)(c); (4)(c)(i); (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(4)(a): (2); 59-2-1004(3); (2) To receive the valuation adjustment described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(4)(a)(i): 59-2-1004(3) the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(4)(a)(ii): (2) 45 days after the day on which the natural disaster damage described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(4)(b): (4)(a); 59-2-1001 The county board of equalization shall hold a hearing:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(4)(b)(i): (4)(a) within 30 days after the day on which the county board of equalization receives the application described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(4)(b)(ii): 59-2-1001 following the procedures and requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(4)(c): (4)(b); (4)(c)(i); (4)(c)(i); (4)(c)(i); (4)(c)(i) At the hearing described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(4)(c)(i): (4)(c)(i); (4)(c)(i) that the property sustained a decrease in taxable value, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(4)(c)(i)(A): was caused by natural disaster damage; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.5(4)(c)(i)(B): (4)(c)(i); (4)(c)(i) is at least 30% of the taxable value of the property described in this Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.6 Tax relief for decrease in fair market value due to access interruption.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.6(1): (1); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act For purposes of this section "access interruption" means interruption of the normal access to or from property due to any circumstance beyond the control of the owner, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.6(1)(a): road construction;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.6(1)(b): traffic diversion;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.6(1)(c): an accident;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.6(1)(d): vandalism;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.6(1)(e): an explosion;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.6(1)(f): fire;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1004.6(1)(g): a flood;

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1005(1)(b)(ii): render a written decision on the appeal within 60 days after receiving the appeal.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1006(3)(b): issue orders that it considers to be just and proper; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1006(3)(c): make any correction or change in the assessment or order of the county board of equalization or entity with decision-making authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1006(4): In reviewing evidence submitted to the commission to decide an appeal under this section, the commission shall consider and weigh:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1006(4)(a): the accuracy, reliability, and comparability of the evidence presented;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1006(4)(b): if submitted, the sales price of relevant property that was under contract for sale as of the lien date but sold after the lien date;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1006(4)(c): if submitted, the sales offering price of property that was offered for sale as of the lien date but did not sell, including considering and weighing the amount of time for which, and manner in which, the property was offered for sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1006(4)(d): if submitted, other evidence that is relevant to determining the fair market value of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1006(5): (1) In reviewing a decision described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1006(5)(a): the issue of equalization of property values is raised; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1006(5)(b): the commission determines that the property that is the subject of the appeal deviates in value plus or minus 5% from the assessed value of comparable properties.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1006(6): The commission shall decide all appeals taken pursuant to this section not later than March 1 of the following year for real property and within 90 days for personal property, and shall report its decision, order, or assessment to the county auditor, who shall make all changes necessary to comply with the decision, order, or assessment.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008 Investigations by commission -- Assessment of escaped property -- Increase or decrease of assessed valuation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(1): 59-2-303.3; 59-2-303.3 As used in this section, "review information" means, as reported by a county assessor:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(1)(a): 59-2-303.3 the number of properties that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(1)(a)(i): 59-2-303.3 required a review in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(1)(a)(ii): the county reduced the value as a result of the review; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(1)(b): 59-2-303.3 the parcel number of any property:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(1)(b)(i): 59-2-303.3 that required a review in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(1)(b)(ii): that has an increase in value of $50,000 or more; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(1)(b)(iii): for which the county assessor did not reduce the value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(2)(a): Each year the commission shall conduct an investigation throughout each county of the state to determine whether all property subject to taxation is on the assessment rolls and whether the property is being assessed at fair market value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(2)(b): When, after any investigation, the commission finds that any property that is subject to taxation is not assessed, the commission shall direct the county assessor, the county board of equalization, or the county auditor, as the commission may determine, to enter the assessment of the escaped property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(3): If the commission finds that any property in any county is not being assessed at the property's fair market value, the commission shall, for the purpose of equalizing the value of property in the state, increase or decrease the valuation of the property in order to enforce the assessment of all property subject to taxation upon the basis of its fair market value, and shall direct the county assessor, the county board of equalization, or the county auditor, as the commission may determine, to correct the value of the property in a manner prescribed by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(4): The county assessors, county boards of equalization, and county auditors shall make all increases or decreases as may be required by the commission to make the assessment of all property within the county conform to the property's fair market value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(5): 59-1-210 Each year, after receiving the review information from a county assessor and on or before June 8, the commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(5)(a): review the assessment of a property described in Subsection (1)(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(5)(b): 59-1-210 if warranted, take action as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(6): For review information relating to the calendar year that begins January 1, 2023, the commission shall on or before June 15, 2024:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(6)(a): review the assessment of a property described in Subsection (1)(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(6)(b): if warranted, take reasonable action to correct an error in assessment and report any action to the county auditor.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(7): The commission shall report the review information and the number of properties for which an adjustment is made in accordance with Subsection (5) to the Revenue and Taxation Interim Committee annually on or before the September interim meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1008(8): The commission shall include in the report the name of each county that reported review information for the current calendar year and the previous calendar year.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1009 Equalization based on reports of county auditors.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Before July 7 the commission shall examine and compare the reports of the county auditors and shall equalize the assessment of the taxable property of the several counties of the state for the purpose of taxation.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1010 Statement of equalization to be sent to county auditors.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When the equalization among the several counties is completed, the commission shall transmit to each county auditor and to the state auditor a statement of the changes made by it in the assessment books of each county or any assessment contained in the book, which is prima facie evidence of the regularity of all proceedings of the commission resulting in the action which is the subject matter of the statement.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1011 Record of changes -- Form and contents of signed statement.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The county auditor shall make a record of all changes, corrections, and orders and before October 15 shall affix a signed statement to the record, subscribed by the auditor, in a form substantially as follows:

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017 Property tax appeal assistance.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1): Title 61, Chapter 2g, Real Estate Appraiser Licensing and Certification Act; Title 61, Chapter 2g, Real Estate Appraiser Licensing and Certification Act; (5); (6) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(a): Title 61, Chapter 2g, Real Estate Appraiser Licensing and Certification Act "Certified appraiser" means an appraiser certified in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(a)(i): Title 61, Chapter 2g, Real Estate Appraiser Licensing and Certification Act
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(a)(ii): the law of a jurisdiction in the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(b): Title 61, Chapter 2g, Real Estate Appraiser Licensing and Certification Act "Licensed appraiser" means an appraiser licensed in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(b)(i): Title 61, Chapter 2g, Real Estate Appraiser Licensing and Certification Act
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(b)(ii): the law of a jurisdiction in the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(c): (5); (6) "Opinion of value" means an estimate of fair market value that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(c)(i): is made by a licensed appraiser or a certified appraiser; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(c)(ii): (5); (6) except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(d): "Present evidence" means to present information:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(d)(i): to a county board of equalization or the commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(d)(ii): related to a property tax appeal made in accordance with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(e): "Price estimate" means an estimate:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(e)(i): of the price that property would sell for; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(e)(ii): that is not an opinion of value.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(1)(f): "Provide property tax information" means to provide information related to a property tax appeal made in accordance with this part to another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(2): Subject to the other provisions of this section, a person may:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(2)(a): present evidence in a property tax appeal on behalf of another person after obtaining permission from that other person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(2)(b): provide property tax information to another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(3): (2) For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(3)(a): only a licensed appraiser or a certified appraiser may present or provide an opinion of value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(3)(b): a licensed appraiser or a certified appraiser may not present or provide a price estimate.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(4): (2) A licensed appraiser or a certified appraiser may, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(4)(a): present or provide an opinion of value; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(4)(b): provide consultation services, including presenting evidence or providing property tax information.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(5): (2); 61-2g-304; 61-2g-403; 61-2g-406; 61-2g-407; (2); 61-2g-304; 61-2g-403; 61-2g-406; 61-2g-407; (2); 61-2g-407; 61-2g-406
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(5)(a): (2); 61-2g-304; 61-2g-403; 61-2g-406; 61-2g-407 A licensed appraiser or a certified appraiser who presents or provides an opinion of value in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(5)(b): (2); 61-2g-304; 61-2g-403; 61-2g-406; 61-2g-407 A licensed appraiser or a certified appraiser who does not present or provide an opinion of value but who provides consultation services by presenting evidence or providing property tax information in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(5)(c): (2); 61-2g-407; 61-2g-406 A person who is not a licensed appraiser and not a certified appraiser who presents evidence or provides property tax information in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(5)(c)(i): 61-2g-407 is subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(5)(c)(ii): 61-2g-406 if the person charges a contingent fee, is subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(6): A licensed appraiser or a certified appraiser may provide an opinion of value, present evidence, or provide tax information in a property tax appeal of the personal residence of the licensed appraiser or certified appraiser despite any personal bias.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1017(7): A county board of equalization or the commission may evaluate the reliability or accuracy of evidence presented or property tax information provided in accordance with this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101 Definitions -- Exemption of certain property -- Proportional payments for certain property -- Exception -- County legislative body authority to adopt rules or ordinances.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1): 59-7-607; 59-10-1010 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(a): "Charitable purposes" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(a)(i): for property used as a nonprofit hospital or a nursing home, the standards outlined in Howell v. County Board of Cache County ex rel. IHC Hospitals, Inc., 881 P.2d 880 (Utah 1994); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(a)(ii): for property other than property described in Subsection (1)(a)(i), providing a gift to the community.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(b): 59-7-607; 59-10-1010 "Compliance period" means a period equal to 15 taxable years beginning with the first taxable year for which the taxpayer claims a tax credit under Section 42, Internal Revenue Code, or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(c)(i): "Educational purposes" means purposes carried on by an educational organization that normally:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(c)(i)(A): maintains a regular faculty and curriculum; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(c)(i)(B): has a regularly enrolled body of pupils and students.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(c)(ii): "Educational purposes" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(c)(ii)(A): the physical or mental teaching, training, or conditioning of competitive athletes by a national governing body of sport recognized by the United States Olympic Committee that qualifies as being tax exempt under Section 501(c)(3), Internal Revenue Code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(c)(ii)(B): an activity in support of or incidental to the teaching, training, or conditioning described in this Subsection (1)(c)(ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(d): "Exclusive use exemption" means a property tax exemption under Subsection (3)(a)(iv), for property owned by a nonprofit entity used exclusively for one or more of the following purposes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(d)(i): religious purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(d)(ii): charitable purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(d)(iii): educational purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(e)(i): "Farm machinery and equipment" means tractors, milking equipment and storage and cooling facilities, feed handling equipment, irrigation equipment, harvesters, choppers, grain drills and planters, tillage tools, scales, combines, spreaders, sprayers, haying equipment, including balers and cubers, and any other machinery or equipment used primarily for agricultural purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(e)(ii): "Farm machinery and equipment" does not include vehicles required to be registered with the Motor Vehicle Division or vehicles or other equipment used for business purposes other than farming.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(f): "Gift to the community" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(f)(i): the lessening of a government burden; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(f)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(f)(ii)(A): the provision of a significant service to others without immediate expectation of material reward;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(f)(ii)(B): the use of the property is supported to a material degree by donations and gifts including volunteer service;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(f)(ii)(C): the recipients of the charitable activities provided on the property are not required to pay for the assistance received, in whole or in part, except that if in part, to a material degree;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(f)(ii)(D): the beneficiaries of the charitable activities provided on the property are unrestricted or, if restricted, the restriction bears a reasonable relationship to the charitable objectives of the nonprofit entity that owns the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(f)(ii)(E): any commercial activities provided on the property are subordinate or incidental to charitable activities provided on the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(g): "Government exemption" means a property tax exemption provided under Subsection (3)(a)(i), (ii), or (iii).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(i): "Nonprofit entity" means an entity:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(i)(A): that is organized on a nonprofit basis, that dedicates the entity's property to the entity's nonprofit purpose, and that makes no dividend or other form of financial benefit available to a private interest;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(i)(B): for which, upon dissolution, the entity's assets are distributable only for exempt purposes under state law or to the government for a public purpose; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(i)(C): for which none of the net earnings or donations made to the entity inure to the benefit of private shareholders or other individuals, as the private inurement standard has been interpreted under Section 501(c)(3), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(ii): "Nonprofit entity" includes an entity:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(ii)(A): if the entity is treated as a disregarded entity for federal income tax purposes and wholly owned by, and controlled under the direction of, a nonprofit entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(ii)(B): for which none of the net earnings and profits of the entity inure to the benefit of any person other than a nonprofit entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(iii): "Nonprofit entity" includes an entity that is not an entity described in Subsection (1)(h)(i) if the entity jointly owns a property that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(iii)(A): is used for the purpose of providing permanent supportive housing;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(iii)(B): has an owner that is an entity described in Subsection (1)(h)(i) or that is a housing authority that operates the permanent supportive housing;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(iii)(C): has an owner that receives public funding from a federal, state, or local government entity to provide support services and rental subsidies to the permanent supportive housing;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(iii)(D): is intended to be transferred at or before the end of the compliance period to an entity described in Subsection (1)(h)(i) or a housing authority that will continue to operate the property as permanent supportive housing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(h)(iii)(E): has been certified by the Utah Housing Corporation as meeting the requirements described in Subsections (1)(h)(iii)(A) through (D).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(i): "Permanent supportive housing" means a housing facility that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(i)(i): provides supportive services;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(i)(ii): makes a 15-year commitment to provide rent subsidies to tenants of the housing facility when the housing facility is placed in service;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(i)(iii): receives an allocation of federal low-income housing tax credits in accordance with 26 U.S.C. Sec. 42; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(i)(iv): leases each unit to a tenant:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(i)(iv)(A): who, immediately before leasing the housing, was homeless as defined in 24 C.F.R. 583.5; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(i)(iv)(B): whose rent is capped at no more than 30% of the tenant's household income.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(j): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(j)(i): "Property of" means property that an entity listed in Subsection (3)(a)(ii) or (iii) has a legal right to possess.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(j)(ii): "Property of" includes a lease of real property if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(j)(ii)(A): the property is wholly leased to a state or political subdivision entity listed in Subsection (3)(a)(ii) or (iii) under a triple net lease; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(j)(ii)(B): the lease is in effect for the entire calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(k): "Supportive service" means a service that is an eligible cost under 24 C.F.R. 578.53.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(1)(l): "Triple net lease" means a lease agreement under which the lessee is responsible for the real estate taxes, building insurance, and maintenance of the property separate from and in addition to the rental price.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), an exemption under this part may be allowed only if the claimant is the owner of the property as of January 1 of the year the exemption is claimed.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(2)(b): A claimant shall collect and pay a proportional tax based upon the length of time that the property was not owned by the claimant if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(2)(b)(i): the claimant is a federal, state, or political subdivision entity described in Subsection (3)(a)(i), (ii), or (iii); or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(2)(b)(ii): pursuant to Subsection (3)(a)(iv):
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(2)(b)(ii)(A): the claimant is a nonprofit entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(2)(b)(ii)(B): the property is used exclusively for religious, charitable, or educational purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3): 10-9a-525; 11-13-103; 11-13-103; 11-13-302
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a): 10-9a-525; 11-13-103; 11-13-103; 11-13-302 The following property is exempt from taxation:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(i): property exempt under the laws of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(ii): property of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(ii)(A): the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(ii)(B): school districts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(ii)(C): public libraries;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(iii): except as provided in Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act, property of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(iii)(A): counties;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(iii)(B): cities;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(iii)(C): towns;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(iii)(D): special districts;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(iii)(E): special service districts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(iii)(F): all other political subdivisions of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(iv): except as provided in Subsection (6) or (7), property owned by a nonprofit entity used exclusively for one or more of the following purposes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(iv)(A): religious purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(iv)(B): charitable purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(iv)(C): educational purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(v): places of burial not held or used for private or corporate benefit;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(vi): farm machinery and equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(vii): 10-9a-525 a high tunnel, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(viii): intangible property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(ix): 11-13-103; 11-13-103; 11-13-302 the ownership interest of an out-of-state public agency, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(ix)(A): 11-13-103 if that ownership interest is in property providing additional project capacity, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(a)(ix)(B): 11-13-302 on which a fee in lieu of ad valorem property tax is payable under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(3)(b): For purposes of a property tax exemption for property of school districts under Subsection (3)(a)(ii)(B), a charter school under Title 53G, Chapter 5, Charter Schools, is considered to be a school district.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(4): Subject to Subsection (5), if property that is allowed an exclusive use exemption or a government exemption ceases to qualify for the exemption because of a change in the ownership of the property:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(4)(a): the new owner of the property shall pay a proportional tax based upon the period of time:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(4)(a)(i): beginning on the day that the new owner acquired the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(4)(a)(ii): ending on the last day of the calendar year during which the new owner acquired the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(4)(b): the new owner of the property and the person from whom the new owner acquires the property shall notify the county assessor, in writing, of the change in ownership of the property within 30 days from the day that the new owner acquires the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(5): Notwithstanding Subsection (4)(a), the proportional tax described in Subsection (4)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(5)(a): is subject to any exclusive use exemption or government exemption that the property is entitled to under the new ownership of the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(5)(b): applies only to property that is acquired after December 31, 2005.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(6)(a): A property may not receive an exemption under Subsection (3)(a)(iv) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(6)(a)(i): the nonprofit entity that owns the property participates in or intervenes in any political campaign on behalf of or in opposition to any candidate for public office, including the publishing or distribution of statements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(6)(a)(ii): a substantial part of the activities of the nonprofit entity that owns the property consists of carrying on propaganda or otherwise attempting to influence legislation, except as provided under Subsection 501(h), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(6)(b): Whether a nonprofit entity is engaged in an activity described in Subsection (6)(a) shall be determined using the standards described in Section 501, Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(7): A property may not receive an exemption under Subsection (3)(a)(iv) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(7)(a): the property is used for a purpose that is not religious, charitable, or educational; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(7)(b): the use for a purpose that is not religious, charitable, or educational is more than de minimis.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(8): A county legislative body may adopt rules or ordinances to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(8)(a): effectuate an exemption under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(8)(b): designate one or more persons to perform the functions given to the county under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1101(9): 59-2-1006 If a person is dissatisfied with an exemption decision made under designated decision-making authority as described in Subsection (8)(b), that person may appeal the decision to the commission under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102 Determination of exemptions by board of equalization -- Appeal -- Application for exemption -- Annual statement -- Exceptions.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(1)(a): For property assessed under Part 3, County Assessment, the county board of equalization may, after giving notice in a manner prescribed by rule, determine whether certain property within the county is exempt from taxation.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(1)(b): The decision of the county board of equalization described in Subsection (1)(a) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(1)(b)(i): be in writing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(1)(b)(ii): include:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(1)(b)(ii)(A): a statement of facts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(1)(b)(ii)(B): the statutory basis for its decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(1)(c): Except as provided in Subsection (10)(a), a copy of the decision described in Subsection (1)(a) shall be sent on or before May 15 to the person applying for the exemption.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(2): Except as provided in Subsection (7) and subject to Subsection (8), a county board of equalization may not grant an exemption under this part unless the person affected or the person's agent:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(2)(a): submits a written application to the county board of equalization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(2)(b): verifies the application by signed statement.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(3)(a): The county board of equalization may require a person making an application for exemption to appear before the county board of equalization and be examined under oath.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(3)(b): If the county board of equalization requires a person making an application for exemption to appear before the county board of equalization, the county board of equalization may not grant an exemption unless the person affected or the person's agent appears and answers all questions pertinent to the inquiry.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(4): For the hearing on the application, the county board of equalization may subpoena any witnesses, and hear and take any evidence in relation to the pending application.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(5): Except as provided in Subsection (10)(b), the county board of equalization shall hold hearings and render a written decision to determine any exemption on or before May 1 in each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(6): 59-2-1006 Any person that made an exemption application and is dissatisfied with the decision of the county board of equalization regarding any exemption may appeal to the commission under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(7): 59-2-1101; 59-2-1101; 59-2-1110; 59-2-1111; 59-2-1112; 59-2-1113; 59-2-1114; 59-2-1101; 59-2-1101
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(7)(a): 59-2-1101; 59-2-1101; 59-2-1110; 59-2-1111; 59-2-1112; 59-2-1113; 59-2-1114 A county board of equalization may not require an owner of property to file an application in accordance with this section to claim an exemption for the property under the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(7)(a)(i): 59-2-1101 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(7)(a)(ii): 59-2-1101 Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(7)(a)(v): 59-2-1112 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(7)(a)(vi): 59-2-1113 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(7)(a)(vii): 59-2-1114 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(7)(b): 59-2-1101; 59-2-1101 A county board of equalization may not require an owner of property to file an application in accordance with this section to claim an exemption for the property described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8): 59-2-1101; 59-2-1101; 59-2-1101; 59-2-1101
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(a): 59-2-1101 Except as provided in Subsection (8)(b), for property described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(b): 59-2-1101 A county board of equalization may not require an owner of property described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(b)(i): the owner filed an application under Subsection (8)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(b)(ii): the county board of equalization determines that the owner may claim an exemption for that property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(b)(iii): the exemption described in Subsection (8)(b)(ii) is in effect.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(c): 59-2-1101
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(c)(i): 59-2-1101 For the time period that an owner is granted an exemption in accordance with this section for property described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(c)(ii): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the commission shall make rules providing:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(c)(ii)(A): the form for the annual statement required by Subsection (8)(c)(i);
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(c)(ii)(B): the contents of the form for the annual statement required by Subsection (8)(c)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(c)(ii)(C): procedures and requirements for making the annual statement required by Subsection (8)(c)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(c)(iii): The commission shall make the form described in Subsection (8)(c)(ii)(A) available to counties.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(d): On or before April 1, a county board of equalization shall notify each property owner that fails to timely file an annual statement in accordance with Subsection (8)(c) of the county board of equalization's intent to revoke the exemption.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(e): 59-2-1101 An owner of exempt property described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(e)(i): files the annual statement on or before March 31; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(e)(ii): includes a statement of facts establishing that the property owner was unable to file the annual statement on or before March 1 due to one of the following conditions and no other responsible party was capable of filing the annual statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(e)(ii)(A): a medical emergency of the property owner, an immediate family member of the property owner, or the property owner's agent;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(e)(ii)(B): the death of the property owner, an immediate family member of the property owner, or the property owner's agent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(8)(e)(ii)(C): other extraordinary and unanticipated circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(9): 59-2-1101
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(9)(a): 59-2-1101 For purposes of this Subsection (9), "exclusive use exemption" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(9)(b): For purposes of Subsection (1)(a), when a person acquires property on or after January 1 that qualifies for an exclusive use exemption, that person may apply for the exclusive use exemption on or before the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(9)(b)(i): the day set by rule as the deadline for filing a property tax exemption application; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(9)(b)(ii): 120 days after the day on which the property is acquired.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(10)(a): Notwithstanding Subsection (1)(c), if a person files an application for an exemption under Subsection (9), a county board of equalization shall send a copy of the decision described in Subsection (1)(c) to the person applying for the exemption on or before the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(10)(a)(i): May 15; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(10)(a)(ii): 45 days after the day on which the application for the exemption is filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(10)(b): Notwithstanding Subsection (5), if an application for an exemption is filed under Subsection (9), a county board of equalization shall hold the hearing and render the decision described in Subsection (5) on or before the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(10)(b)(i): May 1; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1102(10)(b)(ii): 30 days after the day on which the application for the exemption is filed.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103 State lands exemption -- Exceptions to exemption.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(1): Lands to which title remains in the state, which are held or occupied by any person under a contract of sale or lease from the state, are exempt from taxation.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(2): (2)(b)(i); 59-4-101(1)(b); 59-4-101 This section does not exempt the taxation of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(2)(a): improvements on state lands;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(2)(b): (2)(b)(i); 59-4-101(1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(2)(b)(i): any interest in state lands to the extent of money paid or due in part payment of the purchase price, regardless of whether an extension of payment was granted prior to the levying of this tax; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(2)(b)(ii): (2)(b)(i); 59-4-101(1)(b) any interest remaining in the state in state lands after subtracting amounts paid or due in part payment of the purchase price as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(2)(c): 59-4-101 land otherwise subject to the privilege tax under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(3): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(3)(a): (1) If final payment has been made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(3)(b): The state agency from which the interest was purchased shall certify the receipt of final payment to the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(4): Any tax levied on the interest of a purchaser of state lands before title passes to the purchaser or assignee shall be collected in the same manner as taxes on personal property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(5): The interest of a purchaser of state lands is subject to sale for delinquent taxes in the same manner as personal property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(6)(a): If any interest in state lands is sold for delinquent taxes, the officer making the sale shall issue a certificate of sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1103(6)(b): When filed with the state agency from which the interest was purchased, the certificate or certified copy operates as an assignment of the interest of the original purchaser or assignee to the purchaser at the tax sale.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106 Exemption of property owned by blind persons or their unmarried surviving spouses or minor orphans -- Amount -- Application -- County authority to make refunds.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(1): (2); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(1)(a): (2); (3) Subject to Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(1)(a)(i): a blind person;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(1)(a)(ii): the unmarried surviving spouse of a blind person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(1)(a)(iii): a minor orphan of a blind person.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(1)(b): If the claimant is the grantor of a trust holding title to real or tangible personal property on which an exemption is claimed, the claimant may claim the portion of the exemption under this section and be treated as the owner of that portion of the property held in trust for which the claimant proves to the satisfaction of the county that:

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(2)(b): (2)(a) A county may extend the deadline for filing under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(3)(a): has no more than 20/200 visual acuity in the better eye when corrected; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(3)(b): has, in the case of better than 20/200 central vision, a restriction of the field of vision in the better eye which subtends an angle of vision no greater than 20 degrees.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(4): (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(4)(a): (4) For purposes of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(4)(a)(i): "Property taxes due" means the taxes due on a person's property:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(4)(a)(i)(A): for which an exemption is granted by a county under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(4)(a)(i)(B): for the calendar year for which the exemption is granted.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(4)(a)(ii): "Property taxes paid" is an amount equal to the sum of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(4)(a)(ii)(A): the amount of the property taxes the person paid for the taxable year for which the person is applying for the exemption; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(4)(a)(ii)(B): the amount of tax the county exempts under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1106(4)(b): A county granting an exemption to a person under this section shall refund to that person an amount equal to the amount by which the person's property taxes paid exceed the person's property taxes due, if that amount is $1 or more.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1110 Exemption of property used to furnish power for irrigation purposes -- Computation of power used for irrigation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1110(1): Power plants, power transmission lines, and other property used for generating and delivering electrical power, a portion of which is used for furnishing power for pumping water for irrigation purposes on lands in this state, are exempt from taxation, subject to the conditions of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1110(2): (1) For purposes of the exemption under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1110(2)(a): the total amount of electric power distributed by each distributor for all purposes within this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1110(2)(b): the total amount of electric power distributed by each distributor which was used exclusively for pumping water for the irrigation of lands within this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1110(3): The commission shall exempt from the total property assessment on all properties assessed within this state used for generating and distributing electrical power, that portion which the total amount of electric power used exclusively for pumping water for irrigation purposes bears to the total amount of electric power distributed within this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1110(4): The total amount of tax exempted shall be prorated among the distributors.  The distributors shall prorate the benefits among the users according to the amount of power used for pumping water for irrigation purposes by each user.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1110(5): The commission may adopt and enforce all rules necessary to determine the exemption and prorate the benefits provided in this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111 Exemption of property used for irrigation purposes -- Exemption of a nonprofit entity's property used for water purposes.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(1): Water rights, ditches, canals, reservoirs, power plants, pumping plants, transmission lines, pipes, and flumes owned and used by individuals or corporations for irrigating land within the state owned by those individuals or corporations, or by the individual members of the corporation, are exempt from taxation to the extent that they are owned and used for irrigation purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2): (2); (2)(b)(ii); (2)(b)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2)(a): (2) As used in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2)(a)(i): "Domestic water" means water used for a residential or commercial application, including the outdoor watering of vegetation.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2)(a)(ii): "Other water infrastructure" means property, other than a reservoir, pumping plant, ditch, canal, pipe, or flume, whose use is physically necessary in the production, treatment, storage, or distribution of water.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2)(b): If owned by a nonprofit entity and used within the state to irrigate land, provide domestic water, or provide water to a public water supplier, the following are exempt from taxation:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2)(b)(i): a water right;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2)(b)(ii): a reservoir, pumping plant, ditch, canal, pipe, and flume; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2)(b)(iii): other water infrastructure.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2)(c): (2)(b)(ii) Land occupied by a reservoir, ditch, canal, or pipe that is exempt under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2)(d): (2)(b)(ii) Land immediately adjacent to a reservoir, ditch, canal, or pipe that is exempt under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2)(d)(i): owned by the nonprofit entity that owns the adjacent reservoir, ditch, canal, or pipe; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1111(2)(d)(ii): reasonably necessary for the maintenance or for otherwise supporting the operation of the reservoir, ditch, canal, or pipe.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1112 Livestock exemption.
----------------------------------------------------
Livestock in Utah, as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1113 Exemption of household furnishings.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Household furnishings, furniture, and equipment used exclusively by the owner at the owner's place of abode in maintaining a home for the owner and the owner's family are exempt from property taxation.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114 Exemption of inventory or other tangible personal property held for sale.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(1): Tangible personal property present in Utah on the assessment date, at noon, held for sale in the ordinary course of business or for shipping to a final out-of-state destination within 12 months and which constitutes the inventory of any retailer, wholesaler, distributor, processor, warehouseman, manufacturer, producer, gatherer, transporter, storage provider, farmer, or livestock raiser, is exempt from property taxation.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(2): This exemption does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(2)(a): inventory which is not otherwise subject to personal property taxation;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(2)(b): mines;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(2)(c): natural deposits; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(2)(d): a manufactured home or mobile home which is sited at a location where occupancy could take place.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3): (3)(a)(ii) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3)(a): (3)(a)(ii) "Assessment date" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3)(a)(i): (3)(a)(ii) for tangible personal property and vehicles other than vehicles described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3)(a)(ii): for vehicles brought into Utah from out-of-state, the date the vehicles are brought into Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3)(b): "Inventory" means all items of tangible personal property described as materials, containers, goods in process, finished goods, severed minerals, and other personal property owned by or in possession of the person claiming the exemption.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3)(c)(i): "Mine" means a natural deposit of either metalliferous or nonmetalliferous valuable mineral.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3)(c)(ii): "Mine" does not mean a severed mineral.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3)(d): "Natural deposit" means a metalliferous or nonmetalliferous mineral located at or below ground level that has not been severed or extracted from its natural state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3)(e): "Severed mineral" means any mineral that has been previously severed or extracted from a natural deposit including severed or extracted minerals that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3)(e)(i): are stored above, below, or within the ground; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(3)(e)(ii): are ultimately recoverable for future sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1114(4): The commission may adopt rules to implement the inventory exemption.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1115 Exemption of certain tangible personal property.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1115(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 41-1a-102; 41-1a-102 As used in this section:

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1115(1)(a)(i): "Item of taxable tangible personal property" does not include an improvement to real property or a part that will become an improvement.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1115(1)(a)(ii): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1115(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1115(1)(b)(i): "Supply" means taxable tangible personal property that is:

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1115(1)(b)(i)(B): either carried on hand and for which no record of consumption is taken in ordinary business or typically used up within the calendar year; and
