Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1330(11)(b)(ii): with:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1330(11)(b)(ii)(A): an authorized officer of a taxing entity for a tax imposed by a taxing entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1330(11)(b)(ii)(B): an authorized officer of the state for a tax imposed by the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331 Property tax due date -- Date tax is delinquent -- Penalty -- Interest -- Payments -- Refund of prepayment.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(1): 59-2-1332; 59-2-1332; 59-2-1332
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(1)(a): 59-2-1332 Except as provided in Subsection (1)(b) and subject to Subsections (1)(c) and (d), all property taxes, unless otherwise specifically provided for under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(1)(b): 59-2-1332; 59-2-1332 If November 30 falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or holiday:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(1)(b)(i): 59-2-1332 the date of the next following day that is not a Saturday, Sunday, or holiday shall be substituted in Subsection (1)(a) and Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(1)(b)(ii): 59-2-1332 the date of the day occurring 30 days after the date under Subsection (1)(b)(i) shall be substituted in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(1)(c): If a property tax is paid or postmarked after the due date described in this Subsection (1) the property tax is delinquent.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(1)(d): A county treasurer or other public official, public entity, or public employee may not require the payment of a property tax before the due date described in this Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2): 59-2-1802.1
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsections (2)(e), (f), and (g)(i), for each parcel, all delinquent taxes and tax notice charges on each separately assessed parcel are subject to a penalty of 2.5% of the amount of the delinquent taxes and tax notice charges or $10, whichever is greater.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(b): Unless the delinquent taxes and tax notice charges, together with the penalty, are paid on or before January 31, the amount of taxes and tax notice charges and penalty shall bear interest on a per annum basis from the January 1 immediately following the delinquency date.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(c): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(d), for purposes of Subsection (2)(b), the interest rate is equal to the sum of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(c)(i): 6%; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(c)(ii): the federal funds rate target:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(c)(ii)(A): established by the Federal Open Markets Committee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(c)(ii)(B): that exists on the January 1 immediately following the date of delinquency.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(d): The interest rate described in Subsection (2)(c) may not be:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(d)(i): less than 7%; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(d)(ii): more than 10%.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(e): The penalty described in Subsection (2)(a) is 1% of the amount of the delinquent taxes and tax notice charges or $10, whichever is greater, if all delinquent taxes, all tax notice charges, and the penalty are paid on or before the January 31 immediately following the delinquency date.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(f): This section does not apply to the costs, charges, and interest rate accruing on any tax notice charge related to an assessment assessed in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(f)(i): Title 11, Chapter 42, Assessment Area Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(f)(ii): Title 11, Chapter 42a, Commercial Property Assessed Clean Energy Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(g): 59-2-1802.1
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(g)(i): 59-2-1802.1 The county shall waive any penalty or interest for a property granted a deferral in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(2)(g)(ii): Penalties and interest accrue in accordance with this Subsection (2) on any tax or tax notice charge that is delinquent after the deferral period ends.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(3)(a): If the delinquency exceeds one year, the amount of taxes, tax notice charges, and penalties for that year and all succeeding years shall bear interest until settled in full through redemption or tax sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(3)(b): The interest rate to be applied shall be calculated for each year as established under Subsection (2) and shall apply on each individual year's delinquency until paid.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(4): The county treasurer may accept and credit on account against taxes and tax notice charges becoming due during the current year, at any time before or after the tax rates are adopted, but not subsequent to the date of delinquency, either:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(4)(a): payments in amounts of not less than $10; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(4)(b): the full amount of the unpaid tax and tax notice charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(5): 59-2-1317
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(5)(a): 59-2-1317 At any time before the county treasurer provides the tax notice described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1331(5)(b): Upon recommendation by the county treasurer, the county legislative body shall adopt rules or ordinances to implement the provisions of this Subsection (5).

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1332 Extension of date of delinquency.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1332(1): (1)(a); 45-1-101
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1332(1)(a): The county legislative body may, upon a petition of not less than 100 taxpayers or upon its own motion for good cause, by proclamation, extend the property tax due date from November 30 to noon on December 30.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1333 Errors or omissions -- In assessment book -- Authority to correct.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An omission, error, defect in form in the assessment roll, or clerical error, when it can be ascertained what was intended, may, with the consent of the county legislative body, be supplied or corrected by the assessor at any time before the sale for delinquent taxes or tax notice charges and after the original assessment or tax notice charge listing was made.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1334 Omission, error, or defect in delinquent lists -- Republication.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1334(1): If an omission, error, or defect is in a delinquent list or any publication, the list or publication may be republished as amended, or notice of the correction may be given in a supplementary publication.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1334(2): Any republication shall be made in the same manner as the original publication, for not less than one week.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1335 Abbreviations permitted in proceedings.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1335(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1335(1)(a): In all proceedings relating to assessment, levy, or collection of taxes or relating to the listing or collection of tax notice charges, the subjection of any property to a charge for taxes of any nature or for tax notice charges, or the advertisement and sale of any property for taxes or tax notice charges, the following initial letters, abbreviations, symbols, and figures may be used.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1335(1)(b): The meaning of the initial letters, abbreviations, symbols, and figures is shown by the word or words placed opposite the initial letters, abbreviations, symbols, and figures:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1335(2): Where the name of any railroad or railroad company is commonly referred to by the initial letters of the word constituting the name of the railroad, the initial letters may be used as an abbreviation for the full name of the railroad or railroad company in all cases where the name is used in the description of property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1335(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1335(3)(a): Commonly accepted initial letters, abbreviations, symbols, and figures having local significance may be used.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1335(3)(b): Any initial letters, abbreviations, symbols, and figures shall first be approved by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1335(3)(c): A written or printed explanation of initial letters, abbreviations, symbols, and figures shall appear in each assessment roll in which they are used and shall be published with each separate advertisement and sale for taxes or tax notice charges in which they are used.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1337 Pro rata application of ad valorem tax on property taken by eminent domain or by right of entry agreement.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If any property is taken in fee by the state, any of its subdivisions or agencies, or by any private person, or other body pursuant to either:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1337(1): an exercise of the power of eminent domain; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1337(2): by a right of entry agreement executed by reason of the threat or imminence of eminent domain, the ad valorem property tax assessed and collected on the property under this chapter shall be determined on the basis of the relationship which the number of months the property was held by the property owner, prior to the granting by the court of an order of occupancy or the execution of a right of entry agreement, bears to the taxable year.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1338 Record of delinquent taxes -- Contents of record.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1338(1): The treasurer shall prepare the official record of delinquent taxes and tax notice charges in the same order as property appears on the assessment rolls.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1338(2): The record shall show:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1338(2)(a): the name of the person to whom the property is assessed;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1338(2)(b): the description of the delinquent parcel, and a reference to the parcel, serial, or account number under which the property was listed in the assessment roll;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1338(2)(c): the amount of delinquent taxes and tax notice charges, penalties, and administrative costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1338(2)(d): the date of redemption and by whom the property is redeemed.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1338(3): The record shall also provide space for entering delinquent taxes assessed and tax notice charges listed in subsequent years against each parcel which remains unredeemed.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1338(4): Taxes levied only on a certain kind or class of property for a special purpose and tax notice charges shall be separately set out.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1339 Form of treasurer's certificate -- Contents of form.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I, ____, county treasurer of the county of ____, state of Utah, do certify that to the best of my knowledge the attached record is a full, true, and correct record and constitutes the official record of all properties which became delinquent for the year ____, and shows in the same order as the property appears on the assessment roll, the name of the person to whom the property is assessed, the description of the delinquent parcel and a reference to the parcel, serial, or account number under which the property was listed in the assessment roll, the amount of taxes, tax notice charges, penalties, administrative costs, the date of redemption, and by whom the property was redeemed if any redemption has been made.Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1339(1): On or before March 15 the treasurer shall complete the official record of delinquent taxes and tax notice charges and attach the treasurer's certificate to the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1339(2): The certificate shall be substantially in the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1339(3): The official record shall be maintained in the treasurer's office and shall include any subsequent delinquent taxes, tax notice charges, penalties, administrative costs, and redemptions pertaining to the properties listed thereon.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1342 Assessment and sale of property after attachment of county tax lien and tax notice charges.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1342(1): Property against which a property tax delinquency exists shall be assessed in subsequent years for taxes in the same manner as if no delinquency existed.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1342(2): Property against which a delinquency exists for tax notice charges may still accrue tax notice charges as if no delinquency existed.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1342(3): 59-2-1351.1 The rights of any person purchasing the property from the county at tax sale provided under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1343 Tax sale listing.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1343(1): 59-2-1802.1
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1343(1)(a): If any property is not redeemed by March 15 following the lapse of four years from the date when  any item in Subsection (1)(b)  became delinquent, the county treasurer shall immediately file a listing with the county auditor of all properties whose redemption period is expiring in the nearest forthcoming tax sale to pay all outstanding property taxes and tax notice charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1343(1)(b): Except as provided in Subsection (1)(c), a delinquency of any of the following triggers the tax sale process described in Subsection (1)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1343(1)(b)(i): property tax; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1343(1)(b)(ii): a tax notice charge.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1343(1)(c): 59-2-1802.1 A property tax or a tax notice charge that is deferred in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1343(2): The listing is known as the "tax sale listing."


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1345 Daily statement of accounts -- Audits.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1345(1): Between March 15 and the date of the tax sale, the county treasurer shall transmit daily to the county auditor a statement of the amount of money received by the treasurer during the preceding business day on account of redemptions made on property listed for tax sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1345(2): (1) The statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1345(2)(a): the number of the redemption certificate or the receipt issued on account for redemption;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1345(2)(b): the amount received for taxes, tax notice charges, penalties, and administrative costs accrued to the date of the making of the tax sale record;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1345(2)(c): the amount received for administrative costs subsequently accruing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1345(2)(d): the amount received as interest accrued.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1345(3): The county auditor shall audit the treasurer's tax sale records at least once a year and the treasurer shall account to the auditor for all money due the county by reason of any redemptions or payments on account for redemption made, including interest as required by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1345(4): 59-2-1343 Before the tax sale listing under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346 Redemption -- Time allowed.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(1): 59-2-1351 Property may be redeemed on behalf of the record owner by any person at any time before the tax sale which shall be held in May or June as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(2): A person may redeem property by paying to the county treasurer all delinquent taxes, tax notice charges, interest, penalties, and administrative costs that have accrued on the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(3): (3)(d); (3)(b); (3)(a); (3)(b)(ii); (3)(b)(i); (3)(b)(i); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(3)(a): (3)(d); (3)(b) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(3)(b): (3)(a); (3)(b)(ii) The county treasurer shall calculate the amount described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(3)(b)(i): (3)(b)(ii) the amount of the value of the base parcel as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(3)(b)(ii): the value of the base parcel as it existed on January 1 of the year in which the delinquent property taxes on the base parcel were assessed or tax notice charges on the base parcel were listed.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(3)(c): (3)(b)(i); (3)(b)(i) If the county treasurer does not have sufficient information to calculate the amount described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(3)(d): (3) A person may redeem a subdivided lot under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4): (4)(c); Title 63A, Chapter 3, Part 3, Accounts Receivable Collection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(a): At any time before the expiration of the period of redemption, the county treasurer shall accept and credit on account for the redemption of property, payments in amounts of not less than $10, except for the final payment, which may be in any amount.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(b): (4)(c) For the purpose of computing the amount required for redemption and for the purpose of distributing the payments received on account, all payments, except payments described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(b)(i): against the interest and administrative costs accrued on the delinquent tax for the last year included in the delinquent account at the time of payment;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(b)(ii): against the penalty charged on the delinquent tax for the last year included in the delinquent account at the time of payment;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(b)(iii): against the delinquent tax for the last year included in the delinquent account at the time of payment;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(b)(iv): against the interest and administrative costs accrued on the delinquent tax for the next to last year included in the delinquent account at the time of payment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(b)(v): so on until the full amount of the delinquent taxes, tax notice charges, penalties, administrative costs, and interest on the unpaid balances are paid within the period of redemption.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(c): Title 63A, Chapter 3, Part 3, Accounts Receivable Collection For a payment received through a levy on an income tax overpayment or refund in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(c)(i): against the penalty charged on the delinquent tax for the earliest year included in the delinquent account at the time of payment;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(c)(ii): against the interest and administrative costs accrued on the delinquent tax for the earliest year included in the delinquent account at the time of payment;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(c)(iii): against the delinquent tax for the earliest year included in the delinquent account at the time of payment;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(c)(iv): against the penalty charged on the delinquent tax for the next earliest year included in the delinquent account at the time of payment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(c)(v): so on until:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(c)(v)(A): the full amount of the delinquent taxes, tax notice charges, penalties, administrative costs, and interest on the unpaid balances are paid; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1346(4)(c)(v)(B): the amount of the income tax overpayment or refund is exhausted.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347 Redemption -- Adjustment or deferral of taxes -- Interest.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(1)(a): If an interested person applies to a county legislative body for an adjustment or deferral of taxes levied against property  located in the county, the county legislative body may accept a sum less than the full amount due, or defer the full amount due, where, in the judgment of the county legislative body, the best human interests and the interests of the state and the county are served.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(1)(b): Nothing in this section prohibits a county legislative body from granting a retroactive adjustment or deferral if the criteria established in this section are met.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(2)(a): (1) In an application for an adjustment or deferral described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(2)(a)(i): a description of the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(2)(a)(ii): the value of the property for the current year;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(2)(a)(iii): the amount of delinquent taxes, interest, and penalties;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(2)(a)(iv): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(2)(a)(iv)(A): for an adjustment, the amount proposed to be paid; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(2)(a)(iv)(B): for a deferral, the amount proposed to be deferred; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(2)(a)(v): any other information required by the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(2)(b): The commission shall prepare blank forms for an application for an adjustment or deferral under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(3)(a): A county legislative body may not grant a deferral without the written consent of the holder of any mortgage or trust deed outstanding on the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(3)(b): Any amount deferred shall be recorded as a lien on the property and shall bear interest at a rate equal to the lesser of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(3)(b)(i): 6%; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(3)(b)(ii): the federal funds rate target:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(3)(b)(ii)(A): established by the Federal Open Markets Committee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(3)(b)(ii)(B): that exists on the January 1 immediately preceding the day on which the taxes are deferred.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(3)(c): The amount deferred together with accrued interest is due and payable when the property is sold or otherwise conveyed.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(4): Within 10 days after the day on which a county legislative body grants an adjustment or deferral, the county legislative body shall cause the adjustment or deferral to be posted in the county where the property involved is located.  The publication shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(4)(a): the name of the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(4)(b): the parcel, serial, or account number of the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(4)(c): the value of the property for the current year;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(4)(d): the sum of the delinquent taxes, interest, and penalty due; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(4)(e): the adjusted amount paid or deferred.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1347(5): No later than the last day of each calendar month, each county legislative body shall send to the commission a record of any action taken by the county legislative body under this section during the preceding calendar month.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1348 Certificate of redemption.
----------------------------------------------------------
If any property is redeemed, the county treasurer shall make the proper entry in the record of tax sales filed in the treasurer's office and issue a certificate of redemption, which is prima facie evidence of the redemption, and may be recorded in the office of the county recorder without acknowledgment.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1349 Co-owners -- Procedures for redemption.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
If two or more persons own an undivided interest in property on which a tax or tax notice charge delinquency exists, any owner may redeem the owner's interest in the property upon payment of that portion of the taxes, tax notice charges, interest, penalties, and administrative costs which the owner's interest bears to the whole, as determined by the county legislative body.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1350 Land irregularly or erroneously assessed not to be sold.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1350(1): If the county auditor discovers before the tax sale that because of an irregular or erroneous assessment any property should not be sold, the auditor may not sell the property, and the county legislative body shall cause the tax records to reflect the correction in the next succeeding year, on the basis of the value and rates of the year for which it was erroneously assessed, to be collected as other taxes are collected.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1350(2): If the county auditor, subject to approval by the county legislative body, issues a written finding that it may be in the best interest of the public to withdraw a property from the tax sale, the county auditor may withdraw the property from the sale.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351 Sales by county -- Notice of tax sale -- Entries on record.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1): (2); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1)(a): Upon receiving the tax sale listing from the county treasurer, the county auditor shall select a date for the tax sale for all real property:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1)(a)(i): on which a tax or tax notice charge delinquency exists;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1)(a)(ii): that was not previously redeemed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1)(a)(iii): upon which the period of redemption is expiring in the nearest tax sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1)(b): The county auditor shall conduct the tax sale in May or June of the current year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1)(c): (2); (3) The tax sale may occur:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1)(c)(i): at the front door of the county courthouse in the county where the real property is located; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1)(c)(ii): (2); (3) through an electronic process if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1)(c)(ii)(A): the tax sale occurs in the same format as a tax sale would occur at the front door of the county courthouse except that participation is through an electronic means;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1)(c)(ii)(B): members of the public are able to observe and participate, including making bids and payment arrangements, in the tax sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(1)(c)(ii)(C): (2); (3) the county auditor includes information about how the public may access the tax sale through the electronic process with the description of the place of the tax sale in the notice provided in accordance with Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(2): The county auditor shall provide notice of the tax sale by sending notice by certified and first class mail, or by first class mail and another shipping service that includes tracking and delivery confirmation, to the last known address of each of the following persons:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(2)(a): the last known recorded owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(2)(b): the occupant of any improved property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(2)(c): other interests of record as of the preceding March 15.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(3)(a)(i): publishing notice on the county auditor's website, or if the county auditor does not have a separate website from the county, on the county's website, at least four weeks before the date of sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(3)(a)(ii): (3)(a)(i) advertising the date of the tax sale and the web address for the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(3)(b): 45-1-101 a county auditor in a county of the second, third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class shall provide notice by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(3)(b)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(3)(b)(i)(A): publishing notice four times in a newspaper published and having general circulation in the county, once in each of the four successive weeks immediately preceding the date of sale; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(3)(b)(i)(B): if no newspaper is published in the county, posting in five public places in the county, as determined by the county auditor, at least 25 but no more than 30 days before the date of sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351(3)(b)(ii): 45-1-101 publishing notice in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1 Tax sale -- Combining certain parcels -- Acceptable bids -- Deeds.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This conveyance is made in consideration of payment by the grantee of $____, representing the total amount owing for delinquent taxes, delinquent tax notice charges, penalties, interest, and administrative costs constituting a charge against the real property for nonpayment of general taxes assessed against it for the years ____ through ____ in the sum of $____.Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(1)(a): At the time specified in the notice the auditor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(1)(a)(i): attend at the place appointed, offer for sale, and sell all real property for which an acceptable bid is made; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(1)(a)(ii): refuse to offer a parcel of real property for sale if the description of the real property is so defective as to convey no title.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(1)(b): The auditor may post at the place of sale a copy of the published list of real property to be offered and cry the sale by reference to the list rather than crying each parcel separately.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(2)(a): The tax commission shall establish, by rule, minimum procedural standards applicable to tax sales.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(2)(b): For matters not addressed by commission rules, the county legislative body, upon recommendation by the county auditor, shall establish procedures, by ordinance, for the sale of the delinquent property that best protect the financial interest of the delinquent property owner and meet the needs of local governments to collect delinquent property taxes and tax notice charges due.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(3): The county governing body may authorize the auditor to combine for sale two or more contiguous parcels owned by the same party when:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(3)(a): the parcels are a single economic or functional unit;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(3)(b): the combined sale will best protect the financial interests of the delinquent property owner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(3)(c): separate sales will reduce the economic value of the unit.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(4): The governing body may accept any of the following bids:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(4)(a): the highest bid amount for the entire parcel of property, however, a bid may not be accepted for an amount which is insufficient to pay the taxes, tax notice charges, penalties, interest, and administrative costs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(4)(b): a bid in an amount sufficient to pay the taxes, tax notice charges, penalties, interest, and administrative costs, for less than the entire parcel.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(4)(b)(i): The bid which shall be accepted shall be the bid of the bidder who will pay in cash the full amount of the taxes, tax notice charges, penalties, interest, and administrative costs for the smallest portion of the entire parcel.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(4)(b)(ii): The county auditor at the tax sale or the county legislative body following the tax sale shall reject a bid to purchase a strip of property around the entire perimeter of the parcel, or a bid to purchase a strip of the parcel which would prevent access to the remainder of the parcel by the redemptive owner or otherwise unreasonably diminish the value of that remainder.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(4)(b)(iii): If the bid accepted is for less than the entire parcel, the auditor shall note the fact, with a description of the property covered by the bid, upon the tax sale record and the balance of the parcel not affected by the bid shall be considered to have been redeemed by the owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(5): The county legislative body may decide that none of the bids are acceptable.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(6)(a): Once the county auditor has closed the sale of a particular parcel of property as a result of accepting a bid on the parcel, the successful bidder or purchaser of the property may not unilaterally rescind the bid.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(6)(b): The county legislative body, after acceptance of a bid, may enforce the terms of the bid by obtaining a legal judgment against the purchaser in the amount of the bid, plus interest and attorney's fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(7): Title 67, Chapter 4a, Revised Uniform Unclaimed Property Act Any sale funds which are in excess of the amount required to satisfy the delinquent taxes, tax notice charges, penalties, interest, and administrative costs of the delinquent property shall be treated as unclaimed property under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(8): 59-2-1366 All money received upon the sale of property made under this section shall be paid into the county treasury, and the treasurer shall settle with the taxing entities and tax notice charge entities as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(9)(a): The county auditor shall, after acceptance by the county governing body, and in the name of the county, execute deeds conveying in fee simple all property sold at the public sale to the purchaser and attest this with the auditor's seal.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(9)(b): Deeds issued by the county auditor under this section shall recite the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(9)(b)(i): the total amount of all the delinquent taxes, tax notice charges, penalties, interest, and administrative costs which were paid in for the execution and delivery of the deed;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(9)(b)(ii): the year for which the property was assessed or a tax notice charge was listed, the year the property became delinquent, and the year the property was subject to tax sale;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(9)(b)(iii): a full description of the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(9)(b)(iv): the name of the grantee.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(9)(c): When the deed is executed and delivered by the auditor, it shall be prima facie evidence of the regularity of all proceedings subsequent to the date the taxes or tax notice charges initially became delinquent and of the conveyance of the property to the grantee in fee simple.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(9)(d): The deed issued by the county auditor under this section shall be recorded by the county recorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(9)(e): The fee for the recording shall be included in the administrative costs of the sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.1(9)(f): The deed shall be substantially in the following form:


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.3 No purchaser at tax sale -- Property struck off to county.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.3(1): 59-2-1338 Any property offered for sale for which there is no purchaser shall be struck off to the county by the county auditor, who shall then:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.3(1)(a): publicly declare substantially as follows: "All property here offered for sale which has not been struck off to a private purchaser is hereby struck off and sold to the county of ____ (naming the county), and I hereby declare the fee simple title of the property to be vested in the county";
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.3(1)(b): 59-2-1338 make an endorsement opposite each of the entries in the delinquency tax sale record described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.3(1)(c): sign the auditor's name to the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.3(2): The fee simple title to the property shall then vest in the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.3(3): (1) After following the procedures in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.3(4): The recorder shall make the necessary entries in the index, abstract record, and plat book showing the conveyance of all property sold and conveyed to the county pursuant to this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5 Disposition of property struck off to county.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(1): 59-2-1366; Title 67, Chapter 4a, Revised Uniform Unclaimed Property Act
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(1)(a): All property acquired by the county under this part may be disposed of for a price and upon terms determined by the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(1)(b): If property is sold under a contract of sale and title remains in the county, the equity of the purchaser shall be subject to taxation as other taxable property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(1)(c): The county clerk may execute deeds for all property sold under this subsection in the name of the county and attest the same by seal, vesting in the purchaser all of the title of all taxing entities in the real estate so sold.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(1)(d): 59-2-1366; Title 67, Chapter 4a, Revised Uniform Unclaimed Property Act
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(1)(d)(i): Money received from the sale of property under this section shall first be applied to the cost of administering and supervising the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(1)(d)(ii): Any remaining money shall be apportioned to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(1)(d)(ii)(A): state and other taxing entities with an interest in the taxes last levied upon the property in proportion to their respective interests in the taxes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(1)(d)(ii)(B): tax notice charge entities in proportion to the entities' respective tax notice charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(1)(d)(iii): 59-2-1366 The treasurer shall settle with the taxing entities and tax notice charge entities on funds remaining as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(1)(d)(iv): Title 67, Chapter 4a, Revised Uniform Unclaimed Property Act Money in excess of claims under this subsection shall be paid to the state treasurer and treated as unclaimed property under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(2)(a): The county legislative body may rent or lease any property held in the name of the county any time after the tax sale for a price and upon terms determined by the governing body.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(2)(b): Lands leased may be sold at the discretion of the county executive, with the approval of the county legislative body, during the term of the lease, but any sale shall be made subject to the lease.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(2)(c): The county executive, with the approval of the county legislative body, may enter into leasehold terms for asphalt, oil, or gas that the county considers to be in the best interest of the county as long as:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(2)(c)(i): the mineral, asphalt, oil, or gas is produced from, or attributable to, the property leased; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(2)(c)(ii): each lease for oil and gas reserves a royalty of not less than 12-1/2%.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(2)(d): If considered to be in the best interests of the county, the county executive may:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(2)(d)(i): enter into agreements for the pooling or unitizing of acreage with others for unit operations for the production of oil or gas, or both, and for the apportionment of oil or gas royalties, or both, on an acreage or other equitable basis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(2)(d)(ii): with the consent of its lessee, change any and all terms of leases issued by it to facilitate the efficient and economic production of oil and gas from the property under its jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(2)(e): All leases for mineral, asphalt, or oil and gas already entered into by county governing bodies are ratified.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(3): 59-2-1366; Title 67, Chapter 4a, Revised Uniform Unclaimed Property Act
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(3)(a): Money received as rents from the rental or leasing of property held in the name of the county shall first be applied to the cost of administering and supervising the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(3)(b): Any remaining money shall be apportioned to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(3)(b)(i): state and other taxing entities with an interest in the taxes last levied upon the property in proportion to their respective interests in the taxes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(3)(b)(ii): tax notice charge entities in proportion to the entities' respective tax notice charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(3)(c): 59-2-1366 The treasurer shall settle with the taxing entities and tax notice charge entities on funds remaining as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.5(3)(d): Title 67, Chapter 4a, Revised Uniform Unclaimed Property Act Money in excess of these claims shall be paid to the state treasurer and treated as unclaimed property under


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.7 Partial interest tax sales.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.7(1): 59-2-1351.1; 59-2-1351.1 For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.7(1)(a): 59-2-1351.1 "Tax sale interest purchaser" means an owner of an undivided interest in a parcel of tax sale property that bid for and purchased the undivided interest:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.7(1)(a)(i): 59-2-1351.1 at a tax sale in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.7(1)(a)(ii): on or after July 1, 2007; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.7(1)(a)(iii): if the undivided interest in the tax sale property equals 49% or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.7(1)(b): 59-2-1351.1 "Tax sale property" means a parcel of real property that was sold in part as an undivided interest at a tax sale in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.7(2): If a parcel of tax sale property is sold, a tax sale interest purchaser may only receive from the sale of the tax sale property, an amount equal to the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.7(2)(a): the amount the tax sale interest purchaser paid for the undivided interest in the tax sale property at the tax sale plus 12% interest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.7(2)(b): the tax sale interest purchaser's pro rata share of the sale price of the tax sale property based on the percentage of the undivided interest the tax sale interest purchaser holds in the tax sale property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1351.7(3): (2) A tax sale interest purchaser may not object to the sale of the tax sale property if the tax sale interest purchaser receives an amount in accordance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1352 Purchaser of invalid tax title -- Purchaser's lien -- Extent of lien -- Priority of lien -- Foreclosure of lien.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1352(1): Every person who has purchased or purchases any invalid tax title to any real property in this state shall, from the effective date of this part, have a lien against the property for the recovery of the amount of the purchase price paid to the county to the extent that the county would have a lien prior to the sale by the county, but in no event may the lien be greater than the amount of taxes, tax notice charges, interest, and penalties, or the amount actually paid, whichever is smaller.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1352(2): Taxes and tax notice charges paid by the purchaser for subsequent years after the purchase from the county shall be included in the amount secured by the lien which has not already been recovered.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1352(3): The lien shall have the same priority against the property as the lien for the delinquent taxes and tax notice charges which were liquidated by the purchase except that it may not have preference over any right, title, interest in, or lien against, the property acquired since the purchase of the tax title for value and without notice, and the lien shall bear interest at the legal rate for a period of not to exceed four years.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1352(4): The lien shall be foreclosed in any action in which the invalidity of the tax title is determined.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1352(5): If the lien is not foreclosed at the time of the determination of the invalidity of the tax title, any later action to foreclose the lien shall be barred.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1353 Foreclosure of lien claimed by county -- Time -- Venue -- Parties -- Pleading.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1353(1): In all cases where any county claims a lien on real estate for delinquent general taxes or tax notice charges which have not been paid for a period of four years, the county may foreclose the lien by an action in the district court of the county in which the real estate is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1353(2): In this action all persons owning, having, or claiming an interest in or lien upon the real estate or any part of the real estate may be joined as defendants, and the complaint shall contain a description of the property, together with the amount claimed to be due on the property, including interest, penalties, and administrative costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1353(3): If the name of the owner of any real estate cannot be ascertained from the records of the county, the complaint shall state that the owner is unknown to the plaintiff.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1353(4): It is sufficient to allege in the complaint that a general tax has been duly levied upon or a tax notice charge has been listed for the described real estate, without stating any of the proceedings or steps leading up to the levy of the tax or the listing of the tax notice charge.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1354 Notice of intention to foreclose -- Service of notice.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Before the commencement of any action, 30 days' written notice of intention to do so shall be given to the owner, if known, by enclosing the notice in an envelope plainly addressed to the owner at the owner's post office address, as shown on the last assessment roll of the county in which the real estate is located, postage prepaid.  If the post office address of any owner does not appear on the assessment roll, notice shall be addressed to the owner at the general delivery at the post office in the city, town, or precinct where the real estate is located, postage prepaid.  Service of the notice is complete when deposited in the United States mail.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1355 Trial -- Findings -- Decree.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1355(1): 59-2-1353 The action described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1355(2): The court shall also in its decree direct the sheriff to advertise and sell, as in the case of sales on execution, each parcel of property, or so much as may be necessary for the payment of the total amount of the general taxes and tax notice charges due, with interest, penalties, and costs, unless the amount is paid within a time named in the decree, but not to exceed 30 days from the entry of the decree.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1355(3): The decree shall provide that any of the parties to the action may become purchasers at any sale, that if less than an entire parcel of property is sold, it shall be sold at foreclosure sale in such a manner as not to convey to the purchaser a strip of property around the entire perimeter of the parcel, or a strip of the parcel which, if conveyed, would prevent access to the remainder of the parcel by the redemptive owner or otherwise unreasonably diminish the value of that remainder, as determined by the county executive.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1355(4): The decree shall also provide that if all delinquent taxes and tax notice charges, together with interest, respectively levied on or listed for the parcel of property, and all penalties and costs, are paid within the time fixed in the decree for payment, then no sale may be made.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1355(5): After the time for redemption has expired, if no redemption has been made, the sheriff shall execute and deliver to the purchaser a deed conveying to the purchaser all the right, title, and interest of each and all the parties, but subject to the lien of any general or special taxes or tax notice charges which may have been respectively levied on or listed for the property conveyed, other than those for the payment of which the sale has been made.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1356 Sale -- Certificate of sale to be issued.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
If any foreclosure sale is made, the sheriff shall give to the purchaser a certificate of sale as in the case of sales upon execution, and shall file a duplicate of the certificate with the county recorder and county auditor. Where any property has been purchased by the county at any foreclosure sale, the certificate of sale may be sold and assigned by it to any person upon payment of a sum not less than the amount for which it was sold to the county, together with interest.  The assignee acquires all the rights of the county in the property.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1357 Redemption at foreclosure sale.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Any person interested in any real estate sold at foreclosure sale under any decree has the same right to redeem the real estate from the sale, within the same time and upon the same terms as if the sale had been made upon execution.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1358 Foreclosure deemed a cumulative remedy.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
The foreclosure may not deprive any county of any other method or means provided for the collection or enforcement of any taxes or tax notice charges, but is construed as providing an additional or cumulative remedy for the collection of general taxes levied and assessed and tax notice charges listed against the real estate in the county.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1359 Collection of taxes and tax notice charges -- Removal or destruction of property.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The tax commission may, under the conditions existing in this section, declare the taxes and tax notice charges to be immediately due and payable if it finds:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1359(1): that the owner or lessee of any real property, including improvements, subject to taxation within the state is removing, destroying, or is about to remove or destroy the property to such an extent as to render doubtful the payment of delinquent taxes, tax notice charges, penalty, and interest, if any, and the payment of current taxes and tax notice charges; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1359(2): that the continued operation and extraction of ores and minerals from mine or mining claims, or the method employed by the owner or lessee, contractor, or other person working upon or operating any mine or mining claim will render doubtful the payment of delinquent taxes, tax notice charges, penalty, and interest, if any, for past years or the current year.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1360 Proceedings before commission.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Proceedings to make findings under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361 Notice of findings -- Proceedings in district court -- Injunction -- Determining taxes and tax notice charges due -- Security during proceedings.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(1): 59-2-1359
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(1)(a): 59-2-1359 Notice that the commission has made a finding and declaration under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(1)(b): The notice required by this section shall include a notice of the location and time of the hearing in which the findings of the commission may be protested.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(1)(c)(i): The hearing must be scheduled at least 10 days after the mailing of the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(1)(c)(ii): The owner, lessee, contractor, or operator of the property shall be afforded the opportunity to protest the commission's findings at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(2): After the scheduled hearing, the taxes shall become immediately due and payable if any of the following occur:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(2)(a): the owner, contractor, lessee, or operator of the property fails to appear at the hearing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(2)(b): the commission sustains the findings.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(3): If the taxes and tax notice charges are not paid within 10 days from the date due, the commission may commence a proceeding in court in its name, but for the benefit of the state, the taxing entities interested in the taxes, and the tax notice charge entities for the property, in the district court of the county in which the property is located to determine the liens of the taxes and tax notice charges and to foreclose the liens.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(4): In any proceeding the court may order any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(4)(a): enjoin and restrain the destruction or removal of the property or any part of the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(4)(b): appoint a receiver to operate the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(4)(c): order and direct that the proceeds from the property, or so much of it as may be necessary to pay the amount of the taxes and tax notice charges, be withheld and impounded or paid on account of the taxes and tax notice charges from time to time as the court may direct.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(5): In determining the amount of taxes due for any year for which the levy has not been fixed and for the purposes of the proceeding in court, the commission shall use the levy prevailing within the taxing entity where the property is located for the last preceding year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(6): In any court proceeding brought to enforce the payment of taxes and tax notice charges made due and payable under this section, the findings of the commission shall be for all purposes presumptive evidence of the necessity for the action for the protection of the public revenues and of the amount of taxes and tax notice charges to be paid.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(7)(a): Payment of taxes and tax notice charges due under this section will not be enforced through the proceedings authorized by this section prior to the expiration of the time otherwise allowed for payment of taxes if the owner, lessee, contractor, or other person operating the property furnishes security approved by the commission that the person will timely submit all required returns and payment of taxes and tax notice charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(7)(b): The commission may, from time to time, require additional security for the payment of taxes and tax notice charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1361(8): The commission may promulgate rules to implement this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1362 Certified copy of tax sale record prima facie evidence of regularity.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1362(1): A copy of the record of any tax sale duly certified by the official custodian of the record at the time of the certificate under the seal of office as a true copy of the entry in the official record showing the sale is prima facie evidence of the facts shown in the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1362(2): The regularity of all proceedings connected with the assessment, valuation, notice, equalization, levies, tax notices, advertisement, and sale of property described in the record is presumed, and the burden of showing any irregularity in any of the proceedings resulting in the sale of property for the nonpayment of delinquent taxes and tax notice charges shall be on the person who asserts it.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1363 Misnomer or mistake as to ownership does not affect sale.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If property is sold for correctly imposed taxes and tax notice charges as the property of a particular person, no misnomer of the owner or supposed owner, or other mistake relating to ownership, affects the sale or renders it void or voidable.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1364 Record of deeds issued -- Acknowledgment.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
The county auditor shall make and keep on file in the county auditor's office a record of all tax deeds issued.  The acknowledgment of all deeds shall be taken by the county recorder, or other county officer authorized to take acknowledgments, free of charge.  No charge may be made by the county auditor for the making of any deed where the county is the grantee.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365 Payment to taxing entities by county treasurer -- Investment of proceeds -- Transfer and receipt of money between taxing entities.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(1): (3); (4) Except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(1)(a): all money that the county treasurer received during the preceding month that is due to the entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(1)(b): each entity's proportionate share of money the county treasurer received during the preceding month for:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(1)(b)(i): delinquent taxes and tax notice charges;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(1)(b)(ii): interest;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(1)(b)(iii): penalties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(1)(b)(iv): costs on all tax sales and redemptions.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2): (3); (4); (1); (2)(c) Except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(a): adopt an appropriate procedure to account for the transfer and receipt of money between taxing entities and tax notice charge entities;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(b): make a final annual settlement on March 31 with each taxing entity and tax notice charge entity, including providing the entity a written statement for the most recent calendar year of the amount of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(b)(i): total taxes and tax notice charges charged;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(b)(ii): current taxes and tax notice charges collected;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(b)(iii): treasurer's relief;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(b)(iv): redemptions;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(b)(v): penalties;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(b)(vi): interest;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(b)(vii): in lieu fee collections on motor vehicles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(b)(viii): miscellaneous collections;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(c): (1) invest the money it receives under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(d): (2)(c) pay annually to each taxing entity and tax notice charge entity in the county the interest earned on the invested money under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(d)(i): on or before March 31; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(d)(ii): apportioned according to the proportion that the:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(d)(ii)(A): taxing entity's tax receipts bear to the total tax receipts received by the county treasurer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(2)(d)(ii)(B): tax notice charge entity's tax notice charge receipts bear to the total tax notice charge receipts that the county treasurer receives.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(3): (1); (2); (2)(a); (1) Notwithstanding Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(3)(a): (2)(a) negotiate with a taxing entity or tax notice charge entity a procedure other than the procedure provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(3)(b): (1) establish a date other than the tenth day of each month for the county treasurer to make payments required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1365(4): This section does not invalidate an existing contract between a county and a taxing entity or tax notice charge entity relating to the apportionment and payment of money or interest.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1366 Apportionment of redemption or assignment money.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1366(1): If property sold to the county under this title is redeemed, or the certificate of sale is assigned, the money received on account of the redemption or assignment shall be distributed as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1366(1)(a): the original and subsequent taxes, and 40% of interest, penalty, and costs of sale received shall be apportioned to the taxing entities interested, in proportion to their respective taxes;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1366(1)(b): the original and subsequent tax notice charges, and 40% of interest, penalty, and costs of sale received shall be apportioned to the tax notice charge entities interested, in proportion to their respective tax notice charges; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1366(1)(c): the balance shall be paid to the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1366(2): If a sum less than the taxes, tax notice charges, interest, penalty, and costs is accepted in settlement, the proceeds of the settlement shall be applied, first to the payment of the original and subsequent taxes and tax notice charges, and the remainder, if any, to the payment of interest, penalty, and costs.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1372 Auditor duties -- Final settlement with treasurer -- Delinquent Tax Control Account.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1372(1): The auditor shall audit the books and records of the treasurer and make a final settlement with the treasurer.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1372(2): In making the settlement the auditor shall credit the treasurer with the amount of taxes and tax notice charges for the previous year which are found to be still unpaid and shall then charge the treasurer upon the books of the county in an account which shall be called the Delinquent Tax Control Account with the full amount of delinquent taxes, tax notice charges, penalty, and costs found due the county for the previous year.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1501 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Transportable Factory-Built Housing Unit Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(1): 41-1a-102 "Manufactured home" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(2): 41-1a-102 "Mobile home" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(3): "Transportable factory-built housing unit" means a:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(3)(a): mobile home; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(3)(b): manufactured home.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(4): "Transportable factory-built housing unit park" means any tract of land on which two or more unit spaces are:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(4)(a): leased;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(4)(b): rented; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(4)(c): offered for:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(4)(c)(i): lease; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(4)(c)(ii): rent.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1502(5): "Unit space" means a specific area of land within a transportable factory-built housing unit park that is designed to accommodate one transportable factory-built housing unit for residential purposes.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1503 Property tax treatment of transportable factory-built housing units.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Regardless of whether a transportable factory-built housing unit is considered to be real property or personal property under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 59-2-1503(1): (1)(b); (1)(a) a transportable factory-built housing unit that is located in a transportable factory-built housing unit park:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1503(1)(a): (1)(b) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1503(1)(b): (1)(a) notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1503(2): (2)(b); (2)(a) a transportable factory-built housing unit that is not located in a transportable factory-built housing unit park:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1503(2)(a): (2)(b) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1503(2)(b): (2)(a) notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1601 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1601(1): 59-2-1602 "County additional property tax" means the property tax levy described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1601(2): 59-2-1602 "Fund" means the Property Tax Valuation Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1601(3): "Multicounty Appraisal Trust" means the Multicounty Appraisal Trust created by an agreement:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1601(3)(a): entered into by all of the counties in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1601(3)(b): authorized by Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1601(4): 59-2-1602 "Multicounty assessing and collecting levy" means a property tax levied in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1601(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1601(5)(a): "Property valuation service" means any service or technology that promotes uniform assessment levels for the valuation of personal property and real property in accordance with Part 3, County Assessment.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1601(5)(b): "Property valuation service" includes statewide aerial imagery, change detection, sketch validation, exception analysis, commercial valuation modeling, residential valuation modeling, automated valuation modeling, and equity analysis.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1601(6): 59-2-1606 "Statewide property tax system" means a computer assisted system for mass appraisal, equalization, collection, distribution, and administration related to property tax, created by the Multicounty Appraisal Trust in accordance with Section
