Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603 Allocation of money in the Property Tax Valuation Fund -- Use of funds.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(1): The state auditor shall annually conduct a study of each county of the fourth, fifth, or sixth class to determine:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(1)(a): the costs of assessing and collecting property taxes;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(1)(b): the ability to generate revenue from an assessing and collecting levy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(1)(c): the tax burden of levying a property tax sufficient to cover the costs of assessing and collecting property taxes.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(2): (3); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(3): (2); (1); 59-2-103 The rules described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(3)(a): (1) in accordance with the study required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(3)(b): 59-2-103 to have the greatest need to improve:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(3)(b)(i): 59-2-103 the accurate valuation and uniform assessment levels of property as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(3)(b)(ii): the efficiency of the property tax system.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(4): 59-2-103 A county shall use money disbursed from the Property Tax Valuation Fund to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(4)(a): offset the costs of assessing and collecting property taxes;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(4)(b): 59-2-103 improve the accurate valuation and uniform assessment levels of property as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(4)(c): improve the efficiency of the property tax system.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1603(5): If money remains in the fund after all allocations have been distributed to receiving counties in a calendar year, the state auditor shall retain the money in the fund for distribution the following calendar year.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1605 Accounting records for levies.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Each county shall separately budget and account for the use of any money received or expended from a levy imposed under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606 Statewide property tax system funding for counties -- Disbursements to the Multicounty Appraisal Trust -- Use of funds.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(1): 59-2-1602; 59-2-306 The funds deposited into the Multicounty Appraisal Trust in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(1)(a): 59-2-306 a statewide property tax system that will promote:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(1)(a)(i): the accurate valuation of property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(1)(a)(ii): the establishment and maintenance of uniform assessment levels among counties within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(1)(a)(iii): efficient administration of the property tax system, including the costs of assessment, collection, and distribution of property taxes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(1)(a)(iv): 59-2-306 the uniform filing of a signed statement a county assessor requests under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(1)(b): property valuation services within the counties.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(2)(a): An association representing at least two-thirds of the counties in the state shall appoint a trustee.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(2)(b): The trustee of the Multicounty Appraisal Trust shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(2)(b)(i): determine which projects to fund, including property valuation services within counties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(2)(b)(ii): oversee the administration of a statewide property tax system that meets the requirements of Subsection (1)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(3)(a): Subject to Subsection (3)(b), the trustee of the Multicounty Appraisal Trust may, in order to promote the objectives described in Subsection (1), use funds deposited into the Multicounty Appraisal Trust to hire one or more professional appraisers to provide property valuation services within a county of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(3)(b): A professional appraiser hired to provide property valuation services under this Subsection (3) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(3)(b)(i): hold an appraiser's certificate or license from the Division of Real Estate in accordance with Title 61, Chapter 2g, Real Estate Appraiser Licensing and Certification Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(3)(b)(ii): be approved by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(3)(b)(ii)(A): the commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(3)(b)(ii)(B): an association representing two or more counties in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(4)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (4)(b), each county shall adopt the statewide property tax system on or before January 1, 2026.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(4)(b): A county is exempt from the requirement in Subsection (4)(a) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(4)(b)(i): the county utilizes a computer assisted property tax system for mass appraisal other than the statewide property tax system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(4)(b)(ii): the county demonstrates to the trustee of the Multicounty Appraisal Trust and to the commission that the property tax system described in Subsection (4)(b)(i) is interoperable with the statewide property tax system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(4)(b)(iii): the trustee of the Multicounty Appraisal Trust and the commission approve the county's exemption from the requirement in Subsection (4)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1606(4)(c): The commission and an association that represents at least two-thirds of the counties in the state shall assist any county adopting the statewide property tax system.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1701 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Urban Farming Assessment Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(1): 59-2-1703 "Actively devoted to urban farming" means that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(1)(a): land is devoted to active urban farming activities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(1)(b): 59-2-1703 the land produces greater than 50% of the average agricultural production per acre:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(1)(b)(i): 59-2-1703 as determined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(1)(b)(ii): for the given type of land and the given county or area.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(2): 59-2-1705 "Rollback tax" means the tax imposed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(3): (3)(a); 59-2-1714 "Urban farming" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(3)(a): cultivating food or other marketable crop or engaging in livestock production, including grazing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(3)(b): (3)(a); 59-2-1714 performing the activity described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4): 59-2-1707; 59-2-1707; 59-2-1707; 59-2-1707; 59-2-1707; 59-2-1703; 59-2-1703 "Withdrawn from this part" means that land that has been assessed under this part is no longer assessed under this part or eligible for assessment under this part for any reason including that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(a): an owner voluntarily requests that the land be withdrawn from this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(b): the land is no longer actively devoted to urban farming;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(c): 59-2-1707; 59-2-1707
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(c)(i): the land has a change in ownership; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(c)(ii): 59-2-1707; 59-2-1707
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(c)(ii)(A): 59-2-1707 the new owner fails to apply for assessment under this part as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(c)(ii)(B): 59-2-1707 an owner applies for assessment under this part, as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(d): 59-2-1707; 59-2-1707
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(d)(i): the legal description of the land changes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(d)(ii): 59-2-1707; 59-2-1707
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(d)(ii)(A): 59-2-1707 an owner fails to apply for assessment under this part, as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(d)(ii)(B): 59-2-1707 an owner applies for assessment under this part, as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(e): 59-2-1707 the owner of the land fails to file an application as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1702(4)(f): 59-2-1703; 59-2-1703 except as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703 Qualifications for urban farming assessment.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(1)(a): For general property tax purposes, land may be assessed on the basis of the value that the land has for agricultural use if the land:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(1)(a)(i): is actively devoted to urban farming;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(1)(a)(ii): is at least one contiguous acre, but less than five acres, in size; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(1)(a)(iii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(1)(a)(iii)(A): has been actively devoted to urban farming for at least two successive years immediately preceding the tax year for which the land is assessed under this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(1)(a)(iii)(B): was assessed under Part 5, Farmland Assessment Act, for the preceding tax year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(1)(b): Land that is not actively devoted to urban farming may not be assessed as provided in Subsection (1)(a), even if the land is part of a parcel that includes land actively devoted to urban farming.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(2): 59-2-1707
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(2)(a): In determining whether land is actively devoted to urban farming, production per acre for a given county or area and a given type of land shall be determined by using the first applicable of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(2)(a)(i): production levels reported in the current publication of Utah Agricultural Statistics;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(2)(a)(ii): current crop budgets developed and published by Utah State University; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(2)(a)(iii): the highest per acre value used for land assessed under the Farmland Assessment Act for the county in which the property is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(2)(b): 59-2-1707 A county assessor may not assess land actively devoted to urban farming on the basis of the value that the land has for agricultural use under this part unless an owner annually files documentation with the county assessor:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(2)(b)(i): on a form provided by the county assessor;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(2)(b)(ii): demonstrating to the satisfaction of the county assessor that the land meets the production levels required under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(2)(b)(iii): 59-2-1707 except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(3): Notwithstanding Subsection (1)(a)(ii), a county board of equalization may grant a waiver of the acreage requirements of Subsection (1)(a)(ii):
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(3)(a): on appeal by an owner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(3)(b): if the owner submits documentation to the county assessor demonstrating to the satisfaction of the county assessor that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(3)(b)(i): the failure to meet the acreage requirements of Subsection (1)(a)(ii) arose solely as a result of an acquisition by a governmental entity by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(3)(b)(i)(A): eminent domain; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(3)(b)(i)(B): the threat or imminence of an eminent domain proceeding;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(3)(b)(ii): the land is actively devoted to urban farming; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(3)(b)(iii): no change occurs in the ownership of the land.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(a): Notwithstanding Subsection (1) and except as provided in Subsection (4)(d), land for urban farming that is intentionally allowed to lay fallow for one or more growing seasons qualifies for assessment under this part if the fallowing is conducted:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(a)(i): during periods of limited water supply;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(a)(ii): as part of a prudent farm management practice, including crop rotation, rotational grazing, or soil water management; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(a)(iii): to facilitate voluntary participation in a water management or agricultural water optimization program.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(b): If the owner of land assessed under this part fallows the land during any period in a calendar year, the owner may, on or before December 31 of the year in which the land is fallowed, provide to the county assessor written notice that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(b)(i): identifies the land that was fallowed during any period of the calendar year in which the notice is provided, including the acreage of the fallowed land;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(b)(ii): demonstrates how the fallowed land qualifies under Subsection (4)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(b)(iii): specifies whether the owner intends to fallow the land during any period in the following calendar year, and, if so, the intended duration of the fallowing period.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(c)(i): If a written notice under Subsection (4)(b) indicates that the owner intends to fallow the land during any period in the following calendar year, the county assessor may, within 45 days of receiving the written notice, require the owner to submit to the county assessor a land management plan in a form prescribed by the county assessor that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(c)(i)(A): identifies the owner's objectives in fallowing the land for the intended duration of the fallowing period;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(c)(i)(B): provides adequate assurances to the county assessor that the fallowed land will become actively devoted to urban farming upon the expiration of the intended fallowing period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(c)(i)(C): includes any other information required by the county assessor.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(c)(ii): If the owner submits to the county assessor a land management plan for fallowed land that meets the requirements of Subsection (4)(c)(i), the county assessor may not require the owner to submit a new or additional land management plan for the same land within three years from the day on which the owner submitted the plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(d): Fallowed land is withdrawn from this part if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(d)(i): the county assessor determines that the land does not qualify under Subsection (4)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(d)(ii): the owner fails to return the fallowed land to active urban farming upon the expiration of the intended fallowing period as specified in the written notice; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1703(4)(d)(iii): the owner fails to comply with the requirements of Subsection (4)(c), if a land management plan is required.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1704 Indicia of value for urban farming assessment -- Inclusion of fair market value on certain property tax notices.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1704(1): 59-2-1703; 59-2-1707; (1)(b)(i) The county assessor shall consider only those indicia of value that the land has for agricultural use as determined by the commission when assessing land:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1704(1)(a): 59-2-1703 that meets the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1704(1)(b): 59-2-1707; (1)(b)(i) for which the owner has:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1704(1)(b)(i): 59-2-1707 made a timely application in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1704(1)(b)(ii): (1)(b)(i) obtained approval of the application described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1704(2): (1); 59-2-919.1; 59-2-1317 In addition to the value determined in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1704(2)(a): 59-2-919.1 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1704(2)(b): 59-2-1317 Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705 Rollback tax -- Penalty -- Computation of tax -- Procedure -- Lien -- Interest -- Notice -- Collection -- Distribution.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(1): 59-2-1710 Except as provided in this section or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(2)(a): An owner shall notify the county assessor that land is withdrawn from this part within 120 days after the day on which the land is withdrawn from this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(2)(b): (2)(a) An owner who fails to notify the county assessor under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(2)(b)(i): $10; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(2)(b)(ii): 2% of the rollback tax due for the last year of the rollback period.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3): (3)(b); (3)(c); (5); (5); Part 5, Farmland Assessment Act; (3)(b)(i)(A); Part 5, Farmland Assessment Act; 59-2-506
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(a): (3)(b) The county assessor shall determine the amount of the rollback tax by computing the difference for the rollback period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(a)(i): the tax paid while the land was assessed under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(a)(ii): the tax that would have been paid had the property not been assessed under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(b): (3)(c); (5); (5) For purposes of this section, the rollback period is a time period that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(b)(i): (3)(c); (5) begins on the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(b)(i)(A): (3)(c) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(b)(i)(B): (5) five years preceding the day on which the county assessor mails the notice required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(b)(ii): (5) ends the day on which the county assessor mails the notice required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(c): Part 5, Farmland Assessment Act; (3)(b)(i)(A); Part 5, Farmland Assessment Act; 59-2-506 For land that was previously assessed under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4): (4)(a)(ii)(A); 4-46-102
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(a): (4)(a)(ii)(A) The county treasurer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(a)(i): collect the rollback tax; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(a)(ii): (4)(a)(ii)(A) after the rollback tax is paid, certify to the county recorder that the rollback tax lien on the property has been satisfied by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(a)(ii)(A): preparing a document that certifies that the rollback tax lien on the property has been satisfied; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(a)(ii)(B): (4)(a)(ii)(A) providing the document described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(b): 4-46-102 The county treasurer shall pay the rollback tax collected under this section as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(b)(i): 4-46-102 20% to the county for use for land and working agricultural land as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(b)(ii): 80% to the various taxing entities pro rata in accordance with the property tax levies for the current year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5): (5)(a); (5)(a); (7); (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5)(a): (5)(a) The county assessor shall mail to an owner of the land that is subject to a rollback tax a notice that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5)(a)(i): the land is withdrawn from this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5)(a)(ii): the land is subject to a rollback tax under this section; and

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705 Rollback tax -- Penalty -- Computation of tax -- Procedure -- Lien -- Interest -- Notice -- Collection -- Distribution.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(1): 59-2-1710 Except as provided in this section or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(2)(a): An owner shall notify the county assessor that land is withdrawn from this part within 120 days after the day on which the land is withdrawn from this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(2)(b): An owner who fails to notify the county assessor under Subsection (2)(a) that land is withdrawn from this part is subject to a penalty equal to the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(2)(b)(i): $10; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(2)(b)(ii): 2% of the rollback tax due for the last year of the rollback period.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3): 59-2-506
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(a): The county assessor shall determine the amount of the rollback tax by computing the difference for the rollback period described in Subsection (3)(b) between:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(a)(i): the tax paid while the land was assessed under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(a)(ii): the tax that would have been paid had the property not been assessed under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(b): For purposes of this section, the rollback period is a time period that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(b)(i): begins on the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(b)(i)(A): except as provided in Subsection (3)(c), the date the land is first assessed under this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(b)(i)(B): five years preceding the day on which the county assessor mails the notice required by Subsection (5); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(b)(ii): ends the day on which the county assessor mails the notice required by Subsection (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(3)(c): 59-2-506 For land that was previously assessed under Part 5, Farmland Assessment Act, the date described in Subsection (3)(b)(i)(A) is the date the land was first assessed under Part 5, Farmland Assessment Act, unless the land was subject to a rollback tax imposed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4): 4-46-102
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(a): The county treasurer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(a)(i): collect the rollback tax; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(a)(ii): after the rollback tax is paid, certify to the county recorder that the rollback tax lien on the property has been satisfied by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(a)(ii)(A): preparing a document that certifies that the rollback tax lien on the property has been satisfied; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(a)(ii)(B): providing the document described in Subsection (4)(a)(ii)(A) to the county recorder for recording.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(b): 4-46-102 The county treasurer shall pay the rollback tax collected under this section as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(b)(i): 4-46-102 20% to the county for use for land and working agricultural land as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(4)(b)(ii): 80% to the various taxing entities pro rata in accordance with the property tax levies for the current year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5)(a): The county assessor shall mail to an owner of the land that is subject to a rollback tax a notice that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5)(a)(i): the land is withdrawn from this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5)(a)(ii): the land is subject to a rollback tax under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5)(a)(iii): the rollback tax is delinquent if the owner of the land does not pay the tax on or before the due date listed on the notice described in this Subsection (5)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5)(b)(i): The rollback tax is due and payable within 60 days after the day on which the county assessor mails the notice required by Subsection (5)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(5)(b)(ii): Subject to Subsection (7), the rollback tax is delinquent if an owner of the land that is withdrawn from this part does not pay the rollback tax on or before the due date listed on the notice described in Subsection (5)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(6)(a): Subject to Subsection (6)(b), the rollback tax and interest imposed under Subsection (7) are a lien on the land assessed under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(6)(b): The lien described in Subsection (6)(a) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(6)(b)(i): arise upon the imposition of the rollback tax under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(6)(b)(ii): end on the day on which the rollback tax and interest imposed under Subsection (7) are paid in full; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(6)(b)(iii): relate back to the first day of the rollback period described in Subsection (3)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(7): 59-2-1331; 59-2-1317; 59-2-1317
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(7)(a): 59-2-1331 A delinquent rollback tax under this section shall accrue interest:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(7)(a)(i): from the date of delinquency until paid; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(7)(a)(ii): 59-2-1331 at the interest rate established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(7)(b): 59-2-1317; 59-2-1317 The county treasurer shall include in the notice required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(8)(a): Land that becomes ineligible for assessment under this part only as a result of an amendment to this part is not subject to the rollback tax if the owner of the land notifies the county assessor, in accordance with Subsection (2), that the land is withdrawn from this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(8)(b): Land described in Subsection (8)(a) that is withdrawn from this part as a result of an event other than an amendment to this part, whether voluntary or involuntary, is subject to the rollback tax.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1705(9): 59-2-1710; 59-2-1703 Except as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1706 Land included as urban farming.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1706(1): (1)(a); 59-2-1703(2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1706(1)(a): Land under a structure used in or related to urban farming, including a barn, shed, silo, crib, or greenhouse, or under a facility used in or related to urban farming, including a lake, dam, pond, stream, or irrigation ditch, is included in determining the total area of land actively devoted to urban farming.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1706(1)(b): (1)(a); 59-2-1703(2)(a) The land described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1706(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1706(2)(a): Except as provided in this part, land under a residence and land used in connection with residential use may not be included in determining the total area of land actively devoted to urban farming.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1706(2)(b): (2)(a) Land described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1708 Change of ownership or legal description.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1708(1): Subject to the other provisions of this section, land assessed under this part may continue to be assessed under this part if the land continues to comply with the requirements of this part, regardless of whether the land continues to have the same owner or legal description.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1708(2): (1); (1); 59-2-1705 Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1708(3): (1); (3)(a); 59-2-1703; 59-2-1707 Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1708(3)(a): there is a change in:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1708(3)(a)(i): the ownership of the land; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1708(3)(a)(ii): the legal description of the land; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1708(3)(b): (3)(a); 59-2-1703; 59-2-1707 after a change described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1708(3)(b)(i): 59-2-1703 the land does not meet the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1708(3)(b)(ii): 59-2-1707 an owner of the land fails to submit a new application for assessment as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1708(4): (3)(a) An application required by this section shall be submitted within 120 days after the day on which there is a change described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1709 Separation of land.
---------------------------------------------------
Separation of a part of the land that is being valued, assessed, and taxed under this part, either by conveyance or other action of the owner of the land, for a use other than urban farming, subjects the land that is separated to liability for the applicable rollback tax, but does not impair the continuance of urban farming valuation, assessment, and taxation for the remaining land if the remaining land continues to meet the requirements of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710 Acquisition of land by governmental entity -- Requirements -- Rollback tax -- One-time in lieu fee payment -- Passage of title.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(1): For purposes of this section, "governmental entity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(1)(a): the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(1)(b): the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(1)(c): a political subdivision of the state, including a county, city, town, school district, special district, or special service district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(1)(d): an entity created by the state or the United States, including an agency, board, bureau, commission, committee, department, division, institution, instrumentality, or office.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2): (3); (4); 59-2-1703; 10-9a-103
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(a): (3); (4); 59-2-1703 Except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(a)(i): before the governmental entity acquires the land, the land is assessed under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(a)(ii): 59-2-1703 after the governmental entity acquires the land, the land does not meet the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(b): 10-9a-103 A person dedicating a public right-of-way to a governmental entity shall pay the rollback tax imposed by this part if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(b)(i): 10-9a-103 a portion of the public right-of-way is located within a subdivision as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(b)(ii): in exchange for the dedication, the person dedicating the public right-of-way receives money or other consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3): (3)(b); (3)(a)(iii); 59-2-1705; (3)(a)(i); (ii); 59-2-1703; 59-2-1705; 59-2-1705; (3)(b); 4-46-102
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a): (3)(b) Land acquired by a governmental entity is not subject to the rollback tax imposed by this part, but is subject to a one-time in lieu fee payment as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a)(i): the governmental entity acquires the land by eminent domain;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a)(ii)(A): the land is under the threat or imminence of eminent domain proceedings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a)(ii)(B): the governmental entity provides written notice of the proceedings to the owner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a)(iii): the land is donated to the governmental entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b): (3)(a)(iii); 59-2-1705; (3)(a)(i); (ii); 59-2-1703; 59-2-1705; 59-2-1705
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(i): (3)(a)(iii); 59-2-1705 If a governmental entity acquires land under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(i)(A): to the county treasurer of the county in which the land is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(i)(B): 59-2-1705 in an amount equal to the amount of rollback tax calculated under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(ii): (3)(a)(i); (ii); 59-2-1703; 59-2-1705; 59-2-1705 A governmental entity that acquires land under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(ii)(A): 59-2-1703; 59-2-1705 if the land remaining after the acquisition by the governmental entity meets the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(ii)(B): 59-2-1705 if the land remaining after the acquisition by the governmental entity is less than one acre, in an amount equal to the rollback tax under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(c): (3)(b); 4-46-102 A county receiving an in lieu fee payment under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(c)(i): 4-46-102 20% to the county for use for open land and working agricultural land as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(c)(ii): 80% to the taxing entities in which the land is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(4): If a governmental entity acquires land subject to assessment under this part, title to the land may not pass to the governmental entity until any tax, one-time in lieu fee payment, and applicable interest due under this part are paid to the county treasurer.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710 Acquisition of land by governmental entity -- Requirements -- Rollback tax -- One-time in lieu fee payment -- Passage of title.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(1): For purposes of this section, "governmental entity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(1)(a): the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(1)(b): the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(1)(c): a political subdivision of the state, including a county, city, town, school district, special district, or special service district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(1)(d): an entity created by the state or the United States, including an agency, board, bureau, commission, committee, department, division, institution, instrumentality, or office.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2): 59-2-1703; 10-9a-103
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(a): 59-2-1703 Except as provided in Subsections (3) and (4), land acquired by a governmental entity is subject to the rollback tax imposed by this part if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(a)(i): before the governmental entity acquires the land, the land is assessed under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(a)(ii): 59-2-1703 after the governmental entity acquires the land, the land does not meet the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(b): 10-9a-103 A person dedicating a public right-of-way to a governmental entity shall pay the rollback tax imposed by this part if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(b)(i): 10-9a-103 a portion of the public right-of-way is located within a subdivision as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(2)(b)(ii): in exchange for the dedication, the person dedicating the public right-of-way receives money or other consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3): 59-2-1705; 59-2-1703; 59-2-1705; 59-2-1705; 4-46-102
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (4), land acquired by a governmental entity is not subject to the rollback tax imposed by this part, but is subject to a one-time in lieu fee payment as provided in Subsection (3)(b), if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a)(i): the governmental entity acquires the land by eminent domain;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a)(ii)(A): the land is under the threat or imminence of eminent domain proceedings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a)(ii)(B): the governmental entity provides written notice of the proceedings to the owner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(a)(iii): the land is donated to the governmental entity.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(i): 59-2-1705 If a governmental entity acquires land under Subsection (3)(a)(iii), the governmental entity shall make a one-time in lieu fee payment:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(i)(A): to the county treasurer of the county in which the land is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(i)(B): 59-2-1705 in an amount equal to the amount of rollback tax calculated under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(ii): 59-2-1703; 59-2-1705; 59-2-1705 A governmental entity that acquires land under Subsection (3)(a)(i) or (ii) shall make a one-time in lieu fee payment to the county treasurer of the county in which the land is located:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(ii)(A): 59-2-1703; 59-2-1705 if the land remaining after the acquisition by the governmental entity meets the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(b)(ii)(B): 59-2-1705 if the land remaining after the acquisition by the governmental entity is less than one acre, in an amount equal to the rollback tax under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(c): 4-46-102 A county receiving an in lieu fee payment under Subsection (3)(b) shall distribute the revenues collected from the payment as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(c)(i): 4-46-102 20% to the county for use for open land and working agricultural land as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(3)(c)(ii): 80% to the taxing entities in which the land is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(4): 59-2-1705
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(4)(a): This Subsection (4) applies only to a governmental entity that is the state or a political subdivision of the state as described in Subsections (1)(b) and (c).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(4)(b): Land acquired by a governmental entity described in Subsection (4)(a) is not subject to the rollback tax imposed by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(4)(c): 59-2-1705 Notwithstanding Subsection (4)(b), a governmental entity described in Subsection (4)(a) may not, within five years after the day on which the governmental entity acquires land, sell the land to a private entity unless the governmental entity makes a one-time in lieu fee payment:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(4)(c)(i): to the county treasurer of the county in which the land is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(4)(c)(ii): 59-2-1705 in an amount equal to the rollback tax under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(4)(c)(iii): before selling the land to the private entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1710(5): If a governmental entity acquires land subject to assessment under this part, title to the land may not pass to the governmental entity until any tax, one-time in lieu fee payment, and applicable interest due under this part are paid to the county treasurer.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1711 Tax list and duplicate.
-------------------------------------------------------
The factual details to be shown on the assessor's tax list and duplicate with respect to land that is being valued, assessed, and taxed under this part are the same as those set forth by the assessor with respect to other taxable property in the county.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1712 Rules prescribed by commission.
---------------------------------------------------------------
In accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1713 Appeal to the county board of equalization.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding SectionUtah Code Annotated § 59-2-1713(1): the county assessor makes a determination under this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1713(2): the county assessor's failure to make a determination results in the owner's request being considered denied under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1713 Appeal to the county board of equalization.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1713(1): 59-2-1004 Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1713(1)(a): the county assessor makes a determination under this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1713(1)(b): the county assessor's failure to make a determination results in the owner's request being considered denied under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1713(2): Notwithstanding Subsection (1), the commission shall, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, make rules establishing circumstances under which an appeal may be filed with the county board of equalization no later than 60 days after the deadline for an appeal described in Subsection (1).


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1714 County regulation.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1714(1): A county in this state may adopt an ordinance, authorizing residents of the county to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1714(1)(a): participate in urban farming; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1714(1)(b): utilize the provisions of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1714(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1714(2)(a): In adopting the ordinance, a county may limit urban farming to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1714(2)(a)(i): cultivating food or other marketable crop; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1714(2)(a)(ii): engaging in livestock production, including grazing.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1714(2)(b): If the county ordinance does not limit urban farming, the county authorizes urban farming by either cultivating food or other marketable crop or engaging in livestock production, including grazing.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(1): 59-2-1803 "Abatement" means a tax abatement described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(2): 59-2-1802; 59-2-1802.1; 59-2-1802.5 "Deferral" means a postponement of a tax due date or a tax notice charge granted in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(3): 59-2-1208; 59-2-1805 "Eligible owner" means an owner of an attached or a detached single-family residence:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(3)(a): 59-2-1208
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(3)(a)(i): who is 75 years old or older on or before December 31 of the year in which the individual applies for a deferral under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(3)(a)(ii): 59-2-1208 whose household income does not exceed 200% of the maximum household income certified to a homeowner's credit described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(3)(a)(iii): whose household liquid resources do not exceed 20 times the amount of property taxes levied on the owner's residence for the preceding calendar year; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(3)(b): 59-2-1805 that is a trust described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(4): 59-2-1202 "Household" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(5): 59-2-1202 "Household income" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(6): "Household liquid resources" means the following resources that are not included in an individual's household income and held by one or more members of the individual's household:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(6)(a): cash on hand;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(6)(b): money in a checking or savings account;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(6)(c): savings certificates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(6)(d): stocks or bonds.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(7): 59-2-1202; 59-2-1208 "Indigent individual" means a poor individual as described in Utah Constitution, Article XIII, Section 3, Subsection (4), who:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(7)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(7)(a)(i): is at least 65 years old; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(7)(a)(ii): is less than 65 years old and:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(7)(a)(ii)(A): the county finds that extreme hardship would prevail on the individual if the county does not defer or abate the individual's taxes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(7)(a)(ii)(B): the individual has a disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(7)(b): 59-2-1202; 59-2-1208 has a total household income, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(7)(c): resides for at least 10 months of the year in the residence that would be subject to the requested abatement or deferral; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(7)(d): cannot pay the tax assessed on the individual's residence when the tax becomes due.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(8): 59-2-1803 "Property taxes due" means the taxes due on an indigent individual's property:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(8)(a): 59-2-1803 for which a county granted an abatement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(8)(b): for the calendar year for which the county grants the abatement.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(9): 59-2-1803 "Property taxes paid" means an amount equal to the sum of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(9)(a): the amount of property taxes the indigent individual paid for the taxable year for which the indigent individual applied for the abatement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(9)(b): 59-2-1803 the amount of the abatement the county grants under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(10): "Qualifying increase" means a valuation that is equal to or more than 150% higher than the previous year's valuation for property that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(10)(a): is county assessed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(10)(b): on or after January 1 of the previous year and before January 1 of the current year has not had:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(10)(b)(i): a physical improvement if the fair market value of the physical improvement increases enough to result in the valuation increase solely as a result of the physical improvement;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(10)(b)(ii): a zoning change if the fair market value of the real property increases enough to result in the valuation increase solely as a result of the zoning change; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(10)(b)(iii): a change in the legal description of the real property, if the fair market value of the real property increases enough to result in the valuation increase solely as a result of the change in the legal description of the real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(11): "Relative" means a spouse, child, parent, grandparent, grandchild, brother, sister, parent-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, nephew, niece, aunt, uncle, first cousin, or a spouse of any of these individuals.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(12): 41-1a-102; 41-1a-102 "Residence" means real property where an individual resides, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(12)(a): 41-1a-102 a mobile home, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(12)(b): 41-1a-102 a manufactured home, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1801(13): 59-2-1301.5 "Tax notice charge" means the same as that term is defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802 Tax and tax notice charge deferral -- County discretion to grant deferral -- Creation of lien and due date.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(1)(a): In accordance with this part and after receiving an application and giving notice to the taxpayer, a county may grant a deferral on residential property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(1)(b): In determining whether to grant an application for a deferral under this section, a county shall consider an asset transferred to a relative by an applicant for deferral, if the transfer took place during the three years before the day on which the applicant applied for deferral.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(2): A county may grant a deferral described in Subsection (1) at any time:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(2)(a): after the holder of each mortgage or trust deed outstanding on the property gives written approval of the application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(2)(b): if the applicant is not the owner of income-producing assets that could be liquidated to pay the tax.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3): 59-2-1325; 59-2-1805; 59-2-1331
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(a): Taxes and tax notice charges deferred under this part accumulate with interest and applicable recording fees as a lien against the residential property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(b): 59-2-1325 A lien described in this Subsection (3) has the same legal status as a lien described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(c): To release the lien described in this Subsection (3), an owner shall pay the total amount subject to the lien:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(c)(i): upon the owner selling or otherwise disposing of the residential property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(c)(ii): when the residential property is no longer the owner's primary residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(d): 59-2-1805
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(d)(i): 59-2-1805 Notwithstanding Subsection (3)(c), an owner that receives a deferral does not have to pay the deferred taxes, deferred tax notice charges, or applicable recording fees when the residential property transfers:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(d)(i)(A): to the owner's surviving spouse as a result of the owner's death; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(d)(i)(B): 59-2-1805 between the owner and a trust described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(d)(ii): After the residential property transfers to the owner's surviving spouse, the deferred taxes, deferred tax notice charges, and applicable recording fees are due:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(d)(ii)(A): upon the surviving spouse selling or otherwise disposing of the residential property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(d)(ii)(B): when the residential property is no longer the surviving spouse's primary residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(e): 59-2-1331 When the deferral period ends:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(e)(i): 59-2-1331 the lien becomes due and subject to the collection procedures described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(3)(e)(ii): the date of levy is the date that the deferral period ends.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(4)(a): If a county grants an owner more than one deferral for the same single-family residence, the county is not required to submit for recording more than one lien.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(4)(b): Each subsequent deferral relates back to the date of the initial lien filing.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(5)(a): For each residential property for which the county grants a deferral, the treasurer shall maintain a record that is an itemized account of the total amount of deferred property taxes and deferred tax notice charges subject to the lien.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(5)(b): The record described in this Subsection (5) is the official record of the amount of the lien.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802(6): 59-2-1331 Taxes and tax notice charges deferred under this part bear interest at a rate equal to 50% of the rate described in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1 Property tax deferral for property with a qualifying increase.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(1)(a): A county shall grant a deferral for any real property if an owner of the property:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(1)(a)(i): applies for a property tax deferral on or before the date provided in Subsection (1)(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(1)(a)(ii): has a qualifying increase for the calendar year that begins on January 1, 2023, or January 1, 2024.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(1)(b): The owner of the property shall apply for a deferral on or before the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(1)(b)(i): June 30, 2025; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(1)(b)(ii): if an appeal of valuation or equalization of a property described in Subsection (1)(a) is filed with a county board of equalization, the commission, or a court of competent jurisdiction, 30 days after the day on which the county board of equalization, the commission, or a court of competent jurisdiction issues a final, unappealable judgment or order.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(2)(a): The period of deferral is five years.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(2)(b): The property owner shall pay 20% of the taxes and tax notice charges due during each year of the five-year deferral period.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(2)(c): A county shall grant a separate five-year deferral period if an owner has a qualifying increase for both the calendar year that begins on January 1, 2023, and the calendar year that begins on January 1, 2024.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(3): 59-2-1325; 59-2-1331
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(3)(a): Taxes and tax notice charges deferred under this part accumulate as a lien against the residential property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(3)(b): 59-2-1325 A lien described in this Subsection (3) has the same legal status as a lien described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(3)(c): To release the lien described in this Subsection (3), an owner shall pay the total amount subject to the lien on or before the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(3)(c)(i): the day on which the five-year deferral period ends; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(3)(c)(ii): the day the owner sells or otherwise disposes of the real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(3)(d): 59-2-1331 When the deferral period ends:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(3)(d)(i): 59-2-1331 the lien becomes due and subject to the collection procedures described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(3)(d)(ii): the date of levy is the date that the deferral period ends.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(4): 59-2-1331; 59-2-1331
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(4)(a): 59-2-1331 Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(4)(b): 59-2-1331 If the property owner does not make all deferred payments before the day on which the five-year deferral period ends, the county may assess a penalty or interest in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(5)(a): If a county grants an owner more than one deferral for the same property, the county is not required to submit for recording more than one lien.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(5)(b): Each subsequent deferral relates back to the date of the initial lien filing.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(6)(a): For each property for which the county grants a deferral, the treasurer shall maintain a record that is an itemized account of the total amount of deferred property taxes and deferred tax notice charges subject to the lien.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(6)(b): The record described in this Subsection (6) is the official record of the amount of the lien.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(7): 59-2-919.1; 59-2-1004.1; 59-2-1004; 59-2-1331 For a property that has a qualifying increase for the calendar year that begins on January 1, 2023, or January 1, 2024, a county assessor shall include with the notice provided in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(7)(a): 59-2-1004.1; 59-2-1004
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(7)(a)(i): 59-2-1004.1 for a property that has a qualifying increase for the calendar year that begins on January 1, 2023, the option to file an appeal under the extended period described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(7)(a)(ii): 59-2-1004 for a property that has a qualifying increase for the calendar year that begins on January 1, 2024, the option to file an appeal under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(7)(b): instructions for filing an appeal;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(7)(c): the option to apply for a deferral in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.1(7)(d): 59-2-1331 the ability of the county to waive any penalty or interest assessed in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5 Nondiscretionary tax and tax notice charge deferral for elderly property owners.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1): An eligible owner may apply for a deferral under this section if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1)(a): the eligible owner uses the single-family residence as the eligible owner's primary residence as of January 1 of the year for which the eligible owner applies for the deferral;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1)(b): with respect to the single-family residence, there are no:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1)(b)(i): delinquent property taxes;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1)(b)(ii): delinquent tax notice charges; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1)(b)(iii): outstanding penalties, interest, or administrative costs related to a delinquent property tax or a delinquent tax notice charge;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1)(c)(i): the value of the single-family residence for which the eligible owner applies for the deferral is no greater than the median property value of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1)(c)(i)(A): attached single-family residences within the county, if the single-family residence is an attached single-family residence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1)(c)(i)(B): detached single-family residences within the county, if the single-family residence is a detached single-family residence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1)(c)(ii): the eligible owner has owned the single-family residence for a continuous 20-year period as of January 1 of the year for which the eligible owner applies for the deferral; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(1)(d): the holder of each mortgage or trust deed outstanding on the single-family residence gives written approval of the deferral.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(2): If the conditions in Subsection (1) are satisfied and the applicant complies with the other applicable provisions of this part, a county shall defer the property tax  and tax notice charges on an attached single-family residence or a detached single-family residence for an application of deferral made on or after January 1, 2024.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(3): The values described in Subsection (1)(c) are based on the county assessment roll for the county in which the single-family residence is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(4): For purposes of Subsection (1)(c)(ii), ownership is considered continuous regardless of whether the single-family residence is transferred between an eligible owner who is an individual and an eligible owner that is a trust.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(5)(a): Upon application from a county in a form prescribed by the commission, the commission shall reimburse the county for the amount of any tax or tax notice charge that the county defers in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(5)(b): The commission may not reimburse a county:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(5)(b)(i): before the county approves the deferral; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(5)(b)(ii): for a tax or tax notice charge assessed after December 31, 2026.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(5)(c): A county that receives money in accordance with this Subsection (5) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(5)(c)(i): distribute the money to the taxing entities in the same proportion the county would have distributed the revenue from the deferred tax and deferred tax notice charge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(5)(c)(ii): repay the money no later than 30 days after the day on which the deferral lien is satisfied.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1802.5(5)(d): The commission shall deposit money received under Subsection (5)(c)(ii) into the General Fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1803 Tax abatement for indigent individuals -- Maximum amount -- Refund.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1803(1): 59-2-1208 In accordance with this part, a county may remit or abate the taxes of an indigent individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1803(1)(a): if the indigent individual owned the property as of January 1 of the year for which the county remits or abates the taxes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1803(1)(b): 59-2-1208 in an amount not more than the lesser of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1803(1)(b)(i): 59-2-1208 the amount provided as a homeowner's credit for the lowest household income bracket as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1803(1)(b)(ii): 50% of the total tax levied for the indigent individual for the current year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1803(2): A county that grants an abatement to an indigent individual shall refund to the indigent individual an amount that is equal to the amount by which the indigent individual's property taxes paid exceed the indigent individual's property taxes due, if the amount is at least $1.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804 Application for tax deferral or tax abatement.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(1): (1)(b); (2); (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(1)(a): (1)(b); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(1)(b): (1)(a) If a county finds good cause exists, the county may extend until December 31 the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(1)(c): An indigent individual may apply and potentially qualify for deferral, abatement, or both.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(2)(a): A county shall extend the default application deadline by one additional year if the applicant had been approved for a deferral under this part in the prior year; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(2)(b): the county determines that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(2)(b)(i): the applicant or a member of the applicant's immediate family had an illness or injury that prevented the applicant from filing the application on or before the default application deadline;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(2)(b)(ii): a member of the applicant's immediate family died during the calendar year of the default application deadline;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(2)(b)(iii): the failure of the applicant to file the application on or before the default application deadline was beyond the reasonable control of the applicant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(2)(b)(iv): denial of an application would be unjust or unreasonable.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(3): 59-2-1802.5; (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(3)(a): An applicant shall include in an application a signed statement that describes the eligibility of the applicant for deferral or abatement.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(3)(b): 59-2-1802.5; (3)(a) For an application for a deferral under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(3)(b)(i): proof that the applicant resides at the single-family residence for which the applicant seeks the deferral;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(3)(b)(ii): proof of age; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(3)(b)(iii): proof of household income.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(4): Both spouses shall sign an application if the application seeks a deferral or abatement on a residence:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(4)(a): in which both spouses reside; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(4)(b): that the spouses own as joint tenants.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(5): 59-2-1006 If an applicant is dissatisfied with a county's decision on the applicant's application for deferral or abatement, the applicant may appeal the decision to the commission in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1804(6): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1805 Treatment of trusts.
----------------------------------------------------
If an applicant for deferral or abatement is the grantor of a trust holding title to real or tangible personal property for which a deferral or abatement is claimed, a county may allow the applicant to claim a portion of the deferral or abatement and be treated as the owner of that portion of the property held in trust, if the applicant proves to the satisfaction of the county that:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1805(1): title to the portion of the trust will revest in the applicant upon the exercise of a power by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1805(1)(a): the claimant as grantor of the trust;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1805(1)(b): a nonadverse party; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1805(1)(c): both the claimant and a nonadverse party;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1805(2): (1); (1) title will revest as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1805(3): the applicant is obligated to pay the taxes on that portion of the trust property beginning January 1 of the year the claimant claims the deferral or abatement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1805(4): the claimant satisfies the requirements described in this part for deferral or abatement.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1806 Fraudulent or negligent representation -- Penalties and interest.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1806(1): If a county determines that a person knowingly provided false information to the county related to a requirement under this part, the county shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1806(1)(a): deny or revoke any deferral or abatement related to the false information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1806(1)(b): recover by assessment the amount of the claimed or granted deferral or abatement, plus interest that accrues at a rate of 1% per month beginning the day on which the person knowingly provided the false information.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1806(2): If a county determines that a person negligently provided false information to the county related to a requirement under this part, the county shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1806(2)(a): reduce by 10% the amount of any deferral or abatement for which the person is eligible and that relates to the false information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1806(2)(b): recover by assessment the amount of any deferral or abatement the county approved in reliance on the false information that exceeds the amount to which the person is entitled, plus interest that accrues at a rate of 1% per month beginning the day on which the deferral or abatement was approved.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1807 County legislative body authority to adopt rules or ordinances.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A county legislative body may adopt rules or ordinances to:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1807(1): effectuate an abatement or exemption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1807(2): designate one or more persons to perform the functions given to the county under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this section:Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(1): 59-10-1027 "Active component of the United States Armed Forces" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(2): 59-2-1902 "Active duty claimant" means a member of an active component of the United States Armed Forces or a reserve component of the United States Armed Forces who:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(2)(a): performed qualifying active duty military service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(2)(b): 59-2-1902 applies for an exemption described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(3): "Adjusted taxable value limit" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(3)(a): for the calendar year that begins on January 1, 2023, $479,504; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(3)(b): for each calendar year after the calendar year that begins on January 1, 2023, the amount of the adjusted taxable value limit for the previous year plus an amount calculated by multiplying the amount of the adjusted taxable value limit for the previous year by the actual percent change in the consumer price index during the previous calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(4): "Consumer price index" means the same as that term is described in Section 1(f)(4), Internal Revenue Code, and defined in Section 1(f)(5), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(5): "Deceased veteran with a disability" means a deceased individual who was a veteran with a disability at the time the individual died.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(6): "Military entity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(6)(a): the United States Department of Veterans Affairs;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(6)(b): an active component of the United States Armed Forces; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(6)(c): a reserve component of the United States Armed Forces.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(7): 26B-4-501 "Primary residence" includes the residence of a individual who does not reside in the residence if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(7)(a): 26B-4-501 does not reside in the residence because the individual is admitted as an inpatient at a health care facility as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(7)(b): otherwise meets the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(8): 59-2-1902; 59-2-1902; 59-2-1902 "Qualifying active duty military service" means at least 200 days, regardless of whether consecutive, in any continuous 365-day period of active duty military service outside the state in an active component of the United States Armed Forces or a reserve component of the United States Armed Forces, if the days of active duty military service:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(8)(a): 59-2-1902 were completed in the year before an individual applies for an exemption described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(8)(b): 59-2-1902; 59-2-1902 have not previously been counted as qualifying active duty military service for purposes of qualifying for an exemption described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(9): 59-2-1904 "Statement of disability" means the statement of disability described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(10): 59-10-1027 "Reserve component of the United States Armed Forces" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(11): 41-1a-102; 41-1a-102 "Residence" means real property where an individual resides, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(11)(a): 41-1a-102 a mobile home, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(11)(b): 41-1a-102 a manufactured home, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(12): 59-2-1903 "Veteran claimant" means one of the following individuals who applies for an exemption described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(12)(a): a veteran with a disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(12)(b): the unmarried surviving spouse:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(12)(b)(i): of a deceased veteran with a disability; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(12)(b)(ii): a veteran who was killed in action or died in the line of duty; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(12)(c): a minor orphan:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(12)(c)(i): of a deceased veteran with a disability; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(12)(c)(ii): a veteran who was killed in action or died in the line of duty.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(13): "Veteran who was killed in action or died in the line of duty" means an individual who was killed in action or died in the line of duty in an active component of the United States Armed Forces or a reserve component of the United States Armed Forces, regardless of whether that individual had a disability at the time that individual was killed in action or died in the line of duty.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1901(14): "Veteran with a disability" means an individual with a disability who, during military training or a military conflict, acquired a disability in the line of duty in an active component of the United States Armed Forces or a reserve component of the United States Armed Forces, as determined by a military entity.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903 Veteran armed forces exemption -- Amount.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(1): As used in this section, "eligible property" means property owned by a veteran claimant that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(1)(a): the veteran claimant's primary residence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(1)(b): tangible personal property that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(1)(b)(i): is held exclusively for personal use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(1)(b)(ii): is not used in a trade or business.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(2): (3); (4) In accordance with this part, the amount of taxable value of eligible property described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(3): (4); (3); (2); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(3)(a): (4); (3); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(3)(b): (3)(a) The amount of an exemption calculated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(3)(c): A county shall consider a veteran with a disability to have a 100% disability, regardless of the percentage of disability described on the statement of disability, if the United States Department of Veterans Affairs certifies the veteran in the classification of individual unemployability.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(3)(d): A county may not allow an exemption claimed under this section if the percentage of disability listed on the statement of disability is less than 10%.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(4): (2) The amount of taxable value of eligible property that is exempt under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(4)(a): the unmarried surviving spouse of a veteran who was killed in action or died in the line of duty;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(4)(b): a minor orphan of a veteran who was killed in action or died in the line of duty; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(4)(c): the unmarried surviving spouse or minor orphan of a deceased veteran with a disability:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(4)(c)(i): who served in the military service of the United States or the state prior to January 1, 1921; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(4)(c)(ii): whose percentage of disability described in the statement of disability is 10% or more.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(5): 59-2-1904 For purposes of this section and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(5)(a): is presumed to be a citizen of the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-2-1903(5)(b): may not be required to provide additional proof of citizenship to establish that the individual is a citizen of the United States.
