Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-533 Interest on overpayments.
--------------------------------------------------------
Interest shall be allowed and paid upon any overpayment in respect of any tax imposed by this chapter at the rate and in the manner prescribed in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-534 Failure to pay tax -- Suspension or forfeiture of corporate rights.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-534(1): If a tax computed and levied under this chapter is not paid before 5 p.m. on the last day of the 11th month after the date of delinquency, the corporate powers, rights, and privileges of the delinquent taxpayer, if it is a domestic corporation, shall be suspended, and if a foreign corporation, it shall forfeit its rights to do intrastate business in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-534(2): The commission shall transmit the name of each such corporation to the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code, which shall immediately record the same in such manner that it may be available to the public. This suspension or forfeiture shall become effective from the time such record is made, and the certificate of the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code shall be prima facie evidence of such suspension or forfeiture.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-535 Doing business after suspension or forfeiture of certain corporate powers, rights, and privileges -- Penalty.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-535(1): 59-7-534 A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-535(1)(a): 59-7-534 the person's corporate powers, rights, and privileges have been suspended in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-535(1)(b): the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-535(1)(b)(i): attempts or purports to exercise any of the rights, privileges, or powers of a suspended domestic corporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-535(1)(b)(ii): transacts or attempts to transact any intrastate business in this state in behalf of a forfeited foreign corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-535(2): (1)(b) Jurisdiction of the offense shall be in any county in which any part of an action described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-535(3): (1) Any contract made in violation of this section is unenforceable by a corporation or person described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-536 Relief in case of suspension or forfeiture.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-536(1): 59-7-534
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-536(1)(a): 59-7-534 Any corporation which has suffered the suspension or forfeiture referred to in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-536(1)(b): Application for revivor may be made by any stockholder or creditor of the corporation or by a majority of the surviving trustees or directors, and the same shall be filed with the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code.  Upon payment to the commission of the taxes, penalties, and reinstatement fee provided for in this section, the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code shall issue a certificate of revivor, and the applicant shall be revived.  The revivor shall be without prejudice to any action, defense, or right which has accrued by reason of the original suspension or forfeiture.  The certificate of revivor is prima facie evidence of the revivor.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-536(2): If any corporation has adopted, subsequent to such suspension or forfeiture, any name so closely resembling the name of the reviving corporation as will tend to deceive, then the reviving corporation is entitled to a certificate of revivor pursuant to the terms of this section only upon adopting a new name, and in such case nothing in this section may be construed as permitting the reviving corporation to carry on any business under its former name.   The reviving corporation may use its former name or may take the new name only upon filing an application for it with the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code, and upon the issuing of a certificate to such corporation by the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code, setting forth the right of such corporation to take such new name or use its former name as the case may be.  The Division of Corporations and Commercial Code may not issue any certificate permitting any corporation to take or use the name of any corporation already organized in this state and which has not suffered a forfeiture, or take or use a name so closely resembling the name of any corporation already organized in this state as will tend to deceive.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-537 Confidentiality of information.
--------------------------------------------------------------
The confidentiality of returns and other information filed with the commission shall be governed by Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-538 Carry forward of expired or repealed tax credit.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-538(1): Except as provided in Subsection (2), when a nonrefundable corporate income tax credit under Part 6, Credits, expires or is repealed, the commission shall allow a taxpayer to carry forward any amount of the tax credit that remains for the period of time described in the tax credit for the taxable year in which the taxpayer first claimed the tax credit.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-538(2): 59-7-607 Subsection (1) does not apply to a tax credit described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-601 Credit of interest income from state and federal securities.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-601(1): 11-14-303 There shall be allowed as a credit against the tax an amount equal to 1% of the gross interest income included in state taxable income from:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-601(1)(a): 11-14-303 bonds, notes, or other evidences of indebtedness issued by the state and its agencies and instrumentalities, and bonds, notes, or other evidences of indebtedness of any political subdivision as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-601(1)(b): stocks, notes, or obligations issued by, or guaranteed by the United States Government, or any of its agencies and instrumentalities as defined under federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-601(2): Amounts otherwise qualifying for the credit, but not allowable because the credit exceeds the tax, may be carried back three years or may be carried forward five years as a credit against the tax.  Such carryover credits shall be applied against the tax before the application of the credits earned in the current year and on a first-earned first-used basis.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-606 Tax credit -- Items using cleaner burning fuels.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-606(1): Title 19, Chapter 2, Air Conservation Act As used in this section, "board" means the Air Quality Board created under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-606(2): For taxable years beginning on or after January 1, 1992, but prior to January 1, 2003, there is allowed a tax credit against tax otherwise due under this chapter in an amount equal to 10%, up to a maximum of $50, of the total of both the purchase cost and installation services cost of each pellet burning stove, high mass wood stove, and solid fuel burning device purchased and installed that is certified by the federal Environmental Protection Agency in accordance with test procedures prescribed in 40 C.F.R. Sec. 60.534, including purchase cost and installation service cost of natural gas or propane free standing fireplaces or inserts, but not including fireplace logs.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-606(3): (3)(b) A taxpayer shall provide proof of the purchase of an item for which a tax credit is allowed under this section by:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-606(3)(a): providing proof to the board in the form the board requires by rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-606(3)(b): receiving a written statement from the board acknowledging receipt of the proof; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-606(3)(c): (3)(b) retaining the written statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-606(4): The tax credit under this section is allowed only:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-606(4)(a): against any Utah tax owed in the taxable year by the taxpayer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-606(4)(b): for the taxable year in which the item is purchased for which the tax credit is claimed.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607 Utah low-income housing tax credit.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1): 63H-8-201; 59-10-1402; 59-10-1402 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(a): "Allocation certificate" means a certificate in a form prescribed by the commission and issued by the corporation to a housing sponsor that specifies the aggregate amount of the tax credit awarded under this section to a qualified development and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(a)(i): the aggregate annual amount of the tax credit awarded that may be claimed by one or more qualified taxpayers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(a)(ii): the credit period over which the tax credit may be claimed by one or more qualified taxpayers.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(b): "Building" means a qualified low-income building as defined in Section 42(c), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(c): 63H-8-201 "Corporation" means the Utah Housing Corporation created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(d): Except as provided in Subsection (5)(c), "credit period" means the same as that term is defined in Section 42(f)(1), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(e): "Designated reporter" means, as selected by a housing sponsor, the housing sponsor or one of the housing sponsor's direct or indirect partners, members, or shareholders that will provide information to the commission regarding the allocation of tax credits under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(f): "Federal low-income housing tax credit" means the federal tax credit described in Section 42, Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(g): "Housing sponsor" means an entity that owns a qualified development.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(h): 59-10-1402 "Pass-through entity" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(i): 59-10-1402
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(i)(i): 59-10-1402 Subject to Subsection (1)(i)(ii), "pass-through entity taxpayer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(i)(ii): The determination of whether a pass-through entity taxpayer is considered a partner, member, or shareholder of a pass-through entity shall be made in accordance with applicable state law governing the pass-through entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(j): "Qualified allocation plan" means a qualified allocation plan adopted by the corporation in accordance with Section 42(m), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(k): "Qualified development" means a "qualified low-income housing project":
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(k)(i): as defined in Section 42(g)(1), Internal Revenue Code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(k)(ii): that is located in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(l): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(l)(i): "Qualified taxpayer" means a person that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(l)(i)(A): owns a direct interest or an indirect interest, through one or more pass-through entities, in a qualified development; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(l)(i)(B): meets the requirements to claim a tax credit under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(1)(l)(ii): "Qualified taxpayer" includes a pass-through entity taxpayer to which a tax credit under this section is passed through by a pass-through entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2): 59-10-1010; 59-10-1010; 59-10-1010; 59-10-1010
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(a): A qualified taxpayer may claim a nonrefundable tax credit under this section against taxes otherwise due under this chapter, Chapter 8, Gross Receipts Tax on Certain Corporations Not Required to Pay Corporate Franchise or Income Tax Act, or Chapter 9, Taxation of Admitted Insurers.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(b): The tax credit shall be in an amount equal to the tax credit amount specified on the allocation certificate that the corporation issues to a housing sponsor under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c): 59-10-1010; 59-10-1010; 59-10-1010; 59-10-1010
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(i): 59-10-1010 For a calendar year beginning on or before December 31, 2016, the aggregate annual tax credit that the corporation may allocate for each year of the credit period pursuant to this section and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(i)(A): 12.5 cents; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(i)(B): the population of Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(ii): 59-10-1010 For a calendar year beginning on or after January 1, 2017, but beginning on or before December 31, 2022, the aggregate annual tax credit that the corporation may allocate for each year of the credit period pursuant to this section and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(ii)(A): 34.5 cents; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(ii)(B): the population of Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(iii): 59-10-1010 For a calendar year beginning on or after January 1, 2023, but beginning on or before December 31, 2028, the aggregate annual tax credit that the corporation may allocate for each year of the credit period pursuant to this section and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(iv): For a calendar year beginning on or after January 1, 2024, in addition to the amount of annual tax credits available for allocation as described in Subsections (2)(c)(i) through (2)(c)(iii), the corporation shall have the following tax credit amounts available for allocation:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(iv)(A): any tax credits allocated in a calendar year that are subsequently returned to the corporation or recaptured by the corporation may be allocated in the following year, except no tax credits under this Subsection (2)(c)(iv) shall be allocated after December 31, 2028; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(iv)(B): if the actual amount of tax credits allocated in a calendar year to qualified developments is less than the total amount of credits available to be allocated to qualified developments, the balance of the credits but no more than 15% of the total amount of credits available for allocation to qualified developments may be allocated by the corporation to qualified developments in the following calendar year, except no tax credits under this Subsection (2)(c)(iv) shall be allocated after December 31, 2028.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(v): 59-10-1010 For a calendar year beginning on or after January 1, 2029, the aggregate annual tax credit that the corporation may allocate for each year of the credit period pursuant to this section and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(c)(vi): For purposes of this Subsection (2)(c), the population of Utah shall be determined in accordance with Section 146(j), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(d)(i): Subject to Subsection (2)(d)(ii), a qualified taxpayer that is a pass-through entity may allocate a tax credit under this section to one or more of the pass-through entity's pass-through entity taxpayers in any manner agreed upon, regardless of whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(d)(i)(A): the pass-through entity taxpayer is eligible to claim any portion of a federal low-income housing tax credit for the qualified development;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(d)(i)(B): the allocation of the tax credit has substantial economic effect within the meaning of Section 704(b), Internal Revenue Code; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(d)(i)(C): the pass-through entity taxpayer is considered a partner for federal income tax purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(d)(ii): With respect to a tax year, a qualified taxpayer that is a pass-through entity taxpayer may claim a tax credit allocated to the qualified taxpayer by a pass-through entity under Subsection (2)(d)(i) so long as the qualified taxpayer's ownership interest in the pass-through entity is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(d)(ii)(A): acquired on or before December 31 of the tax year to which the tax credit relates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(d)(ii)(B): reflected in the report required in Subsection (6)(b) for the tax year to which the tax credit relates.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(e): If a qualified taxpayer that is a pass-through entity taxpayer assigns to another taxpayer the pass-through entity taxpayer's ownership interest in a pass-through entity, including the pass-through entity taxpayer's interest in the tax credit associated with the ownership interest, the assignee shall be considered a qualified taxpayer and may claim the tax credit so long as the assignee's ownership interest in the pass-through entity is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(e)(i): acquired on or before December 31 of the tax year to which the tax credit relates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(2)(e)(ii): reflected in the report required in Subsection (6)(b) for the tax year to which the tax credit relates.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(3): 59-10-1010
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(3)(a): 59-10-1010 The corporation shall determine criteria and procedures for allocating the tax credit under this section and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(3)(b): The corporation shall create the criteria under Subsection (3)(a) based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(3)(b)(i): the number of affordable housing units to be created in Utah for low and moderate income persons in a qualified development;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(3)(b)(ii): the level of area median income being served by a qualified development;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(3)(b)(iii): the need for the tax credit for the economic feasibility of a qualified development; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(3)(b)(iv): the extended period for which a qualified development commits to remain as affordable housing.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(4): Any housing sponsor may apply to the corporation for a tax credit allocation under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(a)(i): The corporation shall determine the amount of the tax credit to allocate to a qualified development in accordance with the qualified allocation plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(a)(ii)(A): Before the allocation certificate is issued to the housing sponsor, the corporation shall send to the housing sponsor written notice of the corporation's preliminary determination of the tax credit amount to be allocated to the qualified development.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(a)(ii)(B): The notice described in Subsection (5)(a)(ii)(A) shall specify the corporation's preliminary determination of the tax credit amount to be allocated to the qualified development for each year of the credit period and state that allocation of the tax credit is contingent upon the issuance of an allocation certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(a)(iii): Upon approving a final cost certification in accordance with the qualified allocation plan, the corporation shall issue an allocation certificate to the housing sponsor as evidence of the allocation.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(a)(iv): The amount of the tax credit specified in an allocation certificate may not exceed 100% of the federal low-income housing tax credit awarded to a qualified development.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(b)(i): Notwithstanding Subsection (5)(a), if a housing sponsor applies to the corporation for a tax credit under this section and an allocation certificate is not yet issued, a qualified taxpayer may claim a tax credit based upon the corporation's preliminary determination of the tax credit amount as stated in the notice under Subsection (5)(a)(ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(b)(ii): Upon issuance of the allocation certificate to the housing sponsor, a qualified taxpayer that claims a tax credit under this Subsection (5)(b) shall file an amended tax return to adjust the tax credit amount if the amount previously claimed by the qualified taxpayer is different than the amount specified in the allocation certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(c): The amount of tax credit that may be claimed in the first year of the credit period may not be reduced as a result of the calculation in Section 42(f)(2), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(5)(d): On or before January 31 of each year, the corporation shall provide to the commission in a form prescribed by the commission a report that describes each allocation certificate that the corporation issued during the previous calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(6)(a): A housing sponsor shall provide to the commission identification of the housing sponsor's designated reporter.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(6)(b): For each tax year in which a tax credit is claimed under this section, the designated reporter shall provide to the commission in a form prescribed by the commission:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(6)(b)(i): a list of each qualified taxpayer that has been allocated a portion of the tax credit awarded in the allocation certificate for that tax year;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(6)(b)(ii): the amount of tax credit that has been allocated to each qualified taxpayer described in Subsection (6)(b)(i) for that tax year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(6)(b)(iii): any other information, as prescribed by the commission, to demonstrate that the aggregate annual amount of tax credits allocated to all qualified taxpayers for that tax year does not exceed the aggregate annual tax credit amount specified in the allocation certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(7)(a): All elections made by a housing sponsor pursuant to Section 42, Internal Revenue Code, shall apply to this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(7)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(7)(b)(i): If a qualified development is required to recapture a portion of any federal low-income housing tax credit, then each qualified taxpayer that has been allocated a portion of a tax credit under this section shall also be required to recapture a portion of the tax credit under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(7)(b)(ii): The state recapture amount shall be equal to the percentage of the state tax credit that equals the proportion the federal recapture amount bears to the original federal low-income housing tax credit amount subject to recapture.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(7)(b)(iii): The designated reporter shall identify each qualified taxpayer that is required to recapture a portion of any state tax credit as described in this Subsection (7)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(8)(a): Any tax credits returned to the corporation in any year may be reallocated within the same time period as provided in Section 42, Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(8)(b): Tax credits that are unallocated by the corporation in any year may be carried over for allocation in subsequent years.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(9)(a): If a tax credit is not claimed by a qualified taxpayer in the year in which it is earned because the tax credit is more than the tax owed by the qualified taxpayer, the tax credit may be carried back three years or may be carried forward five years as a credit against the tax.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(9)(b): Carryover tax credits under Subsection (9)(a) shall be applied against the tax:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(9)(b)(i): before the application of the tax credits earned in the current year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(9)(b)(ii): on a first-earned first-used basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(10): Any tax credit taken in this section may be subject to an annual audit by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(11): The corporation shall annually provide an electronic report to the Revenue and Taxation Interim Committee that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(11)(a): the purpose and effectiveness of the tax credits;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(11)(b): any recommendations for legislative changes to the aggregate tax credit amount that the corporation is authorized to allocate each year under Subsection (2)(c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(11)(c): the benefits of the tax credits to the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(12): The commission may, in consultation with the corporation, make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to implement this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(13): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(13)(a): Beginning in 2026, and every three years thereafter, the Revenue and Taxation Interim Committee shall conduct a review of the aggregate tax credit amount that the corporation is authorized to allocate and has allocated each year under Subsection (2)(c).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(13)(b): In a review under this Subsection (13), the Revenue and Taxation Interim Committee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(13)(b)(i): study any recommendations provided by the corporation under Subsection (11)(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-607(13)(b)(ii): if the Revenue and Taxation Interim Committee decides to recommend legislative action to the Legislature, prepare legislation for consideration by the Legislature in the next general session.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609 Historic preservation credit.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(1): 59-7-104
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(1)(a): 59-7-104 For tax years beginning January 1, 1993, and thereafter, there is allowed to a taxpayer subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(1)(b): All rehabilitation work to which the credit may be applied shall be approved by the State Historic Preservation Office prior to completion of the rehabilitation project as meeting the Secretary of the Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation so that the office can provide corrective comments to the taxpayer in order to preserve the historical qualities of the building.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(1)(c): Any amount of credit remaining may be carried forward to each of the five taxable years following the qualified expenditures.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(1)(d): The commission, in consultation with the State Historic Preservation Office, shall promulgate rules to implement this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(2): (1)(b) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(2)(a): "Certified historic building" means a building that is listed on the National Register of Historic Places within three years of taking the credit under this section or that is located in a National Register Historic District and the building has been designated by the State Historic Preservation Office as being of significance to the district.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(2)(b): (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(2)(b)(i): "Qualified rehabilitation expenditures" means any amount properly chargeable to the rehabilitation and restoration of the physical elements of the building, including the historic decorative elements, and the upgrading of the structural, mechanical, electrical, and plumbing systems to applicable codes.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(2)(b)(ii): (1)(b) "Qualified rehabilitation expenditures" does not include expenditures related to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(2)(b)(ii)(A): the taxpayer's personal labor;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(2)(b)(ii)(B): cost of acquisition of the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(2)(b)(ii)(C): any expenditure attributable to the enlargement of an existing building;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(2)(b)(ii)(D): (1)(b) rehabilitation of a certified historic building without the approval required in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(2)(b)(ii)(E): any expenditure attributable to landscaping and other site features, outbuildings, garages, and related features.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-609(2)(c): "Residential" means a building used for residential use, either owner occupied or income producing.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610 Recycling market development zones tax credits.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(1): 19-13-102; 59-7-104(2) Subject to other provisions of this section, a taxpayer that is a business operating in a recycling market development zone as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(1)(a): 59-7-104(2) a tax credit equal to the product of the percentage listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(1)(a)(i): commercial composting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(1)(a)(ii): manufacturing facilities or plant units that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(1)(a)(ii)(A): manufacture, process, compound, or produce recycled items of tangible personal property for sale; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(1)(a)(ii)(B): reduce or reuse postconsumer waste material; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(1)(b): a tax credit equal to the lesser of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(1)(b)(i): 20% of net expenditures to third parties for rent, wages, supplies, tools, test inventory, and utilities made by the taxpayer for establishing and operating recycling or composting technology in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(1)(b)(ii): $2,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2): (1); (1)(a); (1)(b); (1); 59-1-1406
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a): (1); (1)(a); (1)(b) To claim a tax credit described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(i): a statement that the taxpayer is operating a business within the boundaries of a recycling market development zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(ii): (1)(a) for a claim of the tax credit described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(ii)(A): the type of the machinery and equipment that the taxpayer purchased;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(ii)(B): the date that the taxpayer purchased the machinery and equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(ii)(C): the purchase price for the machinery and equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(ii)(D): the total purchase price for all machinery and equipment for which the taxpayer is claiming a tax credit;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(ii)(E): a statement that the machinery and equipment are integral to the composting or recycling process; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(ii)(F): the amount of the taxpayer's tax credit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(iii): (1)(b) for a claim of the tax credit described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(iii)(A): the type of net expenditure that the taxpayer made to a third party;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(iii)(B): the date that the taxpayer made the payment to a third party;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(iii)(C): the amount that the taxpayer paid to each third party;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(iii)(D): the total amount that the taxpayer paid to all third parties;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(iii)(E): a statement that the net expenditures support the establishment and operation of recycling or composting technology in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(a)(iii)(F): the amount of the taxpayer's tax credit.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(b): (1); 59-1-1406
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(b)(i): (1) The Department of Environmental Quality shall provide a taxpayer seeking to claim a tax credit under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(b)(ii): 59-1-1406 The taxpayer shall retain a copy of the written certification for the same period of time that a person is required to keep books and records under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(c): The Department of Environmental Quality shall submit to the commission an electronic list that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(c)(i): the name and identifying information of each taxpayer to which the Department of Environmental Quality issues a written certification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(2)(c)(ii): for each taxpayer, the amount of each tax credit listed on the written certification.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(3)(b): before any other tax credits the taxpayer may claim for the taxable year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-610(3)(c): before the taxpayer claims a tax credit authorized by this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(1)(a)(i): (4) a research tax credit of 5% of the taxpayer's qualified research expenses for the current taxable year that exceed the base amount provided for under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(1)(a)(ii): (4) a tax credit for a payment to a qualified organization for basic research as provided in Section 41(e), Internal Revenue Code, of 5% for the current taxable year that exceed the base amount provided for under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(1)(a)(iii): a tax credit equal to 7.5% of the taxpayer's qualified research expenses for the current taxable year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(1)(b): (5); (1)(a)(i); (1)(a)(iii); (1)(a)(ii) Subject to Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(1)(c): The tax credits provided for in this section do not include the alternative incremental credit provided for in Section 41(c)(4), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(2): 59-7-101 For purposes of claiming a tax credit under this section, a unitary group as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(3): (1); (1) Except as specifically provided for in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(3)(a): (1) the tax credits authorized under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(3)(b): (1) the definitions provided in Section 41, Internal Revenue Code, apply in calculating the tax credits authorized under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(4): Part 3, Allocation and Apportionment of Income - Utah UDITPA Provisions; (4)(a)(iii)(A) For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(4)(a): Part 3, Allocation and Apportionment of Income - Utah UDITPA Provisions; (4)(a)(iii)(A) the base amount shall be calculated as provided in Sections 41(c) and 41(h), Internal Revenue Code, except that:

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(4)(a)(ii): Part 3, Allocation and Apportionment of Income - Utah UDITPA Provisions a taxpayer's gross receipts include only those gross receipts attributable to sources within this state as provided in

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(4)(c): "qualified research" is as defined in Section 41(d), Internal Revenue Code, except that the term includes only qualified research conducted in this state;

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(4)(d)(i): in-house research expenses incurred in this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(4)(d)(ii): contract research expenses incurred in this state; and

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-612(5)(a)(ii): may not be carried back to a taxable year preceding the current taxable year.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614 Clean energy systems tax credits -- Definitions -- Certification -- Rulemaking authority.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1): 59-12-102; 54-17-601; 79-6-401; 59-2-405; 59-2-405.1; 59-2-405.2; 59-2-405.3; 72-10-110.5 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(a)(i): "Active solar system" means a system of equipment that is capable of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(a)(i)(A): collecting and converting incident solar radiation into thermal, mechanical, or electrical energy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(a)(i)(B): transferring a form of energy described in Subsection (1)(a)(i)(A) by a separate apparatus to storage or to the point of use.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(a)(ii): "Active solar system" includes water heating, space heating or cooling, and electrical or mechanical energy generation.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(b): 59-12-102 "Biomass system" means a system of apparatus and equipment for use in:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(b)(i): 59-12-102 converting material into biomass energy, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(b)(ii): transporting the biomass energy by separate apparatus to the point of use or storage.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(c): 54-17-601 "Clean energy source" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d): "Commercial energy system" means a system that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(i)(A): an active solar system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(i)(B): a biomass system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(i)(C): a direct use geothermal system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(i)(D): a geothermal electricity system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(i)(E): a geothermal heat pump system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(i)(F): a hydroenergy system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(i)(G): a passive solar system; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(i)(H): a wind system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(ii): located in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(iii): used:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(iii)(A): to supply energy to a commercial unit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(d)(iii)(B): as a commercial enterprise.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(e): "Commercial enterprise" means an entity, the purpose of which is to produce:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(e)(i): electrical, mechanical, or thermal energy for sale from a commercial energy system; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(e)(ii): hydrogen for sale from a hydrogen production system.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(f): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(f)(i): "Commercial unit" means a building or structure that an entity uses to transact business.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(f)(ii): Notwithstanding Subsection (1)(f)(i):
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(f)(ii)(A): with respect to an active solar system used for agricultural water pumping or a wind system, each individual energy generating device is considered to be a commercial unit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(f)(ii)(B): if an energy system is the building or structure that an entity uses to transact business, a commercial unit is the complete energy system itself.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(g): "Direct use geothermal system" means a system of apparatus and equipment that enables the direct use of geothermal energy to meet energy needs, including heating a building, an industrial process, and aquaculture.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(h): "Geothermal electricity" means energy that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(h)(i): contained in heat that continuously flows outward from the earth; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(h)(ii): used as a sole source of energy to produce electricity.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(i): "Geothermal energy" means energy generated by heat that is contained in the earth.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(j): "Geothermal heat pump system" means a system of apparatus and equipment that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(j)(i): enables the use of thermal properties contained in the earth at temperatures well below 100 degrees Fahrenheit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(j)(ii): helps meet heating and cooling needs of a structure.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(k): "Hydroenergy system" means a system of apparatus and equipment that is capable of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(k)(i): intercepting and converting kinetic water energy into electrical or mechanical energy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(k)(ii): transferring this form of energy by separate apparatus to the point of use or storage.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(l): "Hydrogen production system" means a system of apparatus and equipment, located in this state, that uses:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(l)(i): electricity from a clean energy source to create hydrogen gas from water, regardless of whether the clean energy source is at a separate facility or the same facility as the system of apparatus and equipment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(l)(ii): uses renewable natural gas to produce hydrogen gas.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(m): 79-6-401 "Office" means the Office of Energy Development created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(n): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(n)(i): "Passive solar system" means a direct thermal system that utilizes the structure of a building and the structure's operable components to provide for collection, storage, and distribution of heating or cooling during the appropriate times of the year by utilizing the climate resources available at the site.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(n)(ii): "Passive solar system" includes those portions and components of a building that are expressly designed and required for the collection, storage, and distribution of solar energy.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(o): "Photovoltaic system" means an active solar system that generates electricity from sunlight.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(p): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(p)(i): "Principal recovery portion" means the portion of a lease payment that constitutes the cost a person incurs in acquiring a commercial energy system.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(p)(ii): "Principal recovery portion" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(p)(ii)(A): an interest charge; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(p)(ii)(B): a maintenance expense.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(q): "Residential energy system" means the following used to supply energy to or for a residential unit:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(q)(i): an active solar system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(q)(ii): a biomass system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(q)(iii): a direct use geothermal system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(q)(iv): a geothermal heat pump system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(q)(v): a hydroenergy system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(q)(vi): a passive solar system; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(q)(vii): a wind system.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(r): 59-2-405; 59-2-405.1; 59-2-405.2; 59-2-405.3; 72-10-110.5
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(r)(i): "Residential unit" means a house, condominium, apartment, or similar dwelling unit that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(r)(i)(A): is located in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(r)(i)(B): serves as a dwelling for a person, group of persons, or a family.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(r)(ii): 59-2-405; 59-2-405.1; 59-2-405.2; 59-2-405.3; 72-10-110.5 "Residential unit" does not include property subject to a fee under:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(r)(ii)(A): 59-2-405 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(r)(ii)(B): 59-2-405.1 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(r)(ii)(C): 59-2-405.2 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(r)(ii)(D): 59-2-405.3 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(r)(ii)(E): 72-10-110.5 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(s): "Wind system" means a system of apparatus and equipment that is capable of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(s)(i): intercepting and converting wind energy into mechanical or electrical energy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(1)(s)(ii): transferring these forms of energy by a separate apparatus to the point of use, sale, or storage.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(2): A taxpayer may claim an energy system tax credit as provided in this section against a tax due under this chapter for a taxable year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3): 59-10-1014; 59-10-1014
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(a): Subject to the other provisions of this Subsection (3), a taxpayer may claim a nonrefundable tax credit under this Subsection (3) with respect to a residential unit the taxpayer owns or uses if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(a)(i): the taxpayer:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(a)(i)(A): purchases and completes a residential energy system to supply all or part of the energy required for the residential unit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(a)(i)(B): participates in the financing of a residential energy system to supply all or part of the energy required for the residential unit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(a)(ii): the taxpayer obtains a written certification from the office in accordance with Subsection (8).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(b)(i): Subject to Subsections (3)(b)(ii) through (iv) and, as applicable, Subsection (3)(c) or (d), the tax credit is equal to 25% of the reasonable costs of each residential energy system installed with respect to each residential unit the taxpayer owns or uses.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(b)(ii): A tax credit under this Subsection (3) may include installation costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(b)(iii): A taxpayer may claim a tax credit under this Subsection (3) for the taxable year in which the residential energy system is completed and placed in service.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(b)(iv): If the amount of a tax credit under this Subsection (3) exceeds a taxpayer's tax liability under this chapter for a taxable year, the taxpayer may carry forward the amount of the tax credit exceeding the liability for a period that does not exceed the next four taxable years.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(c): The total amount of tax credit a taxpayer may claim under this Subsection (3) for a residential energy system, other than a photovoltaic system, may not exceed $2,000 per residential unit.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(d): The total amount of tax credit a taxpayer may claim under this Subsection (3) for a photovoltaic system may not exceed:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(d)(i): for a system installed on or after January 1, 2018, but on or before December 31, 2020, $1,600;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(d)(ii): for a system installed on or after January 1, 2021, but on or before December 31, 2021, $1,200;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(d)(iii): for a system installed on or after January 1, 2022, but on or before December 31, 2022, $800;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(d)(iv): for a system installed on or after January 1, 2023, but on or before December 31, 2023, $400; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(d)(v): for a system installed on or after January 1, 2024, $0.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(e): 59-10-1014; 59-10-1014 If a taxpayer sells a residential unit to another person before the taxpayer claims the tax credit under this Subsection (3):
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(e)(i): the taxpayer may assign the tax credit to the other person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(e)(ii): 59-10-1014; 59-10-1014
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(e)(ii)(A): if the other person files a return under this chapter, the other person may claim the tax credit under this section as if the other person had met the requirements of this section to claim the tax credit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(3)(e)(ii)(B): 59-10-1014; 59-10-1014 if the other person files a return under Chapter 10, Individual Income Tax Act, the other person may claim the tax credit under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(a): Subject to the other provisions of this Subsection (4), a taxpayer may claim a refundable tax credit under this Subsection (4) with respect to a commercial energy system if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(a)(i): the commercial energy system does not use:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(a)(i)(A): wind, geothermal electricity, solar, or biomass equipment capable of producing a total of 660 or more kilowatts of electricity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(a)(i)(B): solar equipment capable of producing 2,000 or more kilowatts of electricity;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(a)(ii): the taxpayer purchases or participates in the financing of the commercial energy system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(a)(iii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(a)(iii)(A): the commercial energy system supplies all or part of the energy required by commercial units owned or used by the taxpayer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(a)(iii)(B): the taxpayer sells all or part of the energy produced by the commercial energy system as a commercial enterprise;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(a)(iv): the taxpayer has not claimed and will not claim a tax credit under Subsection (7) for hydrogen production using electricity for which the taxpayer claims a tax credit under this Subsection (4); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(a)(v): the taxpayer obtains a written certification from the office in accordance with Subsection (8).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(b)(i): Subject to Subsections (4)(b)(ii) through (iv), the tax credit is equal to 10% of the reasonable costs of the commercial energy system.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(b)(ii): A tax credit under this Subsection (4) may include installation costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(b)(iii): A taxpayer is eligible to claim a tax credit under this Subsection (4) for the taxable year in which the commercial energy system is completed and placed in service.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(b)(iv): The total amount of tax credit a taxpayer may claim under this Subsection (4) may not exceed $50,000 per commercial unit.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(c)(i): Subject to Subsections (4)(c)(ii) and (iii), a taxpayer that is a lessee of a commercial energy system installed on a commercial unit may claim a tax credit under this Subsection (4) if the taxpayer confirms that the lessor irrevocably elects not to claim the tax credit.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(c)(ii): A taxpayer described in Subsection (4)(c)(i) may claim as a tax credit under this Subsection (4) only the principal recovery portion of the lease payments.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(4)(c)(iii): A taxpayer described in Subsection (4)(c)(i) may claim a tax credit under this Subsection (4) for a period that does not exceed seven taxable years after the day on which the lease begins, as stated in the lease agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(a): Subject to the other provisions of this Subsection (5), a taxpayer may claim a refundable tax credit under this Subsection (5) with respect to a commercial energy system if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(a)(i): the commercial energy system uses wind, geothermal electricity, or biomass equipment capable of producing a total of 660 or more kilowatts of electricity;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(a)(ii)(A): the commercial energy system supplies all or part of the energy required by commercial units owned or used by the taxpayer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(a)(ii)(B): the taxpayer sells all or part of the energy produced by the commercial energy system as a commercial enterprise;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(a)(iii): the taxpayer has not claimed and will not claim a tax credit under Subsection (7) for hydrogen production using electricity for which the taxpayer claims a tax credit under this Subsection (5); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(a)(iv): the taxpayer obtains a written certification from the office in accordance with Subsection (8).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(b)(i): Subject to Subsection (5)(b)(ii), a tax credit under this Subsection (5) is equal to the product of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(b)(i)(A): 0.35 cents; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(b)(i)(B): the kilowatt hours of electricity produced and used or sold during the taxable year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(b)(ii): A taxpayer is eligible to claim a tax credit under this Subsection (5) for production occurring during a period of 48 months beginning with the month in which the commercial energy system is placed in commercial service.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(5)(c): A taxpayer that is a lessee of a commercial energy system installed on a commercial unit may claim a tax credit under this Subsection (5) if the taxpayer confirms that the lessor irrevocably elects not to claim the tax credit.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(a): Subject to the other provisions of this Subsection (6), a taxpayer may claim a refundable tax credit as provided in this Subsection (6) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(a)(i): the taxpayer owns a commercial energy system that uses solar equipment capable of producing a total of 660 or more kilowatts of electricity;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(a)(ii)(A): the commercial energy system supplies all or part of the energy required by commercial units owned or used by the taxpayer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(a)(ii)(B): the taxpayer sells all or part of the energy produced by the commercial energy system as a commercial enterprise;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(a)(iii): the taxpayer does not claim a tax credit under Subsection (4) and has not claimed and will not claim a tax credit under Subsection (7) for hydrogen production using electricity for which a taxpayer claims a tax credit under this Subsection (6); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(a)(iv): the taxpayer obtains a written certification from the office in accordance with Subsection (8).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(b)(i): Subject to Subsection (6)(b)(ii), a tax credit under this Subsection (6) is equal to the product of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(b)(i)(A): 0.35 cents; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(b)(i)(B): the kilowatt hours of electricity produced and used or sold during the taxable year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(b)(ii): A taxpayer is eligible to claim a tax credit under this Subsection (6) for production occurring during a period of 48 months beginning with the month in which the commercial energy system is placed in commercial service.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(6)(c): A taxpayer that is a lessee of a commercial energy system installed on a commercial unit may claim a tax credit under this Subsection (6) if the taxpayer confirms that the lessor irrevocably elects not to claim the tax credit.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7): 59-7-626
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(a): 59-7-626 A taxpayer may claim a refundable tax credit as provided in this Subsection (7) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(a)(i): the taxpayer owns a hydrogen production system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(a)(ii): the hydrogen production system is completed and placed in service on or after January 1, 2022;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(a)(iii): the taxpayer sells as a commercial enterprise, or supplies for the taxpayer's own use in commercial units, the hydrogen produced from the hydrogen production system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(a)(iv): 59-7-626 the taxpayer has not claimed and will not claim a tax credit under Subsection (4), (5), or (6) or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(a)(v): the taxpayer obtains a written certification from the office in accordance with Subsection (8).
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(b)(i): Subject to Subsections (7)(b)(ii) and (iii), a tax credit under this Subsection (7) is equal to the product of:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(b)(i)(A): $0.12; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(b)(i)(B): the number of kilograms of hydrogen produced during the taxable year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(b)(ii): A taxpayer may not receive a tax credit under this Subsection (7) for more than 5,600 metric tons of hydrogen per taxable year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(7)(b)(iii): A taxpayer is eligible to claim a tax credit under this Subsection (7) for production occurring during a period of 48 months beginning with the month in which the hydrogen production system is placed in commercial service.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8): 59-1-1406
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(a): Before a taxpayer may claim a tax credit under this section, the taxpayer shall obtain a written certification from the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(b): The office shall issue a taxpayer a written certification if the office determines that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(b)(i): the taxpayer meets the requirements of this section to receive a tax credit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(b)(ii): the residential energy system, the commercial energy system, or the hydrogen production system with respect to which the taxpayer seeks to claim a tax credit:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(b)(ii)(A): has been completely installed;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(b)(ii)(B): is a viable system for saving or producing energy from clean resources; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(b)(ii)(C): is safe, reliable, efficient, and technically feasible to ensure that the residential energy system, the commercial energy system, or the hydrogen production system uses the state's clean and nonrenewable energy resources in an appropriate and economic manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(c): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the office may make rules:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(c)(i): for determining whether a residential energy system, a commercial energy system, or a hydrogen production system meets the requirements of Subsection (8)(b)(ii); and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(c)(ii): for purposes of a tax credit under Subsection (3) or (4), establishing the reasonable costs of a residential energy system or a commercial energy system, as an amount per unit of energy production.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(d): 59-1-1406 A taxpayer that obtains a written certification from the office shall retain the certification for the same time period a person is required to keep books and records under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(e): The office shall submit to the commission an electronic list that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(e)(i): the name and identifying information of each taxpayer to which the office issues a written certification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(e)(ii): for each taxpayer:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(e)(ii)(A): the amount of the tax credit listed on the written certification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(8)(e)(ii)(B): the date the clean energy system was installed.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(9): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the commission may make rules to address the certification of a tax credit under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614(10): A tax credit under this section is in addition to any tax credits provided under the laws or rules and regulations of the United States.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-614.5 Refundable motion picture tax credit.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1 Tax credit related to alternative fuel heavy duty vehicles.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1): Title 19, Chapter 2, Air Conservation Act; 19-2-107 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(a): Title 19, Chapter 2, Air Conservation Act "Board" means the Air Quality Board created under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(b): 19-2-107 "Director" means the director of the Division of Air Quality appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(c): "Heavy duty vehicle" means a commercial category 7 or 8 vehicle, according to vehicle classifications established by the Federal Highway Administration.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(d): "Natural gas" includes compressed natural gas and liquified natural gas.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(e): "Qualified heavy duty vehicle" means a heavy duty vehicle that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(e)(i): has never been titled or registered and has been driven less than 7,500 miles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(e)(ii): is fueled by natural gas, has a 100% electric drivetrain, or has a hydrogen-electric drivetrain.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(f): "Qualified purchase" means the purchase of a qualified heavy duty vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(g): "Qualified taxpayer" means a taxpayer that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(g)(i): purchases a qualified heavy duty vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(g)(ii): receives a tax credit certificate from the director.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(h): "Small fleet" means 40 or fewer heavy duty vehicles registered in the state and owned by a single taxpayer.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(1)(i): "Tax credit certificate" means a certificate issued by the director certifying that a taxpayer is entitled to a tax credit as provided in this section and stating the amount of the tax credit.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2): Chapter 8, Gross Receipts Tax on Certain Corporations Not Required to Pay Corporate Franchise or Income Tax Act A qualified taxpayer may claim a nonrefundable tax credit against tax otherwise due under this chapter or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(a): in an amount equal to:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(a)(i): $15,000, if the qualified purchase occurs during calendar year 2021;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(a)(ii): $13,500, if the qualified purchase occurs during calendar year 2022;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(a)(iii): $12,000, if the qualified purchase occurs during calendar year 2023;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(a)(iv): $10,500, if the qualified purchase occurs during calendar year 2024;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(a)(v): $9,000, if the qualified purchase occurs during calendar year 2025;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(a)(vi): $7,500, if the qualified purchase occurs during calendar year 2026;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(a)(vii): $6,000, if the qualified purchase occurs during calendar year 2027;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(a)(viii): $4,500, if the qualified purchase occurs during calendar year 2028;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(a)(ix): $3,000, if the qualified purchase occurs during calendar year 2029; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(a)(x): $1,500, if the qualified purchase occurs during calendar year 2030; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(2)(b): if the qualified taxpayer certifies under oath that over 50% of the miles that the heavy duty vehicle that is the subject of the qualified purchase will travel annually will be within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(3): (3)(b); (5); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(3)(a): (3)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(3)(b): (5); (3)(a) If, by May 1 of any year, more than 30% of the aggregate annual total amount of tax credits under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(4): (4)(b); (4)(a); (5)(b); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(4)(a): (4)(b) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(4)(b): (4)(a); (5)(b); (4)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(5): 59-10-1033.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(5)(a): 59-10-1033.1 The aggregate annual total amount of tax credits represented by tax credit certificates that the director issues under this section and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(5)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (5)(a) The board shall, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6): (2)(b); (6)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(a): (2)(b); (6)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(a)(i): (2)(b) A taxpayer wishing to claim a tax credit under this section shall, using forms the board requires by rule:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(a)(i)(A): submit to the director an application for a tax credit;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(a)(i)(B): provide the director proof of a qualified purchase; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(a)(i)(C): (2)(b) submit to the director the certification under oath required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(a)(ii): (6)(a)(i) Upon receiving the application, proof, and certification required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(b): If the director determines that a taxpayer qualifies for a tax credit under this section, the director shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(b)(i): determine the amount of tax credit the taxpayer is allowed under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(b)(ii): provide the taxpayer with a written tax credit certificate:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(b)(ii)(A): stating that the taxpayer has qualified for a tax credit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(b)(ii)(B): showing the amount of tax credit for which the taxpayer has qualified under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(c): A qualified taxpayer shall retain the tax credit certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(6)(d): The director shall at least annually submit to the commission a list of all qualified taxpayers to which the director has issued a tax credit certificate and the amount of each tax credit represented by the tax credit certificates.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(7): Chapter 8, Gross Receipts Tax on Certain Corporations Not Required to Pay Corporate Franchise or Income Tax Act The tax credit under this section is allowed only:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(7)(a): Chapter 8, Gross Receipts Tax on Certain Corporations Not Required to Pay Corporate Franchise or Income Tax Act against a tax owed under this chapter or
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(7)(b): for the taxable year in which the qualified purchase occurs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(7)(c): once per vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(8): A qualified taxpayer may not assign a tax credit or a tax credit certificate under this section to another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-618.1(9): Chapter 8, Gross Receipts Tax on Certain Corporations Not Required to Pay Corporate Franchise or Income Tax Act If the qualified taxpayer receives a tax credit certificate under this section that allows a tax credit in an amount that exceeds the qualified taxpayer's tax liability under this chapter or

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-623 Nonrefundable guaranty association assessment tax credit.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-623(1): Title 31A, Chapter 28, Part 1, Utah Life and Health Insurance Guaranty Association Act; 31A-28-113; 31A-1-301; 59-9-101 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-623(1)(a): Title 31A, Chapter 28, Part 1, Utah Life and Health Insurance Guaranty Association Act; 31A-28-113 "Guaranty association assessment" means the amount of any assessments paid by a qualified insurer under the guaranty association established under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-623(1)(b): 31A-1-301; 59-9-101 "Qualified insurer" means an insurer, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-623(2): 31A-28-113 For a taxable year beginning on or after January 1, 2019, a qualified insurer may claim a nonrefundable tax credit equal to 20% of the assessment for each of the five years following the year the qualified insurer pays a guaranty association assessment, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-623(3): 31A-28-113
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-623(3)(a): 31A-28-113 A qualified insurer may carry forward the portion of the tax credit that exceeds the qualified insurer's tax liability for the taxable year in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-623(3)(b): A qualified insurer may not carry back the portion of the tax credit that exceeds the qualified insurer's tax liability for the taxable year.


Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-624 Targeted business income tax credit.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-624(1): 63N-2-302 As used in this section, "business applicant" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-624(2): 63N-2-304 For a taxable year that begins before January 1, 2023, a business applicant that is certified and issued a targeted business income tax eligibility certificate by the Governor's Office of Economic Opportunity under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626 Refundable tax credit for nonrenewable hydrogen production system.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(1): 79-6-401 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(1)(a): "Commercial enterprise" means an entity, the purpose of which is to produce hydrogen for sale from a hydrogen production system.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(1)(b): "Commercial unit" means a building or structure that an entity uses to transact business.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(1)(c): "Hydrogen production system" means a system of apparatus and equipment, located in this state, that produces hydrogen from nonrenewable sources.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(1)(d): 79-6-401 "Office" means the Office of Energy Development created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2): 59-7-614; (3); (2)(b)(ii); (iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(a): 59-7-614; (3) A taxpayer may claim a refundable credit under this section if:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(a)(i): the taxpayer owns a hydrogen production system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(a)(ii): the hydrogen production system is completed and placed in service on or after January 1, 2022;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(a)(iii): the taxpayer sells as a commercial enterprise, or supplies for the taxpayer's own use in commercial units, the hydrogen produced from the hydrogen production system;
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(a)(iv): 59-7-614 the taxpayer has not claimed and will not claim a tax credit under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(a)(v): (3) the taxpayer obtains a written certification from the office in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(b): (2)(b)(ii); (iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(b)(i): (2)(b)(ii); (iii) Subject to Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(b)(i)(A): $0.12; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(b)(i)(B): the number of kilograms of hydrogen produced during the taxable year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(b)(ii): A taxpayer may not receive a tax credit under this section for more than 5,600 metric tons of hydrogen per taxable year.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(2)(b)(iii): A taxpayer is eligible to claim a tax credit under this section for production occurring during a period of 48 months beginning with the month in which the hydrogen production system is placed in commercial service.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (3)(b)(ii); 59-1-1406
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(a): Before a taxpayer may claim a tax credit under this section, the taxpayer shall obtain a written certification from the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(b): The office shall issue a taxpayer a written certification if the office determines that:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(b)(i): the taxpayer meets the requirements of this section to receive a tax credit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(b)(ii): the hydrogen production system with respect to which the taxpayer seeks to claim a tax credit:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(b)(ii)(A): has been completely installed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(b)(ii)(B): is safe, reliable, efficient, and technically feasible to ensure that the hydrogen production system uses the state's nonrenewable energy resources in an appropriate and economic manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(c): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (3)(b)(ii) In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(d): 59-1-1406 A taxpayer that obtains a written certification from the office shall retain the certification for the same time period a person is required to keep books and records under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(e): The office shall submit to the commission an electronic list that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(e)(i): the name and identifying information of each taxpayer to which the office issues a written certification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(e)(ii): for each taxpayer:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(e)(ii)(A): the amount of the tax credit listed on the written certification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(3)(e)(ii)(B): the date the hydrogen production system was installed.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(4): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-626(5): A tax credit under this section is in addition to any tax credits provided under the laws or rules and regulations of the United States.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-803 Filing returns -- Extension.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-803(1): An organization subject to the tax imposed by this part shall file a state return on or before the date which the exempt organization is required to file its federal exempt organization business income tax return, including extensions.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-803(2): 59-7-507 If a valid federal extension is filed, the extension shall be considered valid for state purposes and payment of tax shall be made as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-804 Transition rule -- Net loss carryforwards.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Net operating losses shall be recognized to the extent recognized for federal purposes even if incurred prior to the effective date of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 59-7-805 Apportionment provisions.
--------------------------------------------------------
For purposes of this part, only the property, payroll, and sales included in the computation of unrelated business income or directly related to the unrelated business income of an exempt organization shall be included when apportioning income under

Utah Code Annotated - Title 59 - Chapter 8 - Gross Receipts Tax on Certain Corporations Not Required to Pay Corporate Franchise or Income Tax Act
*************************************************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Gross Receipts Tax on Certain Corporations Not Required to Pay Corporate Franchise or Income Tax Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-102 Purpose.
---------------------------------------
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the imposition of an in lieu excise tax on the gross receipts of corporations, other than those described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-103 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-103(1): Title 16, Chapter 6a, Utah Revised Nonprofit Corporation Act; 16-6a-1501; 16-6a-1518; 11-13-103; 11-13-103; 11-13-103 "Corporation" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-103(1)(a): Title 16, Chapter 6a, Utah Revised Nonprofit Corporation Act any domestic corporation organized under
Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-103(1)(b): 16-6a-1501; 16-6a-1518 any foreign corporation engaged in business in this state under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-103(1)(c): 11-13-103 any project entity defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-103(1)(d): 11-13-103; 11-13-103 a public agency, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-103(2): 59-7-102 "Engaging in business" means carrying on or causing to be carried on any activity through which goods or services are made or rendered by the taxpayer, except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-103(3): "Gross receipts" means the totality of the consideration that the taxpayer receives for any good or service produced or rendered in the state without any deduction or expense paid or accrued in respect to it.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-103(4): Title 59, Chapter 7, Corporate Franchise and Income Taxes "Taxpayer" means any corporation, other than an eleemosynary, religious, or charitable institution, any insurance company, credit union, or Subchapter S organization, any nonprofit hospital, educational, welfare, or employee representation organization, or any mutual benefit association engaged in business in the state that is not otherwise required to pay income or franchise tax to the state under


Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-104 Rate -- Change of rate.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-104(1): 11-13-303 Beginning on or after July 1, 2006, and subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-104(2): 59-8-104 It is the intent of the Legislature that, as a result of the tax rate decrease provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-105 Time for filing of return -- Other applicable provisions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-105(1): Each taxpayer upon whom a gross receipts tax is imposed under this chapter shall file a return with and pay the tax reflected in the return to the commission semiannually on or before the last day of July and January.
Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-105(2): Title 59, Chapter 7, Corporate Franchise and Income Taxes; Title 59, Chapter 7, Corporate Franchise and Income Taxes All other provisions applicable to the gross receipts tax imposed under this chapter shall be the appropriate provisions provided for in


Utah Code Annotated § 59-8-106 Rulemaking authority.
----------------------------------------------------
The commission is charged with the administration and enforcement of this chapter and may promulgate such rules under

Utah Code Annotated § 59-9-101(2)(d)(ii): The actuary shall recommend a premium assessment rate sufficient to provide payments of benefits and expenses from the Employers' Reinsurance Fund and to project a funded condition with assets greater than liabilities by no later than June 30, 2025.
